lines.value: phycocyanin is produced by many photoautotrophic cyanobacteria
lines.name: English

lines.value: even if cyanobacteria have large concentrations of phycocyanin productivity in the ocean is still limited due to light conditions
lines.name: English

lines.value: phycocyanin has ecological significance in indicating cyanobacteria bloom
lines.name: English

lines.value: normally chlorophyll a is used to indicate cyanobacteria numbers however since it is present in a large number of phytoplankton groups it is not an ideal measure
lines.name: English

lines.value: for instance a study in the baltic sea used phycocyanin as a marker for filamentous cyanobacteria during toxic summer blooms
lines.name: English

lines.value: some filamentous organisms in the baltic sea include nodularia spumigena and aphanizomenon flosaquae
lines.name: English

lines.value: an important cyanobacteria named spirulina arthrospira plantensis is a micro algae that produces c pc
lines.name: English

lines.value: there are many different methods of phycocyanin production including photoautotrophic mixotrophic and heterotrophic and recombinant production
lines.name: English

lines.value: photoautotrophic production of phycocyanin is where cultures of cyanobacteria are grown in open ponds in either subtropical or tropical regions
lines.name: English

lines.value: mixotrophic production of algae is where the algae are grown on cultures that have an organic carbon source like glucose
lines.name: English

lines.value: using mixotrophic production produces higher growth rates and higher biomass compared to simply using a photoautotrophic culture
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the mixotrophic culture the sum of heterotrophic and autotrophic growth separately was equal to the mixotrophic growth
lines.name: English

lines.value: heterotrophic production of phycocyanin is not light limited as per its definition
lines.name: English

lines.value: galdieria sulphuraria is a unicellular rhodophyte that contains a large amount of c pc and a small amount of allophycocyanin
lines.name: English

lines.value: g sulphuraria is an example of the heterotrophic production of c pc because its habitat is hot acidic springs and uses a number of carbon sources for growth
lines.name: English

lines.value: recombinant production of c pc is another heterotrophic method and involves gene engineering
lines.name: English

lines.value: lichen forming fungi and cyanobacteria often have a symbiotic relationship and thus phycocyanin markers can be used to show the ecological distribution of these fungi
lines.name: English

lines.value: the two genes cpca and cpcb located in the cpc operon and translated from the same mrna transcript encode for the c pc a and b-chains respectively
lines.name: English

lines.value: additional elements such as linker proteins and enzymes involved in phycobilin synthesis and the phycobiliproteins are often encoded by genes in adjacent gene clusters and the cpc operon of arthrospira platensis also encodes a linker protein assisting in the assembly of c pc complexes
lines.name: English

lines.value: in red algae the phycobiliprotein and linker protein genes are located on the plastid genome
lines.name: English

lines.value: phycocyanobilin is synthesised from heme and inserted into the c pc apo protein by three enzymatic steps
lines.name: English

lines.value: cyclic heme is oxidised to linear biliverdin ixa by heme oxygenase and further converted to 3z-phycocyanobilin the dominant phycocyanobilin isomer by 3z-phycocyanobilin:ferredoxin oxidoreductase
lines.name: English

lines.value: insertion of 3z-phycocyanobilin into the c pc apo protein via thioether bond formation is catalysed by phycocyanobilin lyase
lines.name: English

lines.value: the promoter for the cpc operon is located within the 427-bp upstream region of the cpcb gene
lines.name: English

lines.value: in a platensis 6 putative promoter sequences have been identified in the region with four of them showing expression of green fluorescent protein when transformed into e
lines.name: English

lines.value: coli
lines.name: English

lines.value: the presence of other positive elements such as light response elements in the same region have also been demonstrated
lines.name: English

lines.value: the multiple promoter and response element sequences in the cpc operon enable cyanobacteria and red algae to adjust its expression in response to multiple environmental conditions
lines.name: English

lines.value: expression of the cpca and cpcb genes is regulated by light
lines.name: English

lines.value: low light intensities stimulate synthesis of cpc and other pigments while pigment synthesis is repressed at high light intensities
lines.name: English

lines.value: temperature has also been shown to affect synthesis with specific pigment concentrations showing a clear maximum at 36 °c in arthronema africanum a cyanobacterium with particular high c pc and apc contents
lines.name: English

lines.value: nitrogen and also iron limitation induce phycobiliprotein degradation
lines.name: English

lines.value: organic carbon sources stimulate c pc synthesis in anabaena spp but seem to have almost no effector negative effect in a platensis
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the rhodophytes cyanidium caldarium and galdieria sulphuraria c pc production is repressed by glucose but stimulated by heme
lines.name: English

lines.value: pure phycocyanin extractions can be isolated from algae

lines.value: the basic segregation order is as followed

lines.value: the rupturing of the cell wall with mechanical forces freeze thawing or chemical agents enzymes
lines.name: English

lines.value: then c pc is isolate with centrifugation and purified with with ammonium sulfate precipitation or chromotography either ion or gel filtration
lines.name: English

lines.value: phycocyanin can be used in many practices it is particularly used medicine and foods applications
lines.name: English

lines.value: it can also be used in genetics where it acts a tracer due to its natural fluorescence
lines.name: English

lines.value: phycocyanin has both anti oxidant and anti inflammation properties
lines.name: English

lines.value: peroxyl hydroxyl and alkoxyl radicals are all oxidants scavenged by c pc
lines.name: English

lines.value: c pc however has a greater effect on peroxyl radicals
lines.name: English

lines.value: c pc is a metal binding antioxidant as it prevents lipid peroxidation from occurring
lines.name: English

lines.value: the peroxyl radicals are stabilized by the chromophore a subunit of c pc
lines.name: English

lines.value: for hydroxyl radicals to be scavenged it must be done in low light and with high c pc levels
lines.name: English

lines.value: hydroxyl radicals are found at inflamed parts of the body
lines.name: English

lines.value: c pc being an anti oxidant scavenges these damage inducing radicals hence being an anti inflammation agent
lines.name: English

lines.value: excess oxygen in the brain generates reactive oxygen species ros
lines.name: English

lines.value: ros causes damages to brain neurons leading to strokes
lines.name: English

lines.value: c phycocyanin scavenges hydrogen peroxide a type of ros species from the inside of astrocyte reducing oxidative stress
lines.name: English

lines.value: astrocytes also increase the production of growth factors like bdnf and ndf therefore enhance nerve regeneration
lines.name: English

lines.value: c pc also prevents astrogliosis and glial inflammation
lines.name: English

lines.value: c phycocyanin is found to have hepatotoxicity protection
lines.name: English

lines.value: vadiraja et al 1998 found an increase in the serum glutamic pyruvic transaminase sgpt when c pc is treated against heptatoxins such as carbon tetrachloride ccl4 or r-(+)-pulegone
lines.name: English

lines.value: c pc protects the liver by the means of the cytochrome p450 system
lines.name: English

lines.value: it can either disturb the production of menthofuran or disturb formation of a b-unsaturated y-ketoaldehyde
lines.name: English

lines.value: both of which are key components of the cytochrome p 450 system that produced a reactive metabolite that produce toxins when it binds to liver tissues
lines.name: English

lines.value: another possible protection mechanism by c pc can be the scavenging of reactive metabolites or free radicals if the cause is ccl4
lines.name: English

lines.value: c phycocyanin c-pc has anti cancer effects
lines.name: English

lines.value: cancer happens when cells continue to grow uncontrollably
lines.name: English

lines.value: c pc has been found to prevent cell growth
lines.name: English

lines.value: c pc stops the formation of tumour before the s phase
lines.name: English

lines.value: dna synthesis is not performed due to the tumour cell entering g0 resulting in no tumour proliferation
lines.name: English

lines.value: furthermore c pc induces apoptosis
lines.name: English

lines.value: when cells are treated with c pc ros radical oxygen species are made
lines.name: English

lines.value: these molecules decrease bcl 2 regulator of apoptosis production
lines.name: English

lines.value: here bcl 2 inhibits proteins called caspases
lines.name: English

lines.value: caspases are part of the apoptosis pathway
lines.name: English

lines.value: when bcl 2 decreases the expression of caspases increases
lines.name: English

lines.value: as a result apoptosis occurs
lines.name: English

lines.value: c pc alone is not enough to treat cancer it needs to work other drugs to overcome the persistence nature of tumour cells
lines.name: English

lines.value: c phycocyanin c-pc can be used as a natural blue food colouring
lines.name: English

lines.value: this food colourant can only be used for low temperature prepared goods because of its inability to maintaining its blue colouring in high heats unless there is an addition of preservatives or sugars
lines.name: English

lines.value: the type of sugar is irrelevant c pc is stable when there is high sugar content
lines.name: English

lines.value: knowing so c pc can be used for numerous types of foods one of which being syrups
lines.name: English

lines.value: c pc can be used for syrups ranging from green to blue colours
lines.name: English

lines.value: it can have different green tints by adding yellow food colourings

lines.value: franz friedrich anton mesmer (; ; may 23 1734 - march 5 1815 was a german physician with an interest in astronomy who theorised that there was a natural energetic transference that occurred between all animated and inanimate objects that he called animal magnetism sometimes later referred to as mesmerism
lines.name: English

lines.value: the theory attracted a wide following between about 1780 and 1850 and continued to have some influence until the end of the century
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1843 the scottish physician james braid proposed the term hypnosis for a technique derived from animal magnetism today this is the usual meaning of
lines.name: English

lines.value: mesmer was born in the village of iznang on the shore of lake constance in swabia germany a son of master forester anton mesmer 1701-after 1747 and his wife maria/ursula nee michel 1701 1770
lines.name: English

lines.value: after studying at the jesuit universities of dillingen and ingolstadt he took up the study of medicine at the university of vienna in 1759
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1766 he published a doctoral dissertation with the latin title de planetarum influxu in corpus humanum on the influence of the planets on the human body which discussed the influence of the moon and the planets on the human body and on disease
lines.name: English

lines.value: this was not medical astrology
lines.name: English

lines.value: building largely on isaac newton's theory of the tides mesmer expounded on certain tides in the human body that might be accounted for by the movements of the sun and moon
lines.name: English

lines.value: evidence assembled by frank a pattie suggests that mesmer plagiarized a part of his dissertation from a work by richard mead an eminent english physician and newton's friend
lines.name: English

lines.value: however in mesmer's day doctoral theses were not expected to be original
lines.name: English

lines.value: in january 1768 mesmer married anna maria von posch a wealthy widow and established himself as a physician in the austrian capital vienna
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the summers he lived on a splendid estate and became a patron of the arts
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1768 when court intrigue prevented the performance of la finta semplice k
lines.name: English

lines.value: 51 for which the twelve year old wolfgang amadeus mozart had composed 500 pages of music mesmer is said to have arranged a performance in his garden of mozart's bastien und bastienne k
lines.name: English

lines.value: 50 a one act opera though mozart's biographer nissen found no proof that this performance actually took place
lines.name: English

lines.value: mozart later immortalized his former patron by including a comedic reference to mesmer in his opera cosi fan tutte
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1774 mesmer produced an artificial tide in a patient francisca osterlin who suffered from hysteria by having her swallow a preparation containing iron and then attaching magnets to various parts of her body
lines.name: English

lines.value: she reported feeling streams of a mysterious fluid running through her body and was relieved of her symptoms for several hours
lines.name: English

lines.value: mesmer did not believe that the magnets had achieved the cure on their own
lines.name: English

lines.value: he felt that he had contributed animal magnetism which had accumulated in his work to her
lines.name: English

lines.value: he soon stopped using magnets as a part of his treatment
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the same year mesmer collaborated with maximilian hell
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1775 mesmer was invited to give his opinion before the munich academy of sciences on the exorcisms carried out by johann joseph gassner gabner a priest and healer who grew up in vorarlberg austria
lines.name: English

lines.value: mesmer said that while gassner was sincere in his beliefs his cures resulted because he possessed a high degree of animal magnetism
lines.name: English

lines.value: this confrontation between mesmer's secular ideas and gassner's religious beliefs marked the end of gassner's career as well as according to henri ellenberger the emergence of dynamic psychiatry
lines.name: English

lines.value: the scandal that followed mesmer's unsuccessful attempt to treat the blindness of an 18-year-old musician maria theresia paradis led him to leave vienna in 1777
lines.name: English

lines.value: in february 1778 mesmer moved to paris rented an apartment in a part of the city preferred by the wealthy and powerful and established a medical practice
lines.name: English

lines.value: paris soon divided into those who thought he was a charlatan who had been forced to flee from vienna and those who thought he had made a great discovery
lines.name: English

lines.value: in his first years in paris mesmer tried and failed to get either the royal academy of sciences or the royal society of medicine to provide official approval for his doctrines
lines.name: English

lines.value: he found only one physician of high professional and social standing charles d'eslon to become a disciple
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1779 with d'eslon's encouragement mesmer wrote an 88-page book memoire sur la decouverte du magnetisme animal to which he appended his famous 27 propositions
lines.name: English

lines.value: these propositions outlined his theory at that time
lines.name: English

lines.value: some contemporary scholars equate mesmer's animal magnetism with the qi chi of traditional chinese medicine and mesmerism with medical qigong practices
lines.name: English

lines.value: according to d'eslon mesmer understood health as the free flow of the process of life through thousands of channels in our bodies
lines.name: English

lines.value: illness was caused by obstacles to this flow
lines.name: English

lines.value: overcoming these obstacles and restoring flow produced crises which restored health
lines.name: English

lines.value: when nature failed to do this spontaneously contact with a conductor of animal magnetism was a necessary and sufficient remedy
lines.name: English

lines.value: mesmer aimed to aid or provoke the efforts of nature
lines.name: English

lines.value: to cure an insane person for example involved causing a fit of madness
lines.name: English

lines.value: the advantage of magnetism involved accelerating such crises without danger
lines.name: English

lines.value: mesmer treated patients both individually and in groups
lines.name: English

lines.value: with individuals he would sit in front of his patient with his knees touching the patient's knees pressing the patient's thumbs in his hands looking fixedly into the patient's eyes
lines.name: English

lines.value: mesmer made passes moving his hands from patients shoulders down along their arms
lines.name: English

lines.value: he then pressed his fingers on the patient's hypochondrium region the area below the diaphragm sometimes holding his hands there for hours
lines.name: English

lines.value: many patients felt peculiar sensations or had convulsions that were regarded as crises and supposed to bring about the cure
lines.name: English

lines.value: mesmer would often conclude his treatments by playing some music on a glass armonica
lines.name: English

lines.value: by 1780 mesmer had more patients than he could treat individually and he established a collective treatment known as the baquet an english physician who observed mesmer described the treatment as follows in the middle of the room is placed a vessel of about a foot and a half high which is called here a baquet
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is so large that twenty people can easily sit round it near the edge of the lid which covers it there are holes pierced corresponding to the number of persons who are to surround it into these holes are introduced iron rods bent at right angles outwards and of different heights so as to answer to the part of the body to which they are to be applied
lines.name: English

lines.value: besides these rods there is a rope which communicates between the baquet and one of the patients and from him is carried to another and so on the whole round
lines.name: English

lines.value: the most sensible effects are produced on the approach of mesmer who is said to convey the fluid by certain motions of his hands or eyes without touching the person
lines.name: English

lines.value: i have talked with several who have witnessed these effects who have convulsions occasioned and removed by a movement of the hand
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1784 without mesmer requesting it king louis xvi appointed four members of the faculty of medicine as commissioners to investigate animal magnetism as practiced by d'eslon
lines.name: English

lines.value: at the request of these commissioners the king appointed five additional commissioners from the royal academy of sciences
lines.name: English

lines.value: these included the chemist antoine lavoisier the physician joseph ignace guillotin the astronomer jean sylvain bailly and the american ambassador benjamin franklin
lines.name: English

lines.value: the commission conducted a series of experiments aimed not at determining whether mesmer's treatment worked but whether he had discovered a new physical fluid
lines.name: English

lines.value: the commission concluded that there was no evidence for such a fluid
lines.name: English

lines.value: whatever benefit the treatment produced was attributed to imagination but one of the commissioners the botanist antoine laurent de jussieu took exception to the official reports
lines.name: English

lines.value: he wrote a dissenting opinion that declared mesmer's theory credible and worthy of further investigation
lines.name: English

lines.value: the commission did not examine mesmer but investigated the practice of d'eslon
lines.name: English

lines.value: in august 1784 mesmer visited a mesmeric society in lyon
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1785 mesmer left paris
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1790 he was in vienna again to settle the estate of his deceased wife maria anna
lines.name: English

lines.value: when he sold his house in vienna in 1801 he was in paris
lines.name: English

lines.value: mesmer was driven into exile soon after the investigations on animal magnetism although his influential student armand marie jacques de chastenet marquis de pusegur 1751-1825 continued to have many followers until his death
lines.name: English

lines.value: mesmer continued to practice in frauenfeld switzerland for a number of years and died in 1815 in meersburg germany
lines.name: English

lines.value: abbe faria an indo portuguese monk in paris and a contemporary of mesmer claimed that nothing comes from the magnetizer everything comes from the subject and takes place in his imagination i.e autosuggestion generated from within the mind
lines.name: English

lines.value: java is a general purpose computer programming language that is concurrent class based object oriented and specifically designed to have as few implementation dependencies as possible
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is intended to let application developers write once run anywhere wora meaning that compiled java code can run on all platforms that support java without the need for recompilation
lines.name: English

lines.value: java applications are typically compiled to bytecode that can run on any java virtual machine jvm regardless of computer architecture
lines.name: English

lines.value: as of 2016 java is one of the most popular programming languages in use particularly for client server web applications with a reported 9 million developers
lines.name: English

lines.value: java was originally developed by james gosling at sun microsystems which has since been acquired by oracle corporation and released in 1995 as a core component of sun microsystems java platform
lines.name: English

lines.value: the language derives much of its syntax from c and c++ but it has fewer low level facilities than either of them
lines.name: English

lines.value: the original and reference implementation java compilers virtual machines and class libraries were originally released by sun under proprietary licenses
lines.name: English

lines.value: as of may 2007 in compliance with the specifications of the java community process sun relicensed most of its java technologies under the gnu general public license
lines.name: English

lines.value: others have also developed alternative implementations of these sun technologies such as the gnu compiler for java bytecode compiler gnu classpath standard libraries and icedtea web browser plugin for applets
lines.name: English

lines.value: the latest version is java 10 released on march 20 2018 which follows java 9 after only six months in line with the new release schedule
lines.name: English

lines.value: java 8 is still supported but there will be no more security updates for java 9
lines.name: English

lines.value: versions earlier than java 8 are supported by companies on a commercial basis e.g by oracle back to java 6 as of october 2017 while they still highly recommend that you uninstall pre java 8 from at least windows computers
lines.name: English

lines.value: james gosling mike sheridan and patrick naughton initiated the java language project in june 1991
lines.name: English

lines.value: java was originally designed for interactive television but it was too advanced for the digital cable television industry at the time
lines.name: English

lines.value: the language was initially called oak after an oak tree that stood outside gosling's office
lines.name: English

lines.value: later the project went by the name green and was finally renamed java from java coffee
lines.name: English

lines.value: gosling designed java with a c/c++-style syntax that system and application programmers would find familiar
lines.name: English

lines.value: sun microsystems released the first public implementation as java 1.0 in 1995
lines.name: English

lines.value: it promised write once run anywhere wora providing no cost run times on popular platforms
lines.name: English

lines.value: fairly secure and featuring configurable security it allowed network and file access restrictions
lines.name: English

lines.value: major web browsers soon incorporated the ability to run java applets within web pages and java quickly became popular
lines.name: English

lines.value: the java 1.0 compiler was rewritten in java by arthur van hoff to comply strictly with the java 1.0 language specification
lines.name: English

lines.value: with the advent of java 2 released initially as j2se 1.2 in december 1998 - 1999 new versions had multiple configurations built for different types of platforms
lines.name: English

lines.value: j2ee included technologies and apis for enterprise applications typically run in server environments while j2me featured apis optimized for mobile applications
lines.name: English

lines.value: the desktop version was renamed j2se
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2006 for marketing purposes sun renamed new j2 versions as java ee java me and java se respectively
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1997 sun microsystems approached the iso/iec jtc 1 standards body and later the ecma international to formalize java but it soon withdrew from the process
lines.name: English

lines.value: java remains a de facto standard controlled through the java community process
lines.name: English

lines.value: at one time sun made most of its java implementations available without charge despite their proprietary software status
lines.name: English

lines.value: sun generated revenue from java through the selling of licenses for specialized products such as the java enterprise system
lines.name: English

lines.value: on november 13 2006 sun released much of its java virtual machine jvm as free and open source software foss under the terms of the gnu general public license gpl
lines.name: English

lines.value: on may 8 2007 sun finished the process making all of its jvm's core code available under free software/open source distribution terms aside from a small portion of code to which sun did not hold the copyright
lines.name: English

lines.value: sun's vice president rich green said that sun's ideal role with regard to java was as an evangelist
lines.name: English

lines.value: following oracle corporation's acquisition of sun microsystems in 2009 10 oracle has described itself as the steward of java technology with a relentless commitment to fostering a community of participation and transparency
lines.name: English

lines.value: this did not prevent oracle from filing a lawsuit against google shortly after that for using java inside the android sdk see google section below
lines.name: English

lines.value: java software runs on everything from laptops to data centers game consoles to scientific supercomputers
lines.name: English

lines.value: on april 2 2010 james gosling resigned from oracle
lines.name: English

lines.value: in january 2016 oracle announced that java runtime environments based on jdk 9 will discontinue the browser plugin
lines.name: English

lines.value: there were five primary goals in the creation of the java language
lines.name: English

lines.value: , both java 8 and 10 are officially supported
lines.name: English

lines.value: major release versions of java along with their release dates
lines.name: English

lines.value: one design goal of java is portability which means that programs written for the java platform must run similarly on any combination of hardware and operating system with adequate runtime support
lines.name: English

lines.value: this is achieved by compiling the java language code to an intermediate representation called java bytecode instead of directly to architecture specific machine code
lines.name: English

lines.value: java bytecode instructions are analogous to machine code but they are intended to be executed by a virtual machine vm written specifically for the host hardware
lines.name: English

lines.value: end users commonly use a java runtime environment jre installed on their own machine for standalone java applications or in a web browser for java applets
lines.name: English

lines.value: standard libraries provide a generic way to access host specific features such as graphics threading and networking
lines.name: English

lines.value: the use of universal bytecode makes porting simple
lines.name: English

lines.value: however the overhead of interpreting bytecode into machine instructions made interpreted programs almost always run more slowly than native executables
lines.name: English

lines.value: just in time jit compilers that compile bytecodes to machine code during runtime were introduced from an early stage
lines.name: English

lines.value: java itself is platform independent and is adapted to the particular platform it is to run on by a java virtual machine for it which translates the java bytecode into the platform's machine language
lines.name: English

lines.value: oracle corporation is the current owner of the official implementation of the java se platform following their acquisition of sun microsystems on january 27 2010
lines.name: English

lines.value: this implementation is based on the original implementation of java by sun
lines.name: English

lines.value: the oracle implementation is available for microsoft windows still works for xp while only later versions are currently officially supported macos linux and solaris
lines.name: English

lines.value: because java lacks any formal standardization recognized by ecma international iso/iec ansi or other third party standards organization the oracle implementation is the de facto standard
lines.name: English

lines.value: the oracle implementation is packaged into two different distributions the java runtime environment jre which contains the parts of the java se platform required to run java programs and is intended for end users and the java development kit jdk which is intended for software developers and includes development tools such as the java compiler javadoc jar and a debugger
lines.name: English

lines.value: openjdk is another notable java se implementation that is licensed under the gnu gpl

lines.value: the goal of java is to make all implementations of java compatible
lines.name: English

lines.value: historically sun's trademark license for usage of the java brand insists that all implementations be compatible
lines.name: English

lines.value: this resulted in a legal dispute with microsoft after sun claimed that the microsoft implementation did not support rmi or jni and had added platform specific features of their own
lines.name: English

lines.value: sun sued in 1997 and in 2001 won a settlement of us$20 million as well as a court order enforcing the terms of the license from sun
lines.name: English

lines.value: as a result microsoft no longer ships java with windows
lines.name: English

lines.value: platform independent java is essential to java ee and an even more rigorous validation is required to certify an implementation
lines.name: English

lines.value: this environment enables portable server side applications
lines.name: English

lines.value: programs written in java have a reputation for being slower and requiring more memory than those written in c++
lines.name: English

lines.value: however java programs execution speed improved significantly with the introduction of just in time compilation in 1997/1998 for java 1.1 the addition of language features supporting better code analysis such as inner classes the stringbuilder class optional assertions etc and optimizations in the java virtual machine such as hotspot becoming the default for sun's jvm in 2000
lines.name: English

lines.value: with java 1.5 the performance was improved with the addition of the java.util.concurrent package including lock free implementations of the concurrentmaps and other multi core collections and it was improved further with java 1.6
lines.name: English

lines.value: some platforms offer direct hardware support for java there are microcontrollers that can run java in hardware instead of a software java virtual machine and some arm based processors could have hardware support for executing java bytecode through their jazelle option though support has mostly been dropped in current implementations of arm
lines.name: English

lines.value: java uses an automatic garbage collector to manage memory in the object lifecycle
lines.name: English

lines.value: the programmer determines when objects are created and the java runtime is responsible for recovering the memory once objects are no longer in use
lines.name: English

lines.value: once no references to an object remain the unreachable memory becomes eligible to be freed automatically by the garbage collector
lines.name: English

lines.value: something similar to a memory leak may still occur if a programmer's code holds a reference to an object that is no longer needed typically when objects that are no longer needed are stored in containers that are still in use
lines.name: English

lines.value: if methods for a nonexistent object are called a null pointer exception is thrown
lines.name: English

lines.value: one of the ideas behind java's automatic memory management model is that programmers can be spared the burden of having to perform manual memory management
lines.name: English

lines.value: in some languages memory for the creation of objects is implicitly allocated on the stack or explicitly allocated and deallocated from the heap
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the latter case the responsibility of managing memory resides with the programmer
lines.name: English

lines.value: if the program does not deallocate an object a memory leak occurs
lines.name: English

lines.value: if the program attempts to access or deallocate memory that has already been deallocated the result is undefined and difficult to predict and the program is likely to become unstable or crash
lines.name: English

lines.value: this can be partially remedied by the use of smart pointers but these add overhead and complexity
lines.name: English

lines.value: note that garbage collection does not prevent logical memory leaks i.e those where the memory is still referenced but never used
lines.name: English

lines.value: garbage collection may happen at any time
lines.name: English

lines.value: ideally it will occur when a program is idle
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is guaranteed to be triggered if there is insufficient free memory on the heap to allocate a new object this can cause a program to stall momentarily
lines.name: English

lines.value: explicit memory management is not possible in java
lines.name: English

lines.value: java does not support c/c++ style pointer arithmetic where object addresses and unsigned integers usually long integers can be used interchangeably
lines.name: English

lines.value: this allows the garbage collector to relocate referenced objects and ensures type safety and security
lines.name: English

lines.value: as in c++ and some other object oriented languages variables of java's primitive data types are either stored directly in fields for objects or on the stack for methods rather than on the heap as is commonly true for non primitive data types but see escape analysis
lines.name: English

lines.value: this was a conscious decision by java's designers for performance reasons
lines.name: English

lines.value: java contains multiple types of garbage collectors
lines.name: English

lines.value: by default hotspot uses the parallel scavenge garbage collector
lines.name: English

lines.value: however there are also several other garbage collectors that can be used to manage the heap
lines.name: English

lines.value: for 90% of applications in java the concurrent mark sweep cms garbage collector is sufficient
lines.name: English

lines.value: oracle aims to replace cms with the garbage first collector g1
lines.name: English

lines.value: the syntax of java is largely influenced by c++
lines.name: English

lines.value: unlike c++ which combines the syntax for structured generic and object oriented programming java was built almost exclusively as an object oriented language
lines.name: English

lines.value: all code is written inside classes and every data item is an object with the exception of the primitive data types i.e integers floating point numbers boolean values and characters which are not objects for performance reasons
lines.name: English

lines.value: java reuses some popular aspects of c++ such as the method
lines.name: English

lines.value: unlike c++ java does not support operator overloading or multiple inheritance for classes though multiple inheritance is supported for interfaces
lines.name: English

lines.name: English

lines.value: there are three different styles of comments a single line style marked with two slashes ( .
lines.name: English

lines.name: English

lines.value: the canadian alliance (), formally the canadian reform conservative alliance (), was a conservative and right wing populist federal political party in canada that existed from 2000 to 2003
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party was the successor to the reform party of canada and inherited its position as the official opposition in the house of commons of canada and held it throughout its existence
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party supported policies that were both fiscally and socially conservative seeking reduced government spending on social programs and reductions in taxation
lines.name: English

lines.value: the alliance was created out of the united alternative initiative launched by the reform party of canada and several provincial tory parties as a vehicle to merge with the progressive conservative party of canada
lines.name: English

lines.value: the federal progressive conservative party rebuffed the initiative to unite the right in the late fall of 1998 when it elected joe clark as its leader
lines.name: English

lines.value: in december 2003 the canadian alliance and the progressive conservative parties voted to disband and merge into the conservative party of canada
lines.name: English

lines.value: the canadian alliance's origins were in the reform party of canada which was founded in 1987 as a populist party supporting western canadian interests
lines.name: English

lines.value: however soon after its formation it moved sharply to the right and became a populist conservative largely socially conservative party
lines.name: English

lines.value: initially the reform party was motivated by the perceived need for democratic reforms and by profound western canadian discontent with the progressive conservative government of brian mulroney
lines.name: English

lines.value: led by its founder preston manning the reform party rapidly gained momentum in western canada and sought to expand its base in the east
lines.name: English

lines.value: manning son of longtime alberta premier ernest manning gained support partly from the same political constituency as his father's old party the alberta social credit party
lines.name: English

lines.value: with the collapse of a fragile tory coalition of westerners ontarians and quebec nationalists the reform party's fortunes rose
lines.name: English

lines.value: it first entered parliament in 1989 when deborah grey won a by election in an edmonton area riding
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party achieved major success in the 1993 federal election when it succeeded in replacing the progressive conservative party as the leading right wing party in canada
lines.name: English

lines.value: its platform and policies emphasized inter alia the rights and responsibilities of the individual senate and other democratic reforms and smaller more fiscally responsible government
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party did manage to become canada's official opposition
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party still failed to present a true challenge to the liberal government since its agenda was seen as too extreme for central and eastern canada
lines.name: English

lines.value: reform actually won a seat in ontario in 1993 but lost it in 1997
lines.name: English

lines.value: demand for unity by the right encouraged manning to promote a new movement the united alternative to create a small-"c conservative alternative to the liberals
lines.name: English

lines.value: manning blamed conservative vote splitting for keeping the liberals in power although some polls showed that the liberals were the second choice of many pc voters especially in ontario
lines.name: English

lines.value: manning's efforts created a strong debate in the reform party and he would even write a letter to the effect that he didn't want to lead reform anymore but would only lead the new party
lines.name: English

lines.value: the opposition died down after manning won a leadership review with 74.6% support at the january 2000 ua convention
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2000 following the second of the two united alternative conventions the party voted to dissolve in favour of a new party the canadian conservative reform alliance a declaration of policy and a new constitution
lines.name: English

lines.value: the new party's platform was a mixture of the pc and reform platforms
lines.name: English

lines.value: however it was largely seen as merely a renamed and enlarged reform party
lines.name: English

lines.value: former reform members dominated the new party and the reform caucus in the commons essentially became the alliance caucus with a few exceptions
lines.name: English

lines.value: former prime minister brian mulroney called the party reform in pantyhose and some opponents referred to the party as the reform alliance to enforce this perception
lines.name: English

lines.value: media covering the convention quickly pointed out that if one added the word party to the end of the party's name the resulting initials were ccrap humorously pronounced see- or just crap even though it like the bloc quebecois didn't actually have the word party in its name
lines.name: English

lines.value: one day later the party changed its official name to the canadian reform conservative alliance but was almost always called simply the canadian alliance or the alliance
lines.name: English

lines.value: however the ccrap nickname was still used by its opponents
lines.name: English

lines.value: deborah grey the deputy leader of reform was chosen as the new party's interim leader becoming the first female leader of the opposition in canadian history
lines.name: English

lines.value: the federal progressive conservatives under joe clark refused to participate in these talks but there was strong support from many provincial tories especially in ontario and alberta
lines.name: English

lines.value: subsequently at the new party's first leadership convention manning was defeated by stockwell day longtime treasurer finance minister of alberta
lines.name: English

lines.value: one progressive conservative senator gerry st germain joined the new party in october 2000 becoming the alliance's only member of the senate
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the fall of 2000 the liberals called a snap election that caught the alliance off guard
lines.name: English

lines.value: nonetheless the party went into the election with great hopes campaigning on tax cuts an end to the federal gun registration program and their vision of family values
lines.name: English

lines.value: day was expected to have greater appeal to ontario voters
lines.name: English

lines.value: at one point the alliance was at 30.5% in the polls and some thought they could win the election or at least knock the liberals down to a minority government
lines.name: English

lines.value: however the liberals responded by accusing the alliance of having a hidden agenda e.g to introduce two tier health care and threatening gay rights and abortion rights which the party denied
lines.name: English

lines.value: though disappointed with the election results in ontario the alliance increased its presence to 66 mps including two mps from ontario
lines.name: English

lines.value: nationally the party increased its popular vote to 25%
lines.name: English

lines.value: the alliance remained the official opposition in the house of commons
lines.name: English

lines.value: the liberals increased their large majority mostly at the expense of the ndp and the tories under joe clark lost many seats and remained in fifth place but clark was elected in calgary centre in the middle of alliance country so the overall political landscape was not significantly changed
lines.name: English

lines.value: however the alliance failure to win more than the two seats in ontario along with residual resentments from the alliance leadership contest and questions about stockwell day's competence led to caucus infighting
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the spring of 2001 eleven mps who either voluntarily resigned or were expelled from the party formed the independent alliance caucus
lines.name: English

lines.value: the group was led by chuck strahl and included grey
lines.name: English

lines.value: day offered the dissidents an amnesty at the end of the summer but seven of them including grey and strahl turned it down and formed their own parliamentary grouping the democratic representative caucus
lines.name: English

lines.value: the drc formed a coalition with clark's tories in the house which was widely seen as an attempt by clark to reunite the canadian right on his terms
lines.name: English

lines.value: the split forced day to call a new leadership convention and in april 2002 stephen harper defeated day at the subsequent canadian alliance leadership election
lines.name: English

lines.value: once harper assumed the leadership most of the rebellious mps rejoined the alliance party
lines.name: English

lines.value: two mps did not rejoin however inky mark chose to remain outside of caucus and eventually joined the tories and the scandal plagued jim pankiw was rejected when he applied for readmission to the alliance caucus
lines.name: English

lines.value: during its short history the canadian alliance never seriously entertained the prospect of forming provincial wings or forging formal links with existing provincial parties
lines.name: English

lines.value: the vast majority of alliance supporters in most provinces supported and continued to support their provincial progressive conservative parties while most supporters in saskatchewan remained loyal to the saskatchewan party and in bc supported the conservative bc liberals
lines.name: English

lines.value: however an attempt to form a provincial party with clear if unofficial links with the alliance was made in alberta where the alberta alliance was formed in 2002
lines.name: English

lines.value: under the leadership of reform/alliance activist randy thorsteinson the new party never sought a formal link with the alliance and if it had done so the overture would likely have been rebuffed since many albertan alliance members continued to support the alberta progressive conservatives
lines.name: English

lines.value: however the alberta alliance copied the colours of the alliance and many of its logos bear a striking resemblance to those of the federal party
lines.name: English

lines.value: the alberta alliance continued to grow following the federal party's merger and the provincial party fielded a full slate of candidates for the 2004 provincial election on november 22 2004 and won one seat in the legislature
lines.name: English

lines.value: on october 15 2003 the canadian alliance and the progressive conservative party under its new leader peter mackay announced that they would merge to form a new party called the conservative party of canada
lines.name: English

lines.value: the union was ratified on december 5 2003 with 96% support of the membership of the canadian alliance and on december 6 90.04% support of elected delegates in the pc party
lines.name: English

lines.value: on december 8 the party was registered with elections canada and on march 20 2004 former alliance leader stephen harper was elected as leader of the party
lines.name: English

lines.value: the new party was dubbed the alliance conservatives by critics who considered the new party a hostile takeover of the old progressive conservatives by the newer alliance
lines.name: English

lines.value: the new conservative party formed the canadian government on february 6 2006 and won two additional elections 2008 and 2011 under the leadership of stephen harper of these the 2006 and 2008 votes resulted in the party governing only as a minority only in 2011 was a majority mandate achieved
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party was defeated in 2015 by the liberals and became the official opposition party in the house of commons
lines.name: English

lines.value: *harrison trevor
lines.name: English

lines.value: a sphinx (, boeotian , plural sphinxes or sphinges is a mythical creature with the head of a human and the body of a lion
lines.name: English

lines.value: in greek tradition it has the head of a human the haunches of a lion and sometimes the wings of a bird
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is mythicised as treacherous and merciless
lines.name: English

lines.value: those who cannot answer its riddle suffer a fate typical in such mythological stories as they are killed and eaten by this ravenous monster
lines.name: English

lines.value: this deadly version of a sphinx appears in the myth and drama of oedipus
lines.name: English

lines.value: unlike the greek sphinx which was a woman the egyptian sphinx is typically shown as a man an androsphinx
lines.name: English

lines.value: in addition the egyptian sphinx was viewed as benevolent but having a ferocious strength similar to the malevolent greek version and both were thought of as guardians often flanking the entrances to temples
lines.name: English

lines.value: in european decorative art the sphinx enjoyed a major revival during the renaissance
lines.name: English

lines.value: later the sphinx image something very similar to the original ancient egyptian concept was exported into many other cultures albeit often interpreted quite differently due to translations of descriptions of the originals and the evolution of the concept in relation to other cultural traditions
lines.name: English

lines.value: sphinxes depictions are generally associated with architectural structures such as royal tombs or religious temples
lines.name: English

lines.value: the oldest known sphinx was found near gobekli tepe at another site nevali cori or possibly 195 kilometres 120 mi to the east at kortik tepe turkey and was dated to 9500 bce
lines.name: English

lines.value: the largest and most famous sphinx is the great sphinx of giza situated on the giza plateau adjacent to the great pyramids of giza on the west bank of the nile river and facing east ().
lines.name: English

lines.value: the sphinx is located southeast of the pyramids
lines.name: English

lines.value: although the date of its construction is uncertain the head of the great sphinx now is believed to bear the likeness of the pharaoh khafra
lines.name: English

lines.value: what names their builders gave to these statues is not known
lines.name: English

lines.value: at the great sphinx site a 1400 bce inscription on a stele belonging to the 18th dynasty pharaoh thutmose iv lists the names of three aspects of the local sun deity of that period khepera re atum
lines.name: English

lines.value: many pharaohs had their heads carved atop the guardian statues for their tombs to show their close relationship with the powerful solar deity sekhmet a lioness
lines.name: English

lines.value: besides the great sphinx other famous egyptian sphinxes include one bearing the head of the pharaoh hatshepsut with her likeness carved in granite which is now in the metropolitan museum of art in new york and the alabaster sphinx of memphis memphis egypt currently located within the open air museum at that site
lines.name: English

lines.value: the theme was expanded to form great avenues of guardian sphinxes lining the approaches to tombs and temples as well as serving as details atop the posts of flights of stairs to very grand complexes
lines.name: English

lines.value: nine hundred sphinxes with ram heads representing amon were built in thebes where his cult was strongest
lines.name: English

lines.value: the great sphinx has become an emblem of egypt frequently appearing on its stamps coins and official documents
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was said in late lore that hera or ares sent the sphinx from her aethiopian homeland the greeks always remembered the foreign origin of the sphinx to thebes in greece where she asked all passersby the most famous riddle in history which creature has one voice and yet becomes four footed and two footed and three footed she strangled and devoured anyone who could not answer

lines.value: variously known as purushamriga sanskrit man beast purushamirugam tamil man beast naravirala sanskrit man cat in india or as nara simha sanskrit man lion in sri lanka manusiha or manuthiha pali man lion in myanmar and norasingh from pali man lion a variation of the sanskrit nara simha or thep norasingh man-lion deity or nora nair in thailand
lines.name: English

lines.value: in contrast to the sphinxes in egypt mesopotamia and greece of which the traditions largely have been lost due to the discontinuity of the civilization the traditions related to the asian sphinxes are very much alive today

lines.value: the earliest artistic depictions of sphinxes from the south asian subcontinent are to some extent influenced by hellenistic art and writings

lines.value: these hail from the period when buddhist art underwent a phase of hellenistic influence

lines.value: in south india the sphinx is known as purushamriga sanskrit or purushamirugam tamil meaning human beast
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is found depicted in sculptural art in temples and palaces where it serves an apotropaic purpose just as the sphinxes in other parts of the ancient world
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is said by the tradition to take away the sins of the devotees when they enter a temple and to ward off evil in general
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is therefore often found in a strategic position on the gopuram or temple gateway or near the entrance of the sanctum sanctorum
lines.name: English

lines.value: the purushamriga plays a significant role in daily as well as yearly ritual of south indian shaiva temples
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the shodhasha upakaara or sixteen honors ritual performed between one and six times at significant sacred moments through the day it decorates one of the lamps of the diparadhana or lamp ceremony
lines.name: English

lines.value: and in several temples the purushamriga is also one of the vahana or vehicles of the deity during the processions of the brahmotsava or festival
lines.name: English

lines.value: in kanya kumari district in the southernmost tip of the indian subcontinent during the night of shiva ratri devotees run 75 kilometres while visiting and worshiping at twelve shiva temples

lines.value: this shiva ottam or run for shiva is performed in commemoration of the story of the race between the sphinx and bhima one of the heroes of the epic mahabharata
lines.name: English

lines.value: the indian conception of a sphinx that comes closest to the classic greek idea is in the concept of the sharabha a mythical creature part lion part man and part bird and the form of sharabha that god shiva took on to counter narasimha's violence

lines.value: such sphinxes were revived when the grottesche or grotesque decorations of the unearthed domus aurea of nero were brought to light in late 15th-century rome and she was incorporated into the classical vocabulary of arabesque designs that spread throughout europe in engravings during the 16th and 17th centuries

lines.value: sphinxes were included in the decoration of the loggia of the vatican palace by the workshop of raphael 1515-20 which updated the vocabulary of the roman grottesche

lines.value: the first appearances of sphinxes in french art are in the school of fontainebleau in the 1520s and 1530s and she continues into the late baroque style of the french regence 1715–1723
lines.name: English

lines.value: from france she spread throughout europe becoming a regular feature of the outdoors decorative sculpture of 18th-century palace gardens as in the upper belvedere palace in vienna sanssouci park in potsdam la granja in spain branicki palace in bialystok or the late rococo examples in the grounds of the portuguese queluz national palace of perhaps the 1760s with ruffs and clothed chests ending with a little cape

lines.value: sphinxes are a feature of the neoclassical interior decorations of robert adam and his followers returning closer to the undressed style of the grottesche

lines.value: james tuchet 3rd earl of castlehaven c
lines.name: English

lines.value: 1617 &ndash 11 october 1684 was the son of mervyn tuchet 2nd earl of castlehaven and his first wife elizabeth barnham 1592 &ndash c 1622
lines.name: English

lines.value: castlehaven played a prominent role in the wars of the three kingdoms that took place in the middle of the 17th century and was particularly active in the conflicts in ireland at this time
lines.name: English

lines.value: he succeeded to the irish earldom of castlehaven and baron audley of orier on 14 may 1631 when his father was attainted and beheaded
lines.name: English

lines.value: most of his estates in england were taken over by others
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was created baron audley of hely with remainder to his heirs forever on 3 june 1633 with place and precedency of george his grandfather formerly baron audley in an effort to nullify his father's attainder
lines.name: English

lines.value: however this was considered insufficient legally until a bill was passed by parliament in 1678 allowing him to inherit the original barony of audley
lines.name: English

lines.value: he married twice first elizabeth brydges daughter of grey brydges 5th baron chandos and of his wife lady anne stanley 1580–1647 who married the 2nd earl of castlehaven after lord chandos death
lines.name: English

lines.value: anne stanley was thus both the 3rd earl's stepmother and his mother in law he married secondly about 19 june 1679 elizabeth graves
lines.name: English

lines.value: castlehaven was involved in the defence of ireland during the confederate wars of the 1640s and in the subsequent cromwellian invasion
lines.name: English

lines.value: during the outbreak of the irish uprising in 1641-42 castlehaven volunteered to help suppress the irish rebels but because he was a catholic he was not trusted to take command
lines.name: English

lines.value: shortly afterwards he was arrested and detained at dublin castle
lines.name: English

lines.value: fearing that he would meet the same fate of the earl of strafford tuchet manage to escape 27 september with the help of a friend and fled south into the wicklow mountains
lines.name: English

lines.value: his intention was to gain a passage by wexford into france and from thence into england but coming to kilkenny the headquarters of the confederate catholics he was persuaded to accept a command in the army and was appointed general of horse under sir thomas preston 1st viscount tara
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was believed among the northern irish that his escape was a contrivance on the part of the earl of ormonde to work an understanding between him and his kindred in rebellion castlehaven being related to him through the marriage of his sister with edmund roe butler
lines.name: English

lines.value: even though he considered himself english he was appointed a member of the 25 strong supreme council of the confederation of kilkenny
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1644 the irish confederate supreme council decided to vote for castlehaven as the commander of a 6000 strong expedition force in a push against the ulster scottish army under robert monro
lines.name: English

lines.value: the campaign under castlehaven proved indecisive the large army being mostly used to defend the stronghold of charlemont
lines.name: English

lines.value: historians generally consider the expedition to have been a wasted opportunity as a result of this owen roe o'neill considered castlehaven to be incompetent and thomas preston also developed a dislike of him
lines.name: English

lines.value: castlehaven somewhat unconvincingly later blamed o'neill for the failure of the expedition
lines.name: English

lines.value: however castlehaven was not entirely lacking in military ability
lines.name: English

lines.value: apart from owen roe o'neill he proved to be the only irish confederate commander capable of winning conventional set piece battles
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1643 he surprised and routed hundreds of inchiquin's men in county cork at the battle of cloughleagh
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1650 he won a second small though inconsequential victory over an english parliamentarian force during the battle of tecroghan with some aid from ulick burke
lines.name: English

lines.value: the great weakness of castlehaven was that he was largely an amateur lacking the patience to conduct sieges and somewhat touchy it is said that some referred to him as tiarna beag or little lord
lines.name: English

lines.value: castlehaven wrote his memoirs in 1681 in response to the hysteria of the popish plot
lines.name: English

lines.value: like all catholic peers he had been barred from the house of lords where he sat as baron audley by the test act 1678 much to the regret of the protestant peers who held him in high regard
lines.name: English

lines.value: he took his leave on 30 november 1678 with a speech expressing his duty to the crown and his concern for the peace and welfare of the kingdom
lines.name: English

lines.value: his fellow peers knowing him to be in financial difficulty wrote to charles ii recommending castlehaven to his bounty
lines.name: English

lines.value: he died without issue on 11 october 1686 at kilcash castle county tipperary ireland and was succeeded in the earldom by his youngest brother mervyn
lines.name: English

lines.value: mervyn's older brother george was passed over by virtue of being a benedictine monk
lines.name: English

lines.value: charles-emile reynaud 8 december 1844 &ndash 9 january 1918 was a french inventor responsible for the praxinoscope an animation device patented in 1877 that improved on the zoetrope and the first projected animated films
lines.name: English

lines.value: his pantomimes lumineuses premiered on 28 october 1892 in paris
lines.name: English

lines.value: his theatre optique film system patented in 1888 is also notable as the first known instance of film perforations being used
lines.name: English

lines.value: the performances predated auguste and louis lumiere's first paid public screening of the cinematographe on 26 december 1895 often seen as the birth of cinema
lines.name: English

lines.value: charles-emile reynaud was born on 8 december 1844 in montreuil sous bois now a suburb of paris
lines.name: English

lines.value: his father benoit-claude-brutus reynaud was an engineer and medal engraver originally from le puy en velay and his mother marie caroline bellanger had been a school teacher but stayed at home to raise and educate emile from his birth
lines.name: English

lines.value: marie caroline was trained in watercolor painting by pierre joseph redoute and taught her son drawing and painting techniques
lines.name: English

lines.value: brutus gave him little tasks in his workshop and by the age of 13 emile was able to build small steam engines
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1858 he became an apprentice at a paris company where he repaired assembled and developed optical and physics instruments
lines.name: English

lines.value: he then learned industrial design at another company before working as an operator for photographer antoine samuel adam salomon
lines.name: English

lines.value: by 1862 he started his own career as a photographer in paris
lines.name: English

lines.value: he became an assistant to the famous abbe moigno in 1864
lines.name: English

lines.value: moigno gave lecture screenings with the magic lantern and converted emile to catholicism since his parents had raised him without religion
lines.name: English

lines.value: when his father died in december 1865 emile moved with his mother to puy en velay where brutus cousin dr claude auguste reynaud further educated emile in greek latin physics chemistry mechanics and natural science
lines.name: English

lines.value: in december 1873 emile reynaud started giving weekly scientific screening lectures for the students of the industrial schools of puy en velay free of charge and open to the general public
lines.name: English

lines.value: he used personally made photographic magic lantern slides in two projectors sometimes dissolving from one projection to another
lines.name: English

lines.value: after reynaud read a series of articles on optical toys published in la nature in 1876 he created a prototype praxinoscope out of a discarded cookie box
lines.name: English

lines.value: he applied for a french patent on 30 august 1877 for his then unnamed device settling on the name praxinoscope before the english patent of 13 november 1877 and returned to paris in december 1877 to manufacture and market his invention
lines.name: English

lines.value: on 21 october 1879 emile reynaud married marguerite remiatte in paris
lines.name: English

lines.value: they had two sons paul 1880 and andre 1882
lines.name: English

lines.value: reynaud's late years were tragic after 1910 when his creations outmoded by the cinematograph dejected and penniless he threw the greater part of his irreplaceable work and unique equipment into the seine
lines.name: English

lines.value: the public had forgotten his theatre optique shows which had been a celebrated attraction at the musee grevin between 1892 and 1900
lines.name: English

lines.value: he died in a hospice on the banks of the seine where he had been cared for since 29 march 1917
lines.name: English

lines.value: the pantomimes lumineuses were painted directly onto the transparent strip and manipulated by hand to create a circa 15 min show of circa 500 images per title
lines.name: English

lines.value: the socialist league () was a trotskyist organisation in finland
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was affiliated to the international socialist tendency
lines.name: English

lines.value: from 1995 until 1998 the organisation was known as communist youth kommunistinuoret
lines.name: English

lines.value: at its founding the communist youth was close to the new communist party of finland skp but supporters of the skp left the organisation after the name change
lines.name: English

lines.value: they founded communist youth league of finland in 2000
lines.name: English

lines.value: the socialist league published the magazines murros and antikapitalisti
lines.name: English

lines.value: the organisation was active in different left led protests
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party of the hungarian community (, ; smk mkp formerly known as party of the hungarian coalition (, ), is a political party in slovakia for the ethnic hungarian minority
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was led by pal csaky formerly led by bela bugar until the parliamentary election of 12 june 2010 where it failed to acquire 5% of the popular vote the threshold necessary for entering the national council of the slovak republic
lines.name: English

lines.value: its votes went largely to most hid a new party led by former smk leader bela bugar
lines.name: English

lines.value: in response csaky and the whole party leadership resigned
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party became a member of the european people's party epp on 7 june 2000
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party was founded in 1998 in response to an anti coalition law passed
lines.name: English

lines.value: the law prevented parties from forming electoral cartels at election time which small parties had used to overcome the 5% electoral threshold
lines.name: English

lines.value: three parties representing the hungarian minority had formed such a cartel called hungarian coalition in the 1994 election and had won 10.2% of the vote
lines.name: English

lines.value: to comply with the new law the three parties - the hungarian christian democratic movement coexistence and the hungarian civic party - merged to form the party of the hungarian coalition
lines.name: English

lines.value: following the 2002 parliamentary election in slovakia the party of the hungarian coalition joined the slovak governing coalition for the second time after the 1998 2002 term obtained 321069 votes 11.16% of all votes and was the most stable political party in the governing coalition
lines.name: English

lines.value: at the eu parliament election in 2004 the party won 13.24% of the vote
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party had 4 ministers pal csaky - deputy prime minister for european integration and minority rights laszlo miklos - minister of environment laszlo gyurovszky - minister of construction and regional development and zsolt simon - minister of agriculture and 6 state secretaries ministry of finance ministry of education ministry of economy ministry of culture ministry of foreign affairs and ministry of construction and regional development in the slovak government
lines.name: English

lines.value: bela bugar the president of the party of the hungarian coalition at that time was the vice president of the national council of the slovak republic
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the parliamentary election of 17 june 2006 the party won 11.7% of the popular vote and 20 out of 150 seats but lost its participation in the government
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the parliamentary election of 12 june 2010 the party missed the 5% border needed for participation in parliament by receiving 4.33% and lost its position in parliament
lines.name: English

lines.value: the smk mkp also proved unable to obtain 5% of the votes in the 2012 parliamentary election
lines.name: English

lines.value: on 22 september 2012 the party was renamed to party of the hungarian community
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the 2014 european elections smk mkp came in seventh place nationally receiving 6.53% of the vote and electing 1 mep
lines.name: English

lines.value: although the party of hungarian coalition consistently maintains a narrowly neoliberal or liberal conservative approach to policy it claims as to represent the entire hungarian minority community in slovakia with the objective of strengthening their legal status and ensuring them an equal position in the society
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party also pays attention to the protection of rights of other minorities living in slovakia
lines.name: English

lines.value: laszlo nagy for example mp and one time chairman of the slovak parliament's committee for human rights minorities and the position of women has advocated for a solution to the problems facing the romani
lines.name: English

lines.value: also indicative of the party's approach it supports political and civic equality for romani but also advocates cuts in the social welfare to which romani like other citizens are entitled
lines.name: English

lines.value: the primary party organisations make up the basis of the party
lines.name: English

lines.value: by the end of march 2003 the number of these local organisations was 521 and the number of members was 10983
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party congress is the highest body of the party
lines.name: English

lines.value: between two congresses the highest body of the party is the national council
lines.name: English

lines.value: each elected functionary and body gets elected in form of democratic secret elections
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party leadership of the districts co ordinates the work of local institutions within district
lines.name: English

lines.value: between 1998 and 2007 the party chairman was bela bugar
lines.name: English

lines.value: the chairman of the national council was zsolt komlosy the parliamentary group leader was gyula bardos and executive deputy chairman was miklos duray
lines.name: English

lines.value: pal csaky was the chairman of the minister's club
lines.name: English

lines.value: on 31 march 2007 pal csaky was elected for chairman by the assembly of party thus succeeding the more moderate bela bugar
lines.name: English

lines.value: bela bugar established the party most hid on 30 june 2009 stating that csaky was too nationalist
lines.name: English

lines.value: his new party its name meaning bridge in hungarian and slovak wants to emphasise cooperation between hungarians and slovaks
lines.name: English
