lines.value: non equilibrium thermodynamics is a branch of thermodynamics that deals with physical systems that are not in thermodynamic equilibrium but can be described in terms of variables non-equilibrium state variables that represent an extrapolation of the variables used to specify the system in thermodynamic equilibrium
lines.name: English

lines.value: non equilibrium thermodynamics is concerned with transport processes and with the rates of chemical reactions
lines.name: English

lines.value: it relies on what may be thought of as more or less nearness to thermodynamic equilibrium
lines.name: English

lines.value: non equilibrium thermodynamics is a work in progress not an established edifice
lines.name: English

lines.value: this article will try to sketch some approaches to it and some concepts important for it.almost all systems found in nature are not in thermodynamic equilibrium for they are changing or can be triggered to change over time and are continuously and discontinuously subject to flux of matter and energy to and from other systems and to chemical reactions
lines.name: English

lines.value: some systems and processes are however in a useful sense near enough to thermodynamic equilibrium to allow description with useful accuracy by currently known non equilibrium thermodynamics
lines.name: English

lines.value: nevertheless many natural systems and processes will always remain far beyond the scope of non equilibrium thermodynamic methods
lines.name: English

lines.value: this is because of the very small size of atoms as compared with macroscopic systems
lines.name: English

lines.value: the thermodynamic study of non equilibrium systems requires more general concepts than are dealt with by equilibrium thermodynamics
lines.name: English

lines.value: one fundamental difference between equilibrium thermodynamics and non equilibrium thermodynamics lies in the behaviour of inhomogeneous systems which require for their study knowledge of rates of reaction which are not considered in equilibrium thermodynamics of homogeneous systems
lines.name: English

lines.value: this is discussed below
lines.name: English

lines.value: another fundamental and very important difference is the difficulty or impossibility in general in defining entropy at an instant of time in macroscopic terms for systems not in thermodynamic equilibrium it can be done to useful approximation only in carefully chosen special cases namely those that are throughout in local thermodynamic equilibrium
lines.name: English

lines.value: a profound difference separates equilibrium from non equilibrium thermodynamics
lines.name: English

lines.value: equilibrium thermodynamics ignores the time courses of physical processes
lines.name: English

lines.value: in contrast non equilibrium thermodynamics attempts to describe their time courses in continuous detail
lines.name: English

lines.value: equilibrium thermodynamics restricts its considerations to processes that have initial and final states of thermodynamic equilibrium the time courses of processes are deliberately ignored
lines.name: English

lines.value: consequently equilibrium thermodynamics allows processes that pass through states far from thermodynamic equilibrium that cannot be described even by the variables admitted for non equilibrium thermodynamics such as time rates of change of temperature and pressure
lines.name: English

lines.value: for example in equilibrium thermodynamics a process is allowed to include even a violent explosion that cannot be described by non equilibrium thermodynamics
lines.name: English

lines.value: equilibrium thermodynamics does however for theoretical development use the idealized concept of the quasi static process
lines.name: English

lines.value: a quasi static process is a conceptual timeless and physically impossible smooth mathematical passage along a continuous path of states of thermodynamic equilibrium
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is an exercise in differential geometry rather than a process that could occur in actuality
lines.name: English

lines.value: non equilibrium thermodynamics on the other hand attempting to describe continuous time courses need its state variables to have a very close connection with those of equilibrium thermodynamics
lines.name: English

lines.value: this profoundly restricts the scope of non equilibrium thermodynamics and places heavy demands on its conceptual framework
lines.name: English

lines.value: the suitable relationship that defines non equilibrium thermodynamic state variables is as follows
lines.name: English

lines.value: on occasions when the system happens to be in states that are sufficiently close to thermodynamic equilibrium non equilibrium state variables are such that they can be measured locally with sufficient accuracy by the same techniques as are used to measure thermodynamic state variables or by corresponding time and space derivatives including fluxes of matter and energy
lines.name: English

lines.value: in general non equilibrium thermodynamic systems are spatially and temporally non uniform but their non uniformity still has a sufficient degree of smoothness to support the existence of suitable time and space derivatives of non equilibrium state variables
lines.name: English

lines.value: because of the spatial non uniformity non equilibrium state variables that correspond to extensive thermodynamic state variables have to be defined as spatial densities of the corresponding extensive equilibrium state variables
lines.name: English

lines.value: on occasions when the system is sufficiently close to thermodynamic equilibrium intensive non equilibrium state variables for example temperature and pressure correspond closely with equilibrium state variables
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is necessary that measuring probes be small enough and rapidly enough responding to capture relevant non uniformity
lines.name: English

lines.value: further the non equilibrium state variables are required to be mathematically functionally related to one another in ways that suitably resemble corresponding relations between equilibrium thermodynamic state variables
lines.name: English

lines.value: in reality these requirements are very demanding and it may be difficult or practically or even theoretically impossible to satisfy them
lines.name: English

lines.value: this is part of why non equilibrium thermodynamics is a work in progress
lines.name: English

lines.value: non equilibrium thermodynamics is a work in progress not an established edifice
lines.name: English

lines.value: this article will try to sketch some approaches to it and some concepts important for it.some concepts of particular importance for non equilibrium thermodynamics include time rate of dissipation of energy rayleigh 1873 onsager 1931 also ), time rate of entropy production onsager 1931 thermodynamic fields dissipative structure and non linear dynamical structure
lines.name: English

lines.value: one problem of interest is the thermodynamic study of non equilibrium steady states in which entropy production and some flows are non zero but there is no time variation of physical variables
lines.name: English

lines.value: one initial approach to non equilibrium thermodynamics is sometimes called classical irreversible thermodynamics
lines.name: English

lines.value: there are other approaches to non equilibrium thermodynamics for example extended irreversible thermodynamics and generalized thermodynamics but they are hardly touched on in the present article
lines.name: English

lines.value: according to wildt see also essex ), current versions of non equilibrium thermodynamics ignore radiant heat they can do so because they refer to laboratory quantities of matter under laboratory conditions with temperatures well below those of stars
lines.name: English

lines.value: at laboratory temperatures in laboratory quantities of matter thermal radiation is weak and can be practically nearly ignored
lines.name: English

lines.value: but for example atmospheric physics is concerned with large amounts of matter occupying cubic kilometers that taken as a whole are not within the range of laboratory quantities then thermal radiation cannot be ignored
lines.name: English

lines.value: the terms classical irreversible thermodynamics and local equilibrium thermodynamics are sometimes used to refer to a version of non equilibrium thermodynamics that demands certain simplifying assumptions as follows
lines.name: English

lines.value: the assumptions have the effect of making each very small volume element of the system effectively homogeneous or well mixed or without an effective spatial structure and without kinetic energy of bulk flow or of diffusive flux
lines.name: English

lines.value: even within the thought frame of classical irreversible thermodynamics care is needed in choosing the independent variables for systems
lines.name: English

lines.value: in some writings it is assumed that the intensive variables of equilibrium thermodynamics are sufficient as the independent variables for the task such variables are considered to have no memory and do not show hysteresis in particular local flow intensive variables are not admitted as independent variables local flows are considered as dependent on quasi static local intensive variables
lines.name: English

lines.value: also it is assumed that the local entropy density is the same function of the other local intensive variables as in equilibrium this is called the local thermodynamic equilibrium assumption see also keizer 1987 ).
lines.name: English

lines.value: radiation is ignored because it is transfer of energy between regions which can be remote from one another
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the classical irreversible thermodynamic approach there is allowed very small spatial variation from very small volume element to adjacent very small volume element but it is assumed that the global entropy of the system can be found by simple spatial integration of the local entropy density this means that spatial structure cannot contribute as it properly should to the global entropy assessment for the system
lines.name: English

lines.value: this approach assumes spatial and temporal continuity and even differentiability of locally defined intensive variables such as temperature and internal energy density
lines.name: English

lines.value: all of these are very stringent demands
lines.name: English

lines.value: consequently this approach can deal with only a very limited range of phenomena
lines.name: English

lines.value: this approach is nevertheless valuable because it can deal well with some macroscopically observable phenomena
lines.name: English

lines.value: in other writings local flow variables are considered these might be considered as classical by analogy with the time invariant long term time averages of flows produced by endlessly repeated cyclic processes examples with flows are in the thermoelectric phenomena known as the seebeck and the peltier effects considered by kelvin in the nineteenth century and by onsager in the twentieth
lines.name: English

lines.value: these effects occur at metal junctions which were originally effectively treated as two dimensional surfaces with no spatial volume and no spatial variation
lines.name: English

lines.value: a further extension of local equilibrium thermodynamics is to allow that materials may have memory so that their constitutive equations depend not only on present values but also on past values of local equilibrium variables
lines.name: English

lines.value: thus time comes into the picture more deeply than for time dependent local equilibrium thermodynamics with memoryless materials but fluxes are not independent variables of state
lines.name: English

lines.value: extended irreversible thermodynamics is a branch of non equilibrium thermodynamics that goes outside the restriction to the local equilibrium hypothesis
lines.name: English

lines.value: the space of state variables is enlarged by including the fluxes of mass momentum and energy and eventually higher order fluxes
lines.name: English

lines.value: the formalism is well suited for describing high frequency processes and small length scales materials
lines.name: English

lines.value: there are many examples of stationary non equilibrium systems some very simple like a system confined between two thermostats at different temperatures or the ordinary couette flow a fluid enclosed between two flat walls moving in opposite directions and defining non equilibrium conditions at the walls
lines.name: English

lines.value: laser action is also a non equilibrium process but it depends on departure from local thermodynamic equilibrium and is thus beyond the scope of classical irreversible thermodynamics here a strong temperature difference is maintained between two molecular degrees of freedom with molecular laser vibrational and rotational molecular motion the requirement for two component temperatures in the one small region of space precluding local thermodynamic equilibrium which demands that only one temperature be needed
lines.name: English

lines.value: damping of acoustic perturbations or shock waves are non stationary non equilibrium processes
lines.name: English

lines.value: driven complex fluids turbulent systems and glasses are other examples of non equilibrium systems
lines.name: English

lines.value: the mechanics of macroscopic systems depends on a number of extensive quantities
lines.name: English

lines.value: it should be stressed that all systems are permanently interacting with their surroundings thereby causing unavoidable fluctuations of extensive quantities
lines.name: English

lines.value: equilibrium conditions of thermodynamic systems are related to the maximum property of the entropy
lines.name: English

lines.value: if the only extensive quantity that is allowed to fluctuate is the internal energy all the other ones being kept strictly constant the temperature of the system is measurable and meaningful
lines.name: English

lines.value: the system's properties are then most conveniently described using the thermodynamic potential helmholtz free energy a = u ts a legendre transformation of the energy
lines.name: English

lines.value: if next to fluctuations of the energy the macroscopic dimensions volume of the system are left fluctuating we use the gibbs free energy g = u + pv ts where the system's properties are determined both by the temperature and by the pressure
lines.name: English

lines.value: non equilibrium systems are much more complex and they may undergo fluctuations of more extensive quantities
lines.name: English

lines.value: the boundary conditions impose on them particular intensive variables like temperature gradients or distorted collective motions shear motions vortices etc often called thermodynamic forces
lines.name: English

lines.value: if free energies are very useful in equilibrium thermodynamics it must be stressed that there is no general law defining stationary non equilibrium properties of the energy as is the second law of thermodynamics for the entropy in equilibrium thermodynamics
lines.name: English

lines.value: that is why in such cases a more generalized legendre transformation should be considered
lines.name: English

lines.value: this is the extended massieu potential
lines.name: English

lines.value: by definition the entropy s is a function of the collection of extensive quantities the independent variables are the intensities
lines.name: English

lines.value: intensities are global values valid for the system as a whole
lines.name: English

lines.value: when boundaries impose to the system different local conditions e.g temperature differences there are intensive variables representing the average value and others representing gradients or higher moments
lines.name: English

lines.value: the latter are the thermodynamic forces driving fluxes of extensive properties through the system
lines.name: English

lines.value: it may be shown that the legendre transformation changes the maximum condition of the entropy valid at equilibrium in a minimum condition of the extended massieu function for stationary states no matter whether at equilibrium or not
lines.name: English

lines.value: in thermodynamics one is often interested in a stationary state of a process allowing that the stationary state include the occurrence of unpredictable and experimentally unreproducible fluctuations in the state of the system
lines.name: English

lines.value: the fluctuations are due to the system's internal sub processes and to exchange of matter or energy with the system's surroundings that create the constraints that define the process
lines.name: English

lines.value: if the stationary state of the process is stable then the unreproducible fluctuations involve local transient decreases of entropy
lines.name: English

lines.value: the reproducible response of the system is then to increase the entropy back to its maximum by irreversible processes the fluctuation cannot be reproduced with a significant level of probability
lines.name: English

lines.value: fluctuations about stable stationary states are extremely small except near critical points kondepudi and prigogine 1998 page 323
lines.name: English

lines.value: the stable stationary state has a local maximum of entropy and is locally the most reproducible state of the system
lines.name: English

lines.value: there are theorems about the irreversible dissipation of fluctuations
lines.name: English

lines.value: here local means local with respect to the abstract space of thermodynamic coordinates of state of the system
lines.name: English

lines.value: if the stationary state is unstable then any fluctuation will almost surely trigger the virtually explosive departure of the system from the unstable stationary state
lines.name: English

lines.value: this can be accompanied by increased export of entropy
lines.name: English

lines.value: the scope of present day non equilibrium thermodynamics does not cover all physical processes
lines.name: English

lines.value: a condition for the validity of many studies in non equilibrium thermodynamics of matter is that they deal with what is known as local thermodynamic equilibrium
lines.name: English

lines.value: local thermodynamic equilibrium of matter see also keizer 1987 means that conceptually for study and analysis the system can be spatially and temporally divided into cells or micro phases of small infinitesimal size in which classical thermodynamical equilibrium conditions for matter are fulfilled to good approximation
lines.name: English

lines.value: these conditions are unfulfilled for example in very rarefied gases in which molecular collisions are infrequent and in the boundary layers of a star where radiation is passing energy to space and for interacting fermions at very low temperature where dissipative processes become ineffective
lines.name: English

lines.value: when these cells are defined one admits that matter and energy may pass freely between contiguous cells slowly enough to leave the cells in their respective individual local thermodynamic equilibria with respect to intensive variables
lines.name: English

lines.value: one can think here of two relaxation times separated by order of magnitude
lines.name: English

lines.value: the longer relaxation time is of the order of magnitude of times taken for the macroscopic dynamical structure of the system to change
lines.name: English

lines.value: the shorter is of the order of magnitude of times taken for a single cell to reach local thermodynamic equilibrium
lines.name: English

lines.value: if these two relaxation times are not well separated then the classical non equilibrium thermodynamical concept of local thermodynamic equilibrium loses its meaning and other approaches have to be proposed see for instance extended irreversible thermodynamics
lines.name: English

lines.value: for example in the atmosphere the speed of sound is much greater than the wind speed this favours the idea of local thermodynamic equilibrium of matter for atmospheric heat transfer studies at altitudes below about 60 km where sound propagates but not above 100 km where because of the paucity of intermolecular collisions sound does not propagate
lines.name: English

lines.value: milne 1928 thinking about stars gave a definition of local thermodynamic equilibrium in terms of the thermal radiation of the matter in each small local cell
lines.name: English

lines.value: he defined local thermodynamic equilibrium in a cell by requiring that it macroscopically absorb and spontaneously emit radiation as if it were in radiative equilibrium in a cavity at the temperature of the matter of the cell
lines.name: English

lines.value: then it strictly obeys kirchhoff's law of equality of radiative emissivity and absorptivity with a black body source function
lines.name: English

lines.value: the key to local thermodynamic equilibrium here is that the rate of collisions of ponderable matter particles such as molecules should far exceed the rates of creation and annihilation of photons
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is pointed out by wt grandy jr that entropy though it may be defined for a non equilibrium system is when strictly considered only a macroscopic quantity that refers to the whole system and is not a dynamical variable and in general does not act as a local potential that describes local physical forces
lines.name: English

lines.value: under special circumstances however one can metaphorically think as if the thermal variables behaved like local physical forces
lines.name: English

lines.value: the approximation that constitutes classical irreversible thermodynamics is built on this metaphoric thinking
lines.name: English

lines.value: this point of view shares many points in common with the concept and the use of entropy in continuum thermomechanics which evolved completely independently of statistical mechanics and maximum entropy principles
lines.name: English

lines.value: to describe deviation of the thermodynamic system from equilibrium in addition to constitutive variables is a relaxation time of a corresponding variables
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is convenient to consider the initial value |}} the essential contribution to the thermodynamics of the non equilibrium systems was brought by prigogine when he and his collaborators investigated the systems of chemically reacting substances
lines.name: English

lines.value: the stationary states of such systems exists due to exchange both particles and energy with the environment
lines.name: English

lines.value: in section 8 of the third chapter of his book prigogine has specified three contributions to the variation of entropy of the considered system at the given volume and constant temperature
lines.name: English

lines.value: the middle term in 1 depicts energy dissipation entropy production due to the relaxation of internal variables in equation 1 to comprise of the quantities defining not only degreess of completeness of all chemical reactions occurring in the system but also the structure of the system gradients of temperature difference of concentrations of substances and so on
lines.name: English

lines.value: the fundamental relation of classical equilibrium thermodynamics for classical non equilibrium studies we will consider some new locally defined intensive macroscopic variables
lines.name: English

lines.value: we can under suitable conditions derive these new variables by locally defining the gradients and flux densities of the basic locally defined macroscopic quantities
lines.name: English

lines.value: such locally defined gradients of intensive macroscopic variables are called thermodynamic forces
lines.name: English

lines.value: they drive flux densities perhaps misleadingly often called fluxes which are dual to the forces
lines.name: English

lines.value: these quantities are defined in the article on onsager reciprocal relations
lines.name: English

lines.value: establishing the relation between such forces and flux densities is a problem in statistical mechanics
lines.name: English

lines.value: flux densities may be coupled
lines.name: English

lines.value: the article on onsager reciprocal relations considers the stable near steady thermodynamically non equilibrium regime which has dynamics linear in the forces and flux densities
lines.name: English

lines.value: in stationary conditions such forces and associated flux densities are by definition time invariant as also are the system's locally defined entropy and rate of entropy production
lines.name: English

lines.value: notably according to ilya prigogine and others when an open system is in conditions that allow it to reach a stable stationary thermodynamically non equilibrium state it organizes itself so as to minimize total entropy production defined locally
lines.name: English

lines.value: this is considered further below
lines.name: English

lines.value: one wants to take the analysis to the further stage of describing the behaviour of surface and volume integrals of non stationary local quantities these integrals are macroscopic fluxes and production rates
lines.name: English

lines.value: in general the dynamics of these integrals are not adequately described by linear equations though in special cases they can be so described
lines.name: English

lines.value: following section iii of rayleigh 1873 onsager 1931 i showed that in the regime where both the flows ( the second law of thermodynamics requires that the matrix is symmetric
lines.name: English

lines.value: this fact is called the onsager reciprocal relations
lines.name: English

lines.value: the generalization of the above equations for the rate of creation of entropy was given by pokrovskii
lines.name: English

lines.value: until recently prospects for useful extremal principles in this area have seemed clouded
lines.name: English

lines.value: c nicolis 1999 concludes that one model of atmospheric dynamics has an attractor which is not a regime of maximum or minimum dissipation she says this seems to rule out the existence of a global organizing principle and comments that this is to some extent disappointing she also points to the difficulty of finding a thermodynamically consistent form of entropy production
lines.name: English

lines.value: another top expert offers an extensive discussion of the possibilities for principles of extrema of entropy production and of dissipation of energy chapter 12 of grandy 2008 is very cautious and finds difficulty in defining the rate of internal entropy production in many cases and finds that sometimes for the prediction of the course of a process an extremum of the quantity called the rate of dissipation of energy may be more useful than that of the rate of entropy production this quantity appeared in onsager's 1931 origination of this subject
lines.name: English

lines.value: laboratory virtual instrument engineering workbench labview is a system design platform and development environment for a visual programming language from national instruments
lines.name: English

lines.value: the graphical language is named g not to be confused with g code
lines.name: English

lines.value: originally released for the apple macintosh in 1986 labview is commonly used for data acquisition instrument control and industrial automation on a variety of operating systems oss including microsoft windows various versions of unix linux and macos
lines.name: English

lines.value: the latest versions of labview are labview 2017 sp1 and labview nxg 2.0 released in january 2018
lines.name: English

lines.value: the programming paradigm used in labview sometimes called g is based on data availability
lines.name: English

lines.value: if there is enough data available to a subvi or function that subvi or function will execute
lines.name: English

lines.value: execution flow is determined by the structure of a graphical block diagram the labview source code on which the programmer connects different function nodes by drawing wires
lines.name: English

lines.value: these wires propagate variables and any node can execute as soon as all its input data become available
lines.name: English

lines.value: since this might be the case for multiple nodes simultaneously labview can execute inherently in parallel
lines.name: English

lines.value: multi processing and multi threading hardware is exploited automatically by the built in scheduler which multiplexes multiple os threads over the nodes ready for execution
lines.name: English

lines.value: labview integrates the creation of user interfaces termed front panels into the development cycle
lines.name: English

lines.value: labview programs subroutines are termed virtual instruments vis
lines.name: English

lines.value: each vi has three components a block diagram a front panel and a connector panel
lines.name: English

lines.value: the last is used to represent the vi in the block diagrams of other calling vis
lines.name: English

lines.value: the front panel is built using controls and indicators
lines.name: English

lines.value: controls are inputs they allow a user to supply information to the vi
lines.name: English

lines.value: indicators are outputs they indicate or display the results based on the inputs given to the vi
lines.name: English

lines.value: the back panel which is a block diagram contains the graphical source code
lines.name: English

lines.value: all of the objects placed on the front panel will appear on the back panel as terminals
lines.name: English

lines.value: the back panel also contains structures and functions which perform operations on controls and supply data to indicators
lines.name: English

lines.value: the structures and functions are found on the functions palette and can be placed on the back panel
lines.name: English

lines.value: collectively controls indicators structures and functions are referred to as nodes
lines.name: English

lines.value: nodes are connected to one another using wires e.g two controls and an indicator can be wired to the addition function so that the indicator displays the sum of the two controls
lines.name: English

lines.value: thus a virtual instrument can be run as either a program with the front panel serving as a user interface or when dropped as a node onto the block diagram the front panel defines the inputs and outputs for the node through the connector panel
lines.name: English

lines.value: this implies each vi can be easily tested before being embedded as a subroutine into a larger program
lines.name: English

lines.value: the graphical approach also allows nonprogrammers to build programs by dragging and dropping virtual representations of lab equipment with which they are already familiar
lines.name: English

lines.value: the labview programming environment with the included examples and documentation makes it simple to create small applications
lines.name: English

lines.value: this is a benefit on one side but there is also a certain danger of underestimating the expertise needed for high quality g programming
lines.name: English

lines.value: for complex algorithms or large scale code it is important that a programmer possess an extensive knowledge of the special labview syntax and the topology of its memory management
lines.name: English

lines.value: the most advanced labview development systems offer the ability to build stand alone applications
lines.name: English

lines.value: furthermore it is possible to create distributed applications which communicate by a client server model and are thus easier to implement due to the inherently parallel nature of g
lines.name: English

lines.value: applications in labview are usually designed using well known architectures known as design patterns
lines.name: English

lines.value: the most common design patterns for graphical labview applications are listed in the table below
lines.name: English

lines.value: labview includes extensive support for interfacing to devices instruments camera and other devices
lines.name: English

lines.value: users interface to hardware by either writing direct bus commands usb gpib serial or using high level device specific drivers that provide native labview function nodes for controlling the device
lines.name: English

lines.value: labview includes built in support for ni hardware platforms such as compactdaq and compactrio with a large number of device specific blocks for such hardware the measurement and automation explorer max and virtual instrument software architecture visa toolsets
lines.name: English

lines.value: national instruments makes thousands of device drivers available for download on the ni instrument driver network idnet
lines.name: English

lines.value: labview includes a compiler that produces native code for the cpu platform
lines.name: English

lines.value: this aids performance
lines.name: English

lines.value: the graphical code is translated into executable machine code by a compiler
lines.name: English

lines.value: the labview syntax is strictly enforced during the editing process and compiled into the executable machine code when requested to run or upon saving
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the latter case the executable and the source code are merged into a single file
lines.name: English

lines.value: the executable runs with the help of the labview run time engine which contains some pre compiled code to perform common tasks that are defined by the g language
lines.name: English

lines.value: the run time engine reduces compiling time and provides a consistent interface to various operating systems graphic systems hardware components etc the run time environment makes the code portable across platforms
lines.name: English

lines.value: generally labview code can be slower than equivalent compiled c code although the differences often lie more with program optimization than inherent execution speed
lines.name: English

lines.value: many libraries with a large number of functions for data acquisition signal generation mathematics statistics signal conditioning analysis etc along with numerous for functions such as integration filters and other specialized abilities usually associated with data capture from hardware sensors is enormous
lines.name: English

lines.value: in addition labview includes a text based programming component named mathscript with added functions for signal processing analysis and mathematics
lines.name: English

lines.value: mathscript can be integrated with graphical programming using script nodes and uses a syntax that is compatible generally with matlab
lines.name: English

lines.value: labview is an inherently concurrent language so it is very easy to program multiple tasks that are performed in parallel via multithreading
lines.name: English

lines.value: for example this is done easily by drawing two or more parallel while loops and connecting them to two separate nodes
lines.name: English

lines.value: this is a great benefit for test system automation where it is common practice to run processes like test sequencing data recording and hardware interfacing in parallel
lines.name: English

lines.value: due to the longevity and popularity of the labview language and the ability for users to extend its functions a large ecosystem of third party add ons has developed via contributions from the community
lines.name: English

lines.value: this ecosystem is available on the labview tools network which is a marketplace for both free and paid labview add ons
lines.name: English

lines.value: there is a low cost labview student edition aimed at educational institutions for learning purposes
lines.name: English

lines.value: there is also an active community of labview users who communicate through several electronic mailing lists email groups and internet forums
lines.name: English

lines.value: national instruments provides a low cost labview home bundle edition
lines.name: English

lines.value: labview is a proprietary product of national instruments
lines.name: English

lines.value: unlike common programming languages such as c or fortran labview is not managed or specified by a third party standards committee such as american national standards institute ansi institute of electrical and electronics engineers ieee international organization for standardization iso etc
lines.name: English

lines.value: very small applications still have to start the runtime environment which is a large and slow task
lines.name: English

lines.value: this tends to restrict labview to monolithic applications
lines.name: English

lines.value: examples of this might be tiny programs to grab a single value from some hardware that can be used in a scripting language the overheads of the runtime environment render this approach impractical with labview
lines.name: English

lines.value: g language being non textual software tools such as versioning side by side or diff comparison and version code change tracking cannot be applied in the same manner as for textual programming languages
lines.name: English

lines.value: there are some additional tools to make comparison and merging of code with source code control versioning tools such as subversion cvs and perforce
lines.name: English

lines.value: there is no ability to zoom in to or enlarge a vi which will be hard to see on a large high resolution monitor although this feature is under development
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2005 starting with labview 8.0 major versions are released around the first week of august to coincide with the annual national instruments conference ni week and followed by a bug fix release the following february
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2009 national instruments began naming releases after the year in which they are released
lines.name: English

lines.value: a bug fix is termed a service pack for example the 2009 service pack 1 was released in february 2010
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2017 national instruments moved the annual conference to may and released labview 2017 along side a completely redesigned labview nxg 1.0 built on windows presentation foundation wpf
lines.name: English

lines.value: openg as well as lava code repository lavacr serve as repositories for a wide range of open source labview applications and libraries
lines.name: English

lines.value: sourceforge has labview listed as one of the possible languages in which code can be written
lines.name: English

lines.value: vi package manager has become the standard package manager for labview libraries
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is very similar in purpose to ruby's rubygems and perl's cpan although it provides a graphical user interface similar to the synaptic package manager
lines.name: English

lines.value: vi package manager provides access to a repository of the openg and other libraries for labview
lines.name: English

lines.value: tools exist to convert mathml into g code
lines.name: English

lines.value: national instruments also offers a product named measurement studio which offers many of the test measurement and control abilities of labview as a set of classes for use with microsoft visual studio
lines.name: English

lines.value: this allows developers to harness some of labview's strengths within the text based net framework
lines.name: English

lines.value: national instruments also offers labwindows/cvi as an alternative for ansi c programmers
lines.name: English

lines.value: when applications need sequencing users often use labview with teststand test management software also from national instruments
lines.name: English

lines.value: the ch interpreter is a c/c++ interpreter that can be embedded in labview for scripting
lines.name: English

lines.value: the tril centre ireland biomobius platform and dsp robotics flowstone dsp also use a form of graphical programming similar to labview but are limited to the biomedical and robotics industries respectively
lines.name: English

lines.value: labview has a direct node with modefrontier a multidisciplinary and multi objective optimization and design environment written to allow coupling to almost any computer aided engineering tool
lines.name: English

lines.value: both can be part of the same process workflow description and can be virtually driven by the optimization technologies available in modefrontier

lines.value: felix salten 6 september 1869 - 8 october 1945 was an austrian author and critic in vienna
lines.name: English

lines.value: his most famous work is bambi a life in the woods 1923
lines.name: English

lines.value: salten was born siegmund salzmann in pest hungary the grandson of an orthodox rabbi
lines.name: English

lines.value: when he was four weeks old his family relocated to vienna austria
lines.name: English

lines.value: many jews were immigrating into the city during the late 19th century because vienna had granted full citizenship to jews in 1867
lines.name: English

lines.value: when his father became bankrupt the sixteen year old salten quit school and began working for an insurance agency
lines.name: English

lines.value: he also began submitting poems and book reviews to journals
lines.name: English

lines.value: he became part of the young vienna movement jung wien and soon received work as a full time art and theater critic for vienna's press wiener allgemeine zeitung zeit
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1900 he published his first collection of short stories
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1901 he initiated vienna's first short lived literary cabaret jung wiener theater zum lieben augustin
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was soon publishing on an average one book a year of plays short stories novels travel books and essay collections
lines.name: English

lines.value: he also wrote for nearly all the major newspapers of vienna
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1906 salten went to ullstein as an editor in chief of the bz am mittag and the berliner morgenpost but relocated to vienna some months later
lines.name: English

lines.value: he wrote also film scripts and librettos for operettas
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1927 he became president of the austrian pen club as successor of arthur schnitzler
lines.name: English

lines.value: his most famous work is bambi 1923
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was translated into english in 1928 and became a book of the month club success
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1933 he sold the film rights to the american director sidney franklin for only $1000 and franklin later transferred the rights to the walt disney studios which formed the basis of the 1942 animated classic bambi
lines.name: English

lines.value: life in austria became perilous for a prominent jew during the 1930s
lines.name: English

lines.value: adolf hitler had salten's books banned in 1936
lines.name: English

lines.value: two years later after germany's annexation of austria salten moved to zurich switzerland with his wife and spent there his final years
lines.name: English

lines.value: felix salten died on 8 october 1945 at the age of 76
lines.name: English

lines.value: he is buried at israelitischer friedhof unterer friesenberg
lines.name: English

lines.value: salten married actress ottilie metzl 1868-1942 in 1902 and had two children paul 1903-1937 and anna katharina 1904-1977
lines.name: English

lines.value: he composed another book based on the character bambi titled bambi's children the story of a forest family 1939
lines.name: English

lines.value: his stories perri and the hound of florence inspired the disney films perri 1957 and the shaggy dog 1959
lines.name: English

lines.value: salten is now considered to be the anonymous author of a celebrated erotic novel josephine mutzenbacher the life story of a viennese whore as told by herself 1906
lines.name: English

lines.value: in mathematics a compact topological group is a topological group whose topology is compact
lines.name: English

lines.value: compact groups are a natural generalization of finite groups with the discrete topology and have properties that carry over in significant fashion
lines.name: English

lines.value: compact groups have a well understood theory in relation to group actions and representation theory
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the following we will assume all groups are hausdorff spaces
lines.name: English

lines.value: lie groups form a very nice class of topological groups and the compact lie groups have a particularly well developed theory
lines.name: English

lines.value: basic examples of compact lie groups include
lines.name: English

lines.value: given any compact lie group g one can take its identity component g 0 which is connected
lines.name: English

lines.value: the quotient group g/g 0 is the group of components &pi 0 g which must be finite since g is compact
lines.name: English

lines.value: we therefore have a finite extension meanwhile for connected compact lie groups we have the following result :theorem: every connected compact lie group is the quotient by a finite central subgroup of a product of a simply connected compact lie group and a torus
lines.name: English

lines.value: thus the classification of connected compact lie groups can in principle be reduced to knowledge of the simply connected compact lie groups together with information about their centers
lines.name: English

lines.value: finally every compact connected simply connected lie group k is a product of compact connected simply connected simple lie groups k i each of which is isomorphic to exactly one of the following *the compact symplectic group or one of the five exceptional groups g 2 f 4 , e 6 , e 7 , and e 8
lines.name: English

lines.value: the restrictions on n are to avoid special isomorphisms among the various families for small values of n for each of these groups the center is known explicitly
lines.name: English

lines.value: the classification is through the associated root system for a fixed maximal torus which in turn are classified by their dynkin diagrams
lines.name: English

lines.value: the classification of compact simply connected lie groups is the same as the classification of complex semisimple lie algebras
lines.name: English

lines.value: indeed if k is a simply connected compact lie group then the complexification of the lie algebra of k is semisimple
lines.name: English

lines.value: conversely every complex semisimple lie algebra has a compact real form isomorphic to the lie algebra of a compact simply connected lie group
lines.name: English

lines.value: a key idea in the study of a connected compact lie group k is the concept of a maximal torus that is a subgroup t of k that is isomorphic to several copies of has been chosen one can define a root system and a weyl group similar to what one has for semisimple lie algebras
lines.name: English

lines.value: these structures then play an essential role both in the classification of connected compact groups described above and in the representation theory of a fixed such group described below
lines.name: English

lines.value: the root systems associated to the simple compact groups appearing in the classification of simply connected compact groups are as follows *the special unitary groups
lines.name: English

lines.value: amongst groups that are not lie groups and so do not carry the structure of a manifold examples are the additive group z p of p adic integers and constructions from it
lines.name: English

lines.value: in fact any profinite group is a compact group
lines.name: English

lines.value: this means that galois groups are compact groups a basic fact for the theory of algebraic extensions in the case of infinite degree
lines.name: English

lines.value: pontryagin duality provides a large supply of examples of compact commutative groups
lines.name: English

lines.value: these are in duality with abelian discrete groups
lines.name: English

lines.value: compact groups all carry a haar measure which will be invariant by both left and right translation the modulus function must be a continuous homomorphism to positive reals ℝ + x and so 1
lines.name: English

lines.value: in other words these groups are unimodular
lines.name: English

lines.value: haar measure is easily normalized to be a probability measure analogous to dθ/2&pi on the circle
lines.name: English

lines.value: such a haar measure is in many cases easy to compute for example for orthogonal groups it was known to adolf hurwitz and in the lie group cases can always be given by an invariant differential form
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the profinite case there are many subgroups of finite index and haar measure of a coset will be the reciprocal of the index
lines.name: English

lines.value: therefore integrals are often computable quite directly a fact applied constantly in number theory
lines.name: English

lines.value: the representation theory of compact groups not necessarily lie groups and not necessarily connected was founded by the peter weyl theorem
lines.name: English

lines.value: hermann weyl went on to give the detailed character theory of the compact connected lie groups based on maximal torus theory
lines.name: English

lines.value: the resulting weyl character formula was one of the influential results of twentieth century mathematics
lines.name: English

lines.value: the combination of the peter weyl theorem and the weyl character formula led weyl to a complete classification of the representations of a connected compact lie group this theory is described in the next section
lines.name: English

lines.value: a combination of weyl's work and cartan's theorem gives a survey of the whole representation theory of compact groups g
lines.name: English

lines.value: that is by the peter weyl theorem the irreducible unitary representations &rho of g are into a unitary group of finite dimension and the image will be a closed subgroup of the unitary group by compactness
lines.name: English

lines.value: cartan's theorem states that im(&rho must itself be a lie subgroup in the unitary group
lines.name: English

lines.value: if g is not itself a lie group there must be a kernel to &rho
lines.name: English

lines.value: further one can form an inverse system for the kernel of &rho smaller and smaller of finite dimensional unitary representations which identifies g as an inverse limit of compact lie groups
lines.name: English

lines.value: here the fact that in the limit a faithful representation of g is found is another consequence of the peter weyl theorem the unknown part of the representation theory of compact groups is thereby roughly speaking thrown back onto the complex representations of finite groups
lines.name: English

lines.value: this theory is rather rich in detail but is qualitatively well understood
lines.name: English

lines.value: certain simple examples of the representation theory of compact lie groups can be worked out by hand such as the representations of the rotation group so(3 the special unitary group su(2 and the special unitary group su(3
lines.name: English

lines.value: we focus here on the general theory
lines.name: English

lines.value: see also the parallel theory of [[lie_algebra_representation#classifying_finite-dimensional_representations_of_lie_algebras|representations of a semisimple lie algebra]]
lines.name: English

lines.value: throughout this section we fix a connected compact lie group k and a maximal torus t in k
lines.name: English

lines.value: since t is commutative schur's lemma tells us that each irreducible representation is not injective not every such linear functional satisfying this condition is called an analytically integral element
lines.name: English

lines.value: this integrality condition is related to but not identical to the notion of [[weight_(representation_theory)#weights_in_the_representation_theory_of_semisimple_lie_algebras|integral element]] in the setting of semisimple lie algebras
lines.name: English

lines.value: suppose for example t is just the group of
lines.name: English

lines.value: we now let to t we call is very similar to the construction for complex semisimple lie algebras
lines.name: English

lines.value: specifically the weights are the nonzero weights for the adjoint action of t on the complexified lie algebra of k the root system r has all the usual properties of a root system except that the elements of r may not span with non negative coefficients
lines.name: English

lines.value: the irreducible finite dimensional representations of k are then classified by a theorem of the highest weight which is closely related to the analogous theorem classifying [[lie_algebra_representation#classifying_finite-dimensional_representations_of_lie_algebras|representations of a semisimple lie algebra]]
lines.name: English

lines.value: the result says that
lines.name: English

lines.value: if is determined by its restriction to t the study of characters is an important part of the representation theory of compact groups
lines.name: English

lines.value: one crucial result which is a corollary of the peter weyl theorem is that the characters form an orthonormal basis for the set of square integrable class functions in k a second key result is the weyl character formula which gives an explicit formula for the character or rather the restriction of the character to t in terms of the highest weight of the representation
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the closely related representation theory of semisimple lie algebras the weyl character formula is an additional result established after the representations have been classified
lines.name: English

lines.value: in weyl's analysis of the compact group case however the weyl character formula is actually a crucial part of the classification itself
lines.name: English

lines.value: specifically in weyl's analysis of the representations of k the hardest part of the theorem showing that every dominant analytically integral element is actually the highest weight of some representationis proved in totally different way from the usual lie algebra construction using verma modules
lines.name: English

lines.value: in weyl's approach the construction is based on the peter weyl theorem and an analytic proof of the weyl character formula
lines.name: English

lines.value: ultimately the irreducible representations of k are realized inside the space of continuous functions on k
lines.name: English

lines.value: we now consider the case of the compact group su(2
lines.name: English

lines.value: the representations are often considered from the lie algebra point of view but we here look at them from the group point of view
lines.name: English

lines.value: we take the maximal torus to be the set of matrices of the form : is encoded in its character

lines.value: now the weyl character formula says in this case that the character is given by if we use the formula for the sum of a finite geometric series on the above expression and simplify we obtain the earlier expression from this last expression and the standard formula for the character in terms of the weights of the representation we can read off that the weights of the representation are :
lines.name: English

lines.value: thus we recover much of the information about the representations that is usually obtained from the lie algebra computation
lines.name: English

lines.value: the topic of recovering a compact group from its representation theory is the subject of the tannaka krein duality now often recast in term of tannakian category theory
lines.name: English

lines.value: the influence of the compact group theory on non compact groups was formulated by weyl in his unitarian trick
lines.name: English

lines.value: inside a general semisimple lie group there is a maximal compact subgroup and the representation theory of such groups developed largely by harish chandra uses intensively the restriction of a representation to such a subgroup and also the model of weyl's character theory

lines.value: la crosse encephalitis is an encephalitis caused by an arbovirus the la crosse virus which has a mosquito vector ochlerotatus triseriatus synonym aedes triseriatus
lines.name: English

lines.value: la crosse encephalitis virus lacv is one of a group of mosquito transmitted viruses that can cause encephalitis or inflammation of the brain
lines.name: English

lines.value: lac encephalitis is rare in the united states about 80 100 lacv disease cases are reported each year although it is believed to be underreported due to minimal symptoms experienced by many of those affected
lines.name: English

lines.value: it takes 5 to 15 days after the bite of an infected mosquito to develop symptoms of lacv disease
lines.name: English

lines.value: symptoms include nausea headache vomiting in milder cases and seizures coma paralysis and permanent brain damage in severe cases
lines.name: English

lines.value: lac encephalitis initially presents as a nonspecific summertime illness with fever headache nausea vomiting and lethargy
lines.name: English

lines.value: severe disease occurs most commonly in children under the age of 16 and is characterized by seizures coma paralysis and a variety of neurological sequelae after recovery
lines.name: English

lines.value: death from lac encephalitis occurs in less than 1% of clinical cases
lines.name: English

lines.value: in many clinical settings pediatric cases presenting with cns involvement are routinely screened for herpes or enteroviral causes
lines.name: English

lines.value: since there is no specific treatment for lac encephalitis physicians often do not request the tests required to specifically identify lac virus and the cases are reported as aseptic meningitis or viral encephalitis of unknown cause
lines.name: English

lines.value: as with many infections the very young the very old and the immunocompromised are at a higher risk of developing severe symptoms
lines.name: English

lines.value: the la crosse encephalitis virus is a type of arbovirus called a bunyavirus
lines.name: English

lines.value: the bunyavirales are mainly arboviruses
lines.name: English

lines.value: most cases of lac encephalitis occur in children under 16 years of age
lines.name: English

lines.value: lac virus is a zoonotic pathogen cycled between the daytime biting treehole mosquito aedes triseriatus and vertebrate amplifier hosts chipmunks tree squirrels in deciduous forest habitats
lines.name: English

lines.value: the virus is maintained over the winter by transovarial transmission in mosquito eggs
lines.name: English

lines.value: if the female mosquito is infected she may lay eggs that carry the virus and the adults coming from those eggs may be able to transmit the virus to chipmunks and to humans
lines.name: English

lines.value: anyone bitten by a mosquito in an area where the virus is circulating can get infected with lacv
lines.name: English

lines.value: the risk is highest for people who live work or recreate in woodland habitats because of greater exposure to potentially infected mosquitoes
lines.name: English

lines.value: people reduce the chance of getting infected with lacv by preventing mosquito bites
lines.name: English

lines.value: there is no vaccine or preventive drug
lines.name: English

lines.value: prevention measures against lacv include reducing exposure to mosquito bites
lines.name: English

lines.value: use repellent such as deet and picaridin while spending time outside especially at during the daytime from dawn until dusk
lines.name: English

lines.value: aedes triseriatus mosquitoes that transmit lacv are most active during the day
lines.name: English

lines.value: wear long sleeves pants and socks while outdoors
lines.name: English

lines.value: ensure all screens are in good condition to prevent mosquitoes from entering your home
lines.name: English

lines.value: aedes triseriatus prefer treeholes to lay eggs in
lines.name: English

lines.value: also remove stagnant water such as old tires birdbaths flower pots and barrels
lines.name: English

lines.value: no specific therapy is available at present for la crosse encephalitis and management is limited to alleviating the symptoms and balancing fluids and electrolyte levels
lines.name: English

lines.value: intravenous ribavirin is effective against la crosse encephalitis virus in the laboratory and several studies in patients with severe brain biopsy confirmed la crosse encephalitis are ongoing
lines.name: English

lines.value: in a trial with 15 children being infected with la crosse viral encephalitis were treated at certain phases with ribavirin rbv
lines.name: English

lines.value: rbv appeared to be safe at moderate doses
lines.name: English

lines.value: at escalated doses of rbv adverse events occurred and then the trial was discontinued
lines.name: English

lines.value: nonetheless this was the largest study of antiviral treatment for la crosse encephalitis
lines.name: English

lines.value: la crosse encephalitis was discovered in 1965 after the virus was isolated from stored brain and spinal tissue of a child who died of an unknown infection in la crosse wisconsin in 1960
lines.name: English

lines.value: it occurs in the appalachian and midwestern regions of the united states
lines.name: English

lines.value: recently there has been an increase of cases in the south east of the united states
lines.name: English

lines.value: an explanation to this may be that the mosquito aedes albopictus is also an efficient vector of la crosse virus
lines.name: English

lines.value: aedes albopictus is a species that has entered the us and spread across the se of the us and replaced aedes aegypti in most areas which is not an efficient vector of lac
lines.name: English

lines.value: historically most cases of lac encephalitis occur in the upper midwestern states minnesota wisconsin iowa illinois indiana and ohio
lines.name: English

lines.value: recently more cases are being reported from states in the mid atlantic west virginia virginia and north carolina and southeastern alabama and mississippi regions of the country
lines.name: English

lines.value: it has long been suspected that lac encephalitis has a broader distribution and a higher incidence in the eastern united states but is underreported because the causal agent is often not specifically identified
lines.name: English

lines.value: lac encephalitis cases occur primarily from late spring through early fall but in subtropical areas where the mosquito is found e.g the gulf states rare cases can occur in winter
lines.name: English

lines.value: according to the cdc between 2004 and 2013 there were 787 total cases of la crosse encephalitis and 11 deaths in the us looking at the distribution of cases across the united states by state between 2004 and 2013 the most cases of la crosse encephalitis was in north carolina
lines.name: English

lines.value: north carolina had 184 total cases followed by ohio with 178 total cases
lines.name: English

lines.value: similar diseases that are spread by mosquitoes include western and eastern equine encephalitis japanese encephalitis saint louis encephalitis and west nile virus
lines.name: English

lines.value: the ambrotype from - "immortal and - "impression or amphitype also known as a collodion positive in the uk is a positive photograph on glass made by a variant of the wet plate collodion process
lines.name: English

lines.value: like a print on paper it is viewed by reflected light
lines.name: English

lines.value: like the daguerreotype which it replaced and like the prints produced by a polaroid camera each is a unique original that could only be duplicated by using a camera to copy it.the ambrotype was introduced in the 1850s
lines.name: English

lines.value: during the 1860s it was superseded by the tintype a similar photograph on thin black lacquered iron hard to distinguish from an ambrotype if under glass
lines.name: English

lines.value: one side of a clean glass plate was coated with a thin layer of iodized collodion then dipped in a silver nitrate solution
lines.name: English

lines.value: the plate was exposed in the camera while still wet
lines.name: English

lines.value: exposure times varied from five to sixty seconds or more depending on the brightness of the lighting and the speed of the camera lens
lines.name: English

lines.value: the plate was then developed and fixed
lines.name: English

lines.value: the resulting negative when viewed by reflected light against a black background appears to be a positive image the clear areas look black and the exposed opaque areas appear relatively light
lines.name: English

lines.value: this effect was integrated by backing the plate with black velvet by taking the picture on a plate made of dark reddishcolored glass the result was called a ruby ambrotype or by coating one side of the plate with black varnish
lines.name: English

lines.value: either the emulsion side or the bare side could be coated if the bare side was blackened the thickness of the glass added a sense of depth to the image
lines.name: English

lines.value: in either case another plate of glass was put over the fragile emulsion side to protect it and the whole was mounted in a metal frame and kept in a protective case
lines.name: English

lines.value: in some instances the protective glass was cemented directly to the emulsion generally with a balsam resin
lines.name: English

lines.value: this protected the image well but tended to darken it
lines.name: English

lines.value: ambrotypes were sometimes hand tinted untinted ambrotypes are monochrome gray or tan in their lightest areas
lines.name: English

lines.value: the ambrotype was based on the wet plate collodion process invented by frederick scott archer
lines.name: English

lines.value: ambrotypes were deliberately underexposed negatives made by that process and optimized for viewing as positives instead
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the us ambrotypes first came into use in the early 1850s
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1854 james ambrose cutting of boston took out several patents relating to the process
lines.name: English

lines.value: he may be responsible for coining the term ambrotype
lines.name: English

lines.value: ambrotypes were much less expensive to produce than daguerreotypes the medium that predominated when they were introduced and did not have the bright mirror like metallic surface that could make daguerreotypes troublesome to view and which some people disliked
lines.name: English

lines.value: an ambrotype however appeared dull and drab when compared with the brilliance of a well made and properly viewed daguerreotype
lines.name: English

lines.value: by the late 1850s the ambrotype was overtaking the daguerreotype in popularity
lines.name: English

lines.value: by the mid 1860s the ambrotype itself was being replaced by the tintype a similar image on a sturdy black lacquered thin iron sheet as well as by photographic albumen paper prints made from glass plate collodion negatives
lines.name: English

lines.name: English

lines.value: monster garage is an american television series aired on the discovery channel and hosted by jesse james
lines.name: English

lines.value: each episode was an hour in length and was conceived and produced along with james by thom beers
lines.name: English

lines.value: the show premiered on june 23 2002 and concluded on june 12 2006
lines.name: English

lines.value: a team of five people with mechanical fabricating or modifying expertise was assembled to modify a vehicle into a monster machine on the show this generally meant making one vehicle that could transform into another such as a pt cruiser which could change into a wood chipper or a school bus which transformed into a pontoon boat
lines.name: English

lines.value: occasionally vehicles were modified so as to hide non vehicular functions such as a police car which doubled as a donut shop built by a team of cops or a toyota tundra which was modified so as to allow it to discharge a motorcycle at high speeds
lines.name: English

lines.value: build teams who successfully completed their assignment were rewarded with expensive tool kits
lines.name: English

lines.value: according to the show the rules were as follows starting with season 4 the winning team also donated a toolkit to a high school of their choice
lines.name: English

lines.value: host jesse james claims to be the great great grandson of a cousin of the legendary wild west outlaw jesse james
lines.name: English

lines.value: jesse g james has both mechanical and metal fabricating expertise and is the founder owner and head bike builder for his custom chopper shop west coast choppers
lines.name: English

lines.value: jesse said he liked monsters that went fast and did something
lines.name: English

lines.value: he preferred hard working build crew members
lines.name: English

lines.value: his favorite monster vehicles were the ford ambulance wheel stander and the chevrolet blazer pikes peak hill climber
lines.name: English

lines.value: one of jesse's ambitions throughout the run of the show was to build a monster that could top 200 mph which he was unsuccessful at achieving
lines.name: English

lines.value: announcing for this show was done by brett the big schwag wagner who later became the host of the speed channel show pass time
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was very memorable for frequently shouting out you gotta be kidding me during the tests of the monster vehicles and signing off most episodes saying the next monster garage challenge is just around the bend
lines.name: English

lines.value: with rules as strict as they were in the monster garage there was a 1 in 10 monster build failure rate
lines.name: English

lines.value: when a team failed to complete a vehicle in time it was destroyed by host jesse james
lines.name: English

lines.value: a uk version of the show was aired in 2004 by channel 4
lines.name: English

lines.value: the team always included a hell's angel known as cookie
lines.name: English

lines.value: there was a budget of £3000
lines.name: English

lines.value: only 3 days were used for the build
lines.name: English

lines.value: cars often looked radically different from the production models
lines.name: English

lines.value: challenges included converting a toyota into a lawnmower a lotus into a hovercraft and an ice cream van into a riot truck
lines.name: English

lines.value: in one episode the team sold the internal fittings of the car that was to be transformed a rolls royce to raise funds to convert it into a muck spreader
lines.name: English

lines.value: the uk series lasted only 8 episodes
lines.name: English

lines.value: mbi published monster garage videos detailing the ford mustang lawn mower ford explorer garbage truck limousine firetruck and the volkswagen beetle swamp boat
lines.name: English

lines.value: the 2008 barrett jackson scottsdale auction included 42 of the surviving project vehicles
lines.name: English

lines.value: invictus games ltd developed a pc video game based on the series
lines.name: English

lines.value: an xbox remake was made by impulse games in 2004
lines.name: English

lines.value: both games were published by activision value
lines.name: English

lines.value: inside monster garage a book about the tv series was published by meridith books
lines.name: English

lines.value: mbi publishing company has published monster garage instruction books under the motorbooks brand including the big box of monster garage box set
lines.name: English

lines.value: gevelsberg is a town in the district of ennepe ruhr kreis in north rhine westphalia germany
lines.name: English

lines.value: the town lies in the valley of the river ennepe in the suder uplands which is part of the rhenish massif
lines.name: English

lines.value: gevelsberg lies about halfway between wuppertal and hagen and is part of the industrial ruhr region
lines.name: English

lines.value: the lowest elevation is the ennepe river at vogelsang () and highest is the hagebollinger kopf ().
lines.name: English

lines.value: its east to west length is and the north to south length is
lines.name: English

lines.value: the city has a history of nearly 780 years
lines.name: English

lines.value: the archbishop of cologne engelbert ii of berg was killed on november 7 1225 by his cousin frederick of isenberg in gievilberch
lines.name: English

lines.value: the population grew strongly in the 19th century when many small industries related to iron processing were developed
lines.name: English

lines.value: gevelsberg received its coat of arms a brick gable on a green hill and a cogwheel indicating its industry by decree of the prussian department of the interior in 1903
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the mid 1950s a city wall was added to the coat of arms
lines.name: English

lines.value: gevelsberg is connected to the national road network by the a1 autobahn and the b 7 and b 234 roads
lines.name: English

lines.value: the municipality is served by several regional train lines of the verkehrsverbund rhein ruhr
lines.name: English

lines.value: there are four stations on the local line from hagen to wuppertal gevelsberg-knapp gevelsberg hauptbahnhof gevelsberg kipp and gevelsberg west served by the s 8 trains of the rhein ruhr s bahn
lines.name: English

lines.value: three hourly regional express services the wupper express re 4 between dortmund and aachen via dusseldorf the rhein munsterland express re 7 between krefeld and munster via cologne and hamm and the maas wupper express re 13 between venlo netherlands and hamm via monchengladbach stop at ennepetal gevelsberg station
lines.name: English

lines.value: aberchirder gaelic obar chiardair known locally as foggieloan or foggie is a village in aberdeenshire scotland situated on the a97 road six miles west of turriff
lines.name: English

lines.value: the village of aberchirder was founded in 1764 by alexander gordon the 5th laird of auchintoul
lines.name: English

lines.value: until 1823 its official name was in fact foggieloan after a small farm community on the site of which it was built
lines.name: English

lines.value: there is some uncertainty as to how the name foggieloan originated
lines.name: English

lines.value: there are various theories the most likely is that there is a stretch of moorland north of where the farm town existed and now north of the village which was named foggieloan moss from two gaelic words foidh peat moss and lon meadow so foggieloan means peaty or boggy meadow
lines.name: English

lines.value: kinnairdy castle now belonging to the innes family is 2 miles to the south west where the river deveron joins the auchintoul burn
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1823 the village was renamed aberchirder after the 13th century thanes of aberkerdour of kinnairdy castle
lines.name: English

lines.value: as a planned community the village was built on a grid pattern around a central square and had a mix of single storey thatched stone built houses fronting onto the streets to prevent people having their middens on show with long gardens intended to provide the inhabitants with a seasonal supply of food
lines.name: English

lines.value: alexander gordon envisaged a thriving industrial village and built a small linen factory in back street now north street which produced fine linen table cloths and wincey using flax from auchintoul moss
lines.name: English

lines.value: by the late 19th century wealthier inhabitants had built some grander houses and there was a selection of religious establishments throughout the town catering to various denominations in addition to the church of scotland and free church buildings
lines.name: English

lines.value: * aa touring guide to scotland 1978
lines.name: English

lines.name: English

lines.value: a number of second level domains exist although there is no information available about their exact purposes or restrictions
