lines.value: donald mckenzie 16 june 1783 - 20 january 1851 was a scottish canadian explorer fur trader and governor of the red river colony from 1821 to 1834
lines.name: English

lines.value: born in scotland mckenzie emigrated to canada about 1800
lines.name: English

lines.value: he and two or three of his brothers became involved in the fur trade and were engaged with the north west company
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1810 he left the employ of the north west company to become a partner in the pacific fur company pfc financed solely by john jacob astor
lines.name: English

lines.value: mckenzie traveled west from st louis missouri with an expedition of fellow pfc employees to the pacific northwest
lines.name: English

lines.value: the group experienced hard times in southern idaho and divided
lines.name: English

lines.value: mckenzie's fraction consisted of twelve total and struck north eventually found the salmon river and clearwater river
lines.name: English

lines.value: they proceeded down the lower snake river and columbia river by canoe and were the first of the overland astorians to reach fort astoria on january 18 1812
lines.name: English

lines.value: mckenzie spent two years exploring and trading for the pacific fur company in the willamette valley along the columbia river in eastern washington and northern and central idaho
lines.name: English

lines.value: when the pfc sold its assets and stations to the north west company in 1813 mckenzie was appointed to carry all important papers back east which he did in 1814
lines.name: English

lines.value: after a short time mckenzie became reacquainted with the north west company and returned to the columbia region in 1816
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1818 he and alexander ross built fort nez perces near the confluence of the columbia river and walla walla river
lines.name: English

lines.value: mckenzie and his trappers made the first extensive exploration of what is now southern idaho starting in 1818 with annual expeditions through 1821
lines.name: English

lines.value: his trapping ventures covered most of modern southern idaho and parts of eastern oregon northern utah and western wyoming
lines.name: English

lines.value: many of the names for rivers in this region can be traced to this period
lines.name: English

lines.value: with the merger of the north west company and hudson's bay company in 1821 donald mckenzie was appointed governor of the red river colony
lines.name: English

lines.value: he left the pacific northwest and moved to fort garry for a decade serving as governor of the area including most of present day manitoba saskatchewan and alberta canada
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1834 mckenzie retired and moved to mayville new york where he lived for the next two decades
lines.name: English

lines.value: among the distinguished visitors mckenzie entertained and advised were daniel webster and william h seward who later served as secretary of state
lines.name: English

lines.value: he gave advice on where the international boundary should be established for oregon and also may have planted the seeds that led to the purchase of alaska from russia
lines.name: English

lines.value: the mckenzie pass and the mckenzie river in oregon are named for him
lines.name: English

lines.value: * manitoba historical society donald mckenzie
lines.name: English

lines.value: in december 1832 two naval vessels were sent by the united kingdom to reassert british sovereignty over the falkland islands (), after the united provinces of the river plate part of which later became argentina ignored british diplomatic protests over the appointment of luis vernet as governor of the falkland islands and a dispute over fishing rights
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1765 captain john byron explored saunders island on west falkland
lines.name: English

lines.value: he named the harbour port egmont and claimed this and other islands for britain on the grounds of prior discovery
lines.name: English

lines.value: the next year captain john macbride established a british settlement at port egmont
lines.name: English

lines.value: the british presence in the west continued until interrupted by spain who had acquired the french colony during the falkland crisis from 10 july 1770 to 22 january 1771
lines.name: English

lines.value: economic pressures led britain to unilaterally withdraw from many overseas settlements in 1774
lines.name: English

lines.value: on 20 may 1776 the british forces under the command of lieutenant clayton formally took their leave of port egmont leaving a plaque asserting britain's continuing sovereignty over the islands
lines.name: English

lines.value: the falkland islands remained an important outpost for whalers and sealers who used the islands to shelter from the worst of the south atlantic weather
lines.name: English

lines.value: by merit of their location the falkland islands have often been the last refuge for ships damaged at sea
lines.name: English

lines.value: most numerous among those using the islands were british and american sealers where typically between 40 and 50 ships were engaged in hunting fur seals
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1823 after its war of independence against spain the united provinces granted land on east falkland to luis vernet who first travelled to the islands the following year
lines.name: English

lines.value: that first expedition failed almost as soon as it landed and a second attempt in 1826 sanctioned by the british but delayed until winter by a brazilian blockade also failed after arrival in the islands
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1828 the united provinces government granted vernet all of east falkland including all its resources with exemption from taxation if a colony could be established within three years
lines.name: English

lines.value: he took settlers some of them british and before leaving once again sought permission first from the british consulate in buenos aires
lines.name: English

lines.value: after receiving consent vernet agreed to provide regular reports to the british consul and expressed the desire for british protection for his settlement should they decide to reestablish their presence in the islands
lines.name: English

lines.value: on vernet's return to the falklands puerto soledad was renamed puerto luis
lines.name: English

lines.value: the united provinces proclaimed luis vernet as governor of the islands in 1829
lines.name: English

lines.value: british diplomatic protests at the appointment and declarations of sovereignty were ignored
lines.name: English

lines.value: the united provinces also granted vernet exclusive rights to seal hunting in the islands
lines.name: English

lines.value: this too was disputed by the british and us consulates at buenos aires but once again the diplomatic protests were ignored
lines.name: English

lines.value: vernet continued to provide regular reports to the british consul throughout this period
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1831 luis vernet seized three us vessels breakwater superior and harriet hunting seals in falklands waters confiscating their catch and arresting their crews
lines.name: English

lines.value: vernet returned to the mainland bringing senior officers of the us vessels to stand trial for violating restrictions on seal hunting
lines.name: English

lines.value: the us consul protested violently against the seizure of us ships and the uss lexington sailed to the falklands
lines.name: English

lines.value: the log of the lexington reports only the destruction of arms and a powder store though in his claim against the us government for compensation rejected by the us government of president grover cleveland in 1885 vernet stated that the settlement was destroyed
lines.name: English

lines.value: the islands were declared free from all government the seven senior members of the settlement were arrested for piracy and taken to montevideo where they were released without charge on the orders of commodore rogers
lines.name: English

lines.value: this latter incident finally convinced the british foreign office to reassert its sovereignty claim over the islands
lines.name: English

lines.value: throughout much of 1832 the united provinces did not have a government representative in the islands
lines.name: English

lines.value: the buenos aires government commissioned major esteban mestivier as the new governor of the islands to set up a penal colony but when he arrived at the settlement on 15 november 1832 his soldiers mutinied and killed him
lines.name: English

lines.value: the mutiny was put down by major jose maria pinedo commander of the united provinces schooner sarandi
lines.name: English

lines.value: order was restored just before the british arrived
lines.name: English

lines.value: under the command of captain john james onslow the brig sloop hms clio previously stationed at rio de janeiro reached port egmont on 20 december 1832
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was later joined by hms tyne
lines.name: English

lines.value: their first actions were to repair the fort at port egmont and affix a notice of possession
lines.name: English

lines.value: onslow arrived at puerto louis on 2 january 1833
lines.name: English

lines.value: pinedo sent an officer to the british ship where he was presented with the following written request to replace the argentine flag with the british one and leave the location
lines.name: English

lines.value: i have to direct you that i have received directions from his excellency and commander in chief of his britannic majesty's ships and vessels of war south america station in the name of his britannic majesty to exercise the rights of sovereignty over these islands it is my intention to hoist to morrow the national flag of great britain on shore when i request you will be pleased to haul down your flag on shore and withdraw your force taking all stores belonging to your government pinedo entertained plans for resisting but finally desisted because of his obvious numerical inferiority and the want of enough nationals among his crew approximately 80% of his forces were british mercenaries who refused to fight their countrymen
lines.name: English

lines.value: the british forces disembarked on 3 january and switched the flags delivering the argentine one to pinedo who left on 5 january
lines.name: English

lines.value: recognising vernet's settlement had british permission onslow set about ensuring the continuation of that settlement for the replenishment of passing ships
lines.name: English

lines.value: the gauchos had not been paid since vernet's departure and were anxious to return to the mainland
lines.name: English

lines.value: onslow persuaded them to stay by paying them in silver for provisions and promising that in the absence of vernet's authority they could earn their living from the feral cattle on the islands
lines.name: English

lines.value: the british vessels did not stay long and departed two days later leaving william dixon vernet's storekeeper in charge of the settlement
lines.name: English

lines.value: dixon was provided with a flagpole and instructed to fly the british flag whenever a vessel was in harbour
lines.name: English

lines.value: argentina claims that the population of the islands was expelled in 1833 however both british and argentine sources from the time including the log of the ara sarandi suggest that the colonists were encouraged to remain under vernet's deputy matthew brisbane
lines.name: English

lines.value: hms beagle arrived on 15 march 1833
lines.name: English

lines.value: vernet dispatched his deputy matthew brisbane to the islands to take charge of his settlement march 1833
lines.name: English

lines.value: meeting with captain fitzroy of the beagle he was encouraged to continue with vernet's enterprise provided there was no attempt to further the ambitions of the united provinces
lines.name: English

lines.value: like onslow before him fitzroy was forced to use his powers of persuasion to encourage the gauchos to continue working in vernet's establishment arriving in the falklands fitzroy expected to find the thriving settlement reported by another british officer
lines.name: English

lines.value: instead he found the settlement in a derelict state which brisbane blamed upon the lexington's raid
lines.name: English

lines.value: fitzroy questioned several members of the settlement who corroborated brisbane's account on departing from the islands fitzroy expressed his concern for the settlement with its lack of regular authority in a virtually lawless group of islands
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 26 august 1833 eight members of the settlement led by antonio rivero ran amok killing the five senior members
lines.name: English

lines.value: in part this stemmed from the reimposition of paying the wages of the gauchos in paper vouchers issued by vernet
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1834 on his second visit charles darwin commented that lieutenant henry smith was installed as the first british resident in january 1834 he immediately set about establishing british authority arresting the murderers
lines.name: English

lines.value: the united kingdom has held the territory ever since but for a two months period after the 1982 invasion during the falklands war
lines.name: English

lines.value: in buenos aires vernet was effectively bankrupt and attempts to obtain compensation from the us government for losses from the lexington raid proved fruitless
lines.name: English

lines.value: the situation in buenos aires was chaotic and diplomatic relations with the us remained ruptured till 1839
lines.name: English

lines.value: he made several approaches to the british government asking for support to reestablish his business at port louis receiving support from woodbine parish british charge d'affaires in buenos aires from 1825 to 1832 as the best qualified person to develop the islands
lines.name: English

lines.value: vernet wrote to lieutenant smith offering advice which was gratefully received and acted upon
lines.name: English

lines.value: smith repeatedly urged vernet to return to port louis but as vernet became increasingly involved in the territorial dispute with the government in buenos aires all communications ceased and no more accounts were sent
lines.name: English

lines.value: an approach to lieutenant lowcay to retrieve his property was rebuffed but later he was requested to remove his property as the government could not be responsible for it
lines.name: English

lines.value: jonathan hoefler born august 22 1970 ) is an american typeface designer
lines.name: English

lines.value: hoefler pronounced heffler founded the hoefler type foundry in 1989 a type foundry in new york
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1999 hoefler began working with type designer tobias frere jones and from 2005 2014 the company operated under the name hoefler & frere jones until their public split
lines.name: English

lines.value: hoefler has designed original typefaces for rolling stone harper's bazaar the new york times magazine sports illustrated and esquire and several institutional clients including the solomon r guggenheim museum and alternative band they might be giants
lines.name: English

lines.value: perhaps his best known work is the hoefler text family of typefaces designed for apple computer and now appearing as part of the macintosh operating system
lines.name: English

lines.value: he also designed the current wordmark of the church of jesus christ of latter day saints
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1995 hoefler was named one of the forty most influential designers in america by id magazine and in 2002 the association typographique internationale atypi presented him with its most prestigious award the prix charles peignot for outstanding contributions to type design
lines.name: English

lines.value: hoefler and frere jones have been profiled in the new york times time magazine and esquire magazine and appearances on national public radio and cbs sunday morning
lines.name: English

lines.value: hoefler's work is part of the cooper hewitt national design museum's permanent collection
lines.name: English

lines.value: jonathan hoefler's types include
lines.name: English

lines.value: in computer networking a reliable protocol provides notifications to the sender as to the delivery of transmitted data as opposed to an unreliable protocol which does not provide assurance of the delivery of data to the intended recipient(s
lines.name: English

lines.value: reliability is a synonym for assurance which is the term used by the itu and atm forum in the context of the atm service specific coordination function for example for transparent assured delivery with aal5
lines.name: English

lines.value: reliable protocols typically incur more overhead than unreliable protocols and as a result function more slowly and with less scalability
lines.name: English

lines.value: this often is not an issue for unicast protocols but it may become a problem for reliable multicast protocols
lines.name: English

lines.value: tcp the main protocol used on the internet is a reliable unicast protocol
lines.name: English

lines.value: udp often used in computer games or in other situations where speed is an issue and the loss of a little data is not as important because of the transitory nature of the data is an unreliable protocol
lines.name: English

lines.value: often a reliable unicast protocol is also connection oriented
lines.name: English

lines.value: for example tcp is connection oriented with the virtual circuit id consisting of source and destination ip addresses and port numbers
lines.name: English

lines.value: some unreliable protocols are connection oriented as well
lines.name: English

lines.value: these include atm and frame relay
lines.name: English

lines.value: there are also reliable connectionless protocols such as ax.25 when it passes data in i frames
lines.name: English

lines.value: but this combination occurs rarely reliableconnectionless is uncommon in commercial and academic networks
lines.name: English

lines.value: after the npl network pioneered packet switching the arpanet provided a reliable packet delivery procedure to its connected hosts via its 1822 interface
lines.name: English

lines.value: a host computer simply arranged the data in the correct packet format inserted the address of the destination host computer and sent the message across the interface to its connected interface message processor
lines.name: English

lines.value: once the message was delivered to the destination host an acknowledgement was delivered to the sending host
lines.name: English

lines.value: if the network could not deliver the message it would send an error message back to the sending host
lines.name: English

lines.value: meanwhile the developers of cyclades and of alohanet demonstrated that it was possible to build an effective computer network without providing reliable packet transmission
lines.name: English

lines.value: this lesson was later embraced by the designers of ethernet
lines.name: English

lines.value: if a network does not guarantee packet delivery then it becomes the host's responsibility to provide reliability by detecting and retransmitting lost packets
lines.name: English

lines.value: subsequent experience on the arpanet indicated that the network itself could not reliably detect all packet delivery failures and this pushed responsibility for error detection onto the sending host in any case
lines.name: English

lines.value: this led to the development of the end to end principle which is one of the internet's fundamental design assumptions
lines.name: English

lines.value: a reliable service is one that notifies the user if delivery fails while an unreliable one does not notify the user if delivery fails
lines.name: English

lines.value: for example ip provides an unreliable service
lines.name: English

lines.value: together tcp and ip provide a reliable service whereas udp and ip provide an unreliable one
lines.name: English

lines.value: all these protocols use packets but udp packets are generally called datagrams
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the context of distributed protocols reliability properties specify the guarantees that the protocol provides with respect to the delivery of messages to the intended recipient(s
lines.name: English

lines.value: an example of a reliability property for a unicast protocol is at least once i.e at least one copy of the message is guaranteed to be delivered to the recipient
lines.name: English

lines.value: reliability properties for multicast protocols can be expressed on a per recipient basis simple reliability properties or they may relate the fact of delivery or the order of delivery among the different recipients strong reliability properties
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the context of multicast protocols strong reliability properties express the guarantees that the protocol provides with respect to the delivery of messages to different recipients
lines.name: English

lines.value: an example of a strong reliability property is last copy recall meaning that as long as at least a single copy of a message remains available at any of the recipients every other recipient that does not fail eventually also receives a copy
lines.name: English

lines.value: strong reliability properties such as this one typically require that messages are retransmitted or forwarded among the recipients
lines.name: English

lines.value: an example of a reliability property stronger than last copy recall is atomicity
lines.name: English

lines.value: the property states that if at least a single copy of a message has been delivered to a recipient all other recipients will eventually receive a copy of the message
lines.name: English

lines.value: in other words each message is always delivered to either all or none of the recipients
lines.name: English

lines.value: one of the most complex strong reliability properties is virtual synchrony
lines.name: English

lines.value: strong reliability properties are offered by group communication systems gcs such as is is appia framework spread jgroups or quicksilver scalable multicast
lines.name: English

lines.value: the quicksilver properties framework is a flexible platform that allows strong reliability properties to be expressed in a purely declarative manner using a simple rule based language and automatically translated into a hierarchical protocol
lines.name: English

lines.value: there is however a problem with the definition of reliability as delivery or notification of failure in real time computing
lines.name: English

lines.value: in such systems failure to deliver the real time data will adversely affect the performance of the systems and some systems e.g safety critical safety involved and some secure mission critical systems must be proved to perform at some specified minimum level
lines.name: English

lines.value: this in turn requires that there be a specified minimum reliability for the delivery of the critical data
lines.name: English

lines.value: hence it is only the delivery that matters and notifying the sender does not negate or ameliorate this failure of the real time system's transport layer to deliver
lines.name: English

lines.value: in hard and firm real time systems the data has to be delivered within a deadline i.e data that is delivered late is valueless
lines.name: English

lines.value: in hard real time systems all data must be delivered within its deadline or it is considered a system failure
lines.name: English

lines.value: in firm real time systems late data is still valueless but the system can tolerate some amount of late or missing data
lines.name: English

lines.value: there are a number of protocols that are capable of meeting real time requirements for reliable delivery and timeliness at least for firm real time systems due to the inevitable and unavoidable losses from e.g the physical layer bit error rates mil std 1553b and stanag 3910 are well known examples of such timely and reliable protocols for avionic data buses
lines.name: English

lines.value: mil 1553 uses a 1 mbit s shared media for the transmission of data and the control of these transmissions and is widely used in federated military avionics systems in which each system has its own computers performing its own functions ).
lines.name: English

lines.value: it uses a bus controller bc to command the connected remote terminals rts to receive or transmit this data
lines.name: English

lines.value: the bc can therefore ensure that there will be no congestion and transfers are always timely
lines.name: English

lines.value: the mil 1553 protocol also allows for automatic retries that can still ensure timely delivery and increase the reliability above that of the physical layer
lines.name: English

lines.value: stanag 3910 also known as efabus in its use on the eurofighter typhoon is in effect a version of mil 1553 augmented with a 20 mbit s shared media bus for data transfers retaining the 1 mbit s shared media bus for control purposes
lines.name: English

lines.value: the asynchronous transfer mode atm the avionics full duplex switched ethernet afdx and time triggered ethernet ttethernet are examples of packet switched networks protocols where the timeliness and reliability of data transfers can be assured by the network
lines.name: English

lines.value: afdx and ttethernet are also based on ieee 802.3 ethernet though not entirely compatible with itatm uses connection oriented virtual channels vcs which have fully deterministic paths through the network and usage and network parameter control upc/npc which are implemented within the network to limit the traffic on each vc separately
lines.name: English

lines.value: this allows the usage of the shared resources switch buffers in the network to be calculated from the parameters of the traffic to be carried in advance i.e at system design time
lines.name: English

lines.value: that they are implemented by the network means that these calculations remain valid even when other users of the network behave in unexpected ways i.e transmit more data than they are expected to
lines.name: English

lines.value: the calculated usages can then be compared with the capacities of these resources to show that given the constraints on the routes and the bandwidths of these connections the resource used for these transfers will never be over subscribed
lines.name: English

lines.value: these transfers will therefore never be affected by congestion and there will be no losses due to this effect
lines.name: English

lines.value: then from the predicted maximum usages of the switch buffers the maximum delay through the network can also be predicted
lines.name: English

lines.value: however for the reliability and timeliness to be proved and for the proofs to be tolerant of faults in and malicious actions by the equipment connected to the network the calculations of these resource usages cannot be based on any parameters that are not actively enforced by the network i.e they cannot be based on what the sources of the traffic are expected to do or on statistical analyses of the traffic characteristics see network calculus
lines.name: English

lines.value: afdx uses frequency domain traffic policing or bandwidth allocation that allows the traffic on each virtual link vl to be limited so that the requirements for shared resources can be predicted and congestion prevented so it can be proved not to affect the critical data
lines.name: English

lines.value: however the techniques for predicting the resource requirements and proving that congestion is prevented are not part of the afdx standard
lines.name: English

lines.value: ttethernet provides the lowest possible latency in transferring data across such a network by using time domain control methods - each time triggered transfer is scheduled at a specific time so that contention for shared resources is entirely controlled and thus the possibility of congestion is eliminated
lines.name: English

lines.value: the switches in the network enforce this timing to provide tolerance of faults in and malicious actions on the part of the other connected equipments
lines.name: English

lines.value: however synchronized local clocks are the fundamental prerequisite for time triggered communication
lines.name: English

lines.value: this is because the sources of critical data will have to have the same view of time as the switch in order that they can transmit at the correct time and the switch will see this as correct
lines.name: English

lines.value: this also requires that the sequence with which a critical transfer is scheduled has to be predictable to both source and switch
lines.name: English

lines.value: this in turn will limit the transmission schedule to a highly deterministic one e.g the cyclic executive
lines.name: English

lines.value: however low latency in transferring data over the bus or network does not necessarily translate into low transport delays between the application processes that source and sink this data
lines.name: English

lines.value: this is especially true where the transfers over the bus or network are cyclically scheduled as is commonly the case with mil std 1553b and stanag 3910 and necessarily so with afdx and ttethernet but the application processes are e.g pre emptively scheduled or only plesiosynchronous with this schedule
lines.name: English

lines.value: in which case the maximum delay and jitter will be twice the update rate for the cyclic transfer transfers wait up to the update interval between release and transmission and again wait up to the update interval between delivery and use
lines.name: English

lines.value: with both afdx and ttethernet there are additional functions required of the interfaces to the network for the transmission of critical data etc that make it difficult to use standard ethernet interfaces e.g afdx's bandwidth allocation gap control and ttethernet's requirement for very close synchronization of the sources of time triggered data
lines.name: English

lines.value: other methods for control of the traffic in the network that would allow the use of such standard ieee 802.3 network interfaces is a subject of current research
lines.name: English

lines.value: baldwin larus baldwinson october 26 1856 &ndash october 5 1936 was a politician in manitoba canada
lines.name: English

lines.value: he served in the legislative assembly of manitoba from 1899 to 1907 and from 1910 to 1913 as a member of the conservative party
lines.name: English

lines.value: baldwinson was born in akureyri iceland and attended public school in that country
lines.name: English

lines.value: he came to canada in 1873 and worked in the newspaper industry
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was editor of the icelandic weekly heimskringla and served as president secretary and manager of the heimskringla news and publishing co ltd he was a member of the lutheran church
lines.name: English

lines.value: he first ran for the manitoba legislature in the 1892 provincial election and lost to liberal frederick colcleugh by seventy eight votes in the st andrews constituency
lines.name: English

lines.value: he ran again in the 1896 election and lost to liberal sigtryggur jonasson by seventy nine votes
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was elected to the legislature on his third attempt defeating jonasson by eight votes in the 1899 election for the deferred gimli constituency
lines.name: English

lines.value: the conservatives won the election and baldwinson served in the legislature as a backbench supporter of the administrations led by hugh john macdonald and rodmond roblin
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was reelected by acclamation in the 1903 election
lines.name: English

lines.value: baldwinson lost to jonasson by 156 votes in the 1907 election
lines.name: English

lines.value: jonasson did not seek reelection in the 1910 campaign and baldwin returned to the legislature after defeating a new liberal candidate by 450 votes
lines.name: English

lines.value: he resigned his seat in 1913 on being appointed as deputy provincial secretary
lines.name: English

lines.value: assistant commissioner of police of the metropolis usually just assistant commissioner ac is the third highest rank in london's metropolitan police ranking below deputy commissioner and above deputy assistant commissioner.there are usually four officers in the rank
lines.name: English

lines.value: however currently there are five due to the secondment of assistant commissioner rob beckley to operation resolve the criminal investigation into the hillsborough disaster
lines.name: English

lines.value: there have also at times been five in the past
lines.name: English

lines.value: from 1 september 2016 the salary is £198823 + £2373 allowance
lines.name: English

lines.value: this does not include use of private car and pension contributions
lines.name: English

lines.value: this makes them the equal fifth highest paid police officers in the united kingdom behind the commissioner the deputy commissioner the chief constable of police scotland and the chief constable of the police service of northern ireland and alongside the chief constables of greater manchester and the west midlands
lines.name: English

lines.value: the rank of assistant commissioner was introduced by the police act 1856 which abolished the two joint commissioners and established a single commissioner sir richard mayne assisted by two assistant commissioners
lines.name: English

lines.value: the assistant commissioner administrative was in charge of administration and discipline
lines.name: English

lines.value: the assistant commissioner executive was in charge of executive business supplies and buildings
lines.name: English

lines.value: the first two men to fill these posts were lieutenant colonel douglas labalmondiere and captain william c harris respectively
lines.name: English

lines.value: like the commissioner the assistant commissioners were sworn in as justices of the peace although they could not try criminal cases
lines.name: English

lines.value: this continued until 1973
lines.name: English

lines.value: like the commissioner the assistant commissioners were mainly appointed from outside the police until well into the 20th century although career police officers could and sometimes did rise to the rank
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1878 howard vincent was appointed director of criminal intelligence a post that had equal rank to the assistant commissioners but not the title
lines.name: English

lines.value: on his resignation in 1884 his post was replaced by a third assistant commissioner the assistant commissioner crime
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1909 commissioner sir edward henry realising that the assistant commissioners workload was becoming too great appointed a fourth assistant commissioner who took over some of the duties of the assistant commissioner executive
lines.name: English

lines.value: the four became known as assistant commissioners a b c and l heading departments with the same letter designations
lines.name: English

lines.value: assistant commissioner a effectively acted as deputy commissioner until 1931 when a separate deputy commissioner was appointed
lines.name: English

lines.value: from 1922 until 1931 assistant commissioner a was generally known as the deputy commissioner
lines.name: English

lines.value: after world war i assistant commissioner b became responsible solely for traffic and lost property with his other former duties divided between assistant commissioners a and l
lines.name: English

lines.value: assistant commissioner l was responsible for l legal department until its reorganisation in 1931
lines.name: English

lines.value: after 1931 he was renamed assistant commissioner d and became responsible for policy and planning
lines.name: English

lines.value: by the end of world war ii assistant commissioner a operations and administration was responsible for all uniformed police including specialist units except traffic police which were under assistant commissioner b traffic
lines.name: English

lines.value: assistant commissioner c crime headed the criminal investigation department cid and assistant commissioner d personnel and training was responsible for recruitment training welfare communications and police dogs
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1970 commissioner sir john waldron designated assistant commissioner d as the senior assistant commissioner
lines.name: English

lines.value: as policing became more technical assistant commissioner b also became responsible for technical support
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1985 commissioner sir kenneth newman finally abolished the system of lettered departments
lines.name: English

lines.value: he redesignated the four assistant commissioners as in 1995 commissioner sir paul condon introduced the widest ranging reorganisation when he increased the number of assistant commissioners to six
lines.name: English

lines.value: the previous eight areas each commanded by a deputy assistant commissioner dac were reduced to five each commanded by an assistant commissioner designated ac 1 to 5
lines.name: English

lines.value: each assistant commissioner also had force wide responsibility for a portfolio such as crime or traffic setting force policy and managing related headquarters branches
lines.name: English

lines.value: acso remained outside the area system and continued to manage the specialist operations units
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2000 the system changed again with policing restructured around the boroughs and the areas being abolished
lines.name: English

lines.value: the six assistant commissioners were reduced to four again
lines.name: English

lines.value: with the creation of the specialist crime directorate under its own assistant commissioner in 2002 there were five assistant commissioners although this was once again reduced to four in 2008
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2011 the number was briefly increased to five again then reduced to four once more
lines.name: English

lines.value: the posts have held varying designations since 2000 with the acso being the only post to have remained since the initial reorganisation in 1985
lines.name: English

lines.value: the assistant commissioners are considered to hold equal rank to the chief constables of other british police forces and wear the same rank insignia a crown over crossed tipstaves in a wreath
lines.name: English

lines.value: these positions existed concurrently
lines.name: English

lines.value: these were not all concurrently existing positions
lines.name: English

lines.value: *peter winship 1992–1995
lines.name: English

lines.value: *anthony speed 1995–1999
lines.name: English

lines.name: English

lines.name: English

lines.name: English

lines.value: *john yates 2006–2007
lines.name: English

lines.value: *chris allison 2011–2013

lines.value: rolled oats are traditionally oat groats that have been dehusked and steamed before being rolled into flat flakes under heavy rollers and stabilized by being lightly toasted
lines.name: English

lines.value: rolled oats that are sold as porridge oats usually have had the tough bran removed
lines.name: English

lines.value: they have often but not always been lightly baked or pressure cooked or processed in some fashion
lines.name: English

lines.value: thick rolled oats are large whole flakes and thin rolled oats are smaller fragmented flakes
lines.name: English

lines.value: oat flakes that are simply rolled whole oats without further processing can be cooked into a porridge and eaten as old fashioned oats but more highly fragmented and processed rolled oats absorb water much more easily and therefore cook faster into a porridge so they are sometimes called quick or instant oats
lines.name: English

lines.value: rolled oats are most often the main ingredient in granola and muesli
lines.name: English

lines.value: rolled oats can be further processed into coarse powder which when cooked becomes a thick broth
lines.name: English

lines.value: finer oatmeal powder is often used as baby food
lines.name: English

lines.value: the oat like other cereals has a hard inedible outer husk that must be removed before the grain can be eaten
lines.name: English

lines.value: after the outer husk or chaff has been removed from the still bran covered oat grains the remainder is called oat groats
lines.name: English

lines.value: since the bran layer though nutritious makes the grains tough to chew and contains an enzyme that can cause the oats to go rancid raw oat groats are often further steam treated to soften them for a quicker cooking time modern quick oats and to denature the enzymes for a longer shelf life
lines.name: English

lines.value: steel cut or pinhead oats are oat groats that have been chopped into smaller pieces before any steaming and thus retain bits of the bran layer
lines.name: English

lines.value: rolled oats can be eaten without further heating or cooking the oats are soaked for 1 6 hours in water based liquid such as water or fruit juice
lines.name: English

lines.value: the soak duration depends on shape size and pre processing technique saving the time and the energy spent on heating preserving its taste and saving its nutritional values destroyed during cooking
lines.name: English

lines.value: traditionally oat groats are a whole grain that can be used as a breakfast cereal just like the various forms of oatmeal rolled oats and pinhead oats can be cooked to make porridge
lines.name: English

lines.value: rolled oats are used in granola muesli oatcakes and flapjacks
lines.name: English

lines.value: whole oats are an excellent source of thiamine iron and dietary fiber
lines.name: English

lines.value: whole oats are also the only source of antioxidant compounds known as avenanthramides these are believed to have properties which help to protect the circulatory system from arteriosclerosis
lines.name: English

lines.value: oat products also contain beta glucan
lines.name: English

lines.value: bluffmaster is a 2005 indian hindi romance comedy film directed by rohan sippy and produced by ramesh sippy
lines.name: English

lines.value: the film stars abhishek bachchan priyanka chopra and riteish deshmukh in the lead roles along with boman irani and nana patekar in supporting roles
lines.name: English

lines.value: the storyline resembles the argentinian film nine queens
lines.name: English

lines.value: bluffmaster released on 16 december 2005 and received positive response from critics
lines.name: English

lines.value: the film became a moderate box office success earning a semi hit verdict as well as being the 17th highest grossing bollywood film of the year 2005
lines.name: English

lines.value: sanjay dutt was the original choice for the role of roy kapoor and aishwarya rai for the role of simi
lines.name: English

lines.value: roy kapoor abhishek bachchan is a conman who cons everybody even his girlfriend simi priyanka chopra
lines.name: English

lines.value: on the day of their engagement however roy's true face is exposed and he loses simi
lines.name: English

lines.value: as if that were not enough roy finds out that he has a tumor and is going to die in less than three months
lines.name: English

lines.value: an amateur conman named dittu ritesh deshmukh enters his life
lines.name: English

lines.value: he learns from dittu that a man named chandrakant parekh aka chandru nana patekar had duped dittu's father and countless other of their life savings
lines.name: English

lines.value: chandru is a whimsical irate and ruthless man who will not hesitate in resorting to violence even on the slightest pretext
lines.name: English

lines.value: before dying roy decides to do one good deed for dittu which is conning chandru off all his stolen money & wealth
lines.name: English

lines.value: however whilst planning the biggest con of his life the stages of his tumor begin to start
lines.name: English

lines.value: roy is now between devil and the deep sea
lines.name: English

lines.value: can the greatest conman con death itself
lines.name: English

lines.value: the movie has borrowed most of its story from an american film criminal 2004 which itself is based upon the argentine film nine queens
lines.name: English

lines.value: the soundtrack was released on 20 november 2005
lines.name: English

lines.value: the background score was done by sameeruddin
lines.name: English

lines.value: according to the indian trade website box office india with around 1400000 units sold this film's soundtrack album was the year's tenth highest selling
lines.name: English

lines.value: bluffmaster received mixed to positive response from critics
lines.name: English

lines.value: taran adarsh from bollywood hungama rated the film 1.5/5 and added that the film was disappointing
lines.name: English

lines.value: at the box office the film had an below average opening due to the poor word of mouth however managed to pick up and recover throughout its theatrical run
lines.name: English

lines.value: the film turned out to be a moderate success at the box office earning the verdict average by boxofficeindia.com
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is serviced by wasaya airways with regular scheduled flights to sioux lookout airport fort severn airport and bearskin lake airport

lines.value: in law damages are an award typically of money to be paid to a person as compensation for loss or injury
lines.name: English

lines.value: the rules for damages can and frequently do vary based on the type of claim which is presented e.g breach of contract versus a tort claim and the jurisdiction
lines.name: English

lines.value: at common law damages are categorized into compensatory or actual damages and punitive damages
lines.name: English

lines.value: compensatory damages are further categorized into special damages which are economic losses such as loss of earnings property damage and medical expenses and general damages which are noneconomic damages such as pain and suffering and emotional distress
lines.name: English

lines.value: among the saxons a price called weregild was placed on every human being and every piece of property in the salic code
lines.name: English

lines.value: if property was stolen or someone was injured or killed the guilty person would have to pay weregild as restitution to the victim's family or to the owner of the property
lines.name: English

lines.value: recovery of damages is subject to the legal principle that damages must be proximately caused by the wrongful conduct of the defendant
lines.name: English

lines.value: this is known as the principle of proximate cause
lines.name: English

lines.value: this principle governs the recovery of all compensatory damages whether the underlying claim is based on contract tort or both
lines.name: English

lines.value: damages are likely to be limited to those reasonably foreseeable by the defendant
lines.name: English

lines.value: if a defendant could not reasonably have foreseen that someone might be hurt by their actions there may be no liability
lines.name: English

lines.value: this rule does not usually apply to intentional torts for example tort of deceit and also has stunted applicability to the quantum in negligence where the maxim intended consequences are never too remote applies'never is inaccurate here but resorts to unforeseeable direct and natural consequences of an act
lines.name: English

lines.value: it may be useful for the lawyers the plaintiff and or the defendant to employ forensic accountants or someone trained in the relevant field of economics to give evidence on the value of the loss
lines.name: English

lines.value: in this case they may be called upon to give opinion evidence as an expert witness
lines.name: English

lines.value: compensatory damages are paid to compensate the claimant for loss injury or harm suffered as a result of see requirement of causation another's breach of duty
lines.name: English

lines.value: e.g in a negligence claim under tort law
lines.name: English

lines.value: expectation damages are used in contract law
lines.name: English

lines.value: liability for payment of an award of damages is established when the claimant proves on the balance of probabilities that a defendant's wrongful act caused a tangible harm loss or injury to the plaintiff
lines.name: English

lines.value: once that threshold is met the plaintiff is entitled to some amount of recovery for that loss or injury
lines.name: English

lines.value: no recovery is not an option
lines.name: English

lines.value: the court must then assess the amount of compensation attributable to the harmful acts of the defendant
lines.name: English

lines.value: special damages compensate the claimant for the quantifiable monetary losses suffered by the plaintiff
lines.name: English

lines.value: for example extra costs repair or replacement of damaged property lost earnings both historically and in the future loss of irreplaceable items additional domestic costs and so on
lines.name: English

lines.value: they are seen in both personal and commercial actions
lines.name: English

lines.value: special damages can include direct losses such as amounts the claimant had to spend to try to mitigate damages and consequential or economic losses resulting from lost profits in a business
lines.name: English

lines.value: special damages basically include compensatory damages for the injury or harm to the plaintiff that result from the tort committed by the defendant
lines.name: English

lines.value: damages in tort are awarded generally to place the claimant in the position in which he would have been had the tort not taken place
lines.name: English

lines.value: damages for breach of contract are generally awarded to place the claimant in the position in which he would have been had the contract not been breached
lines.name: English

lines.value: this can often result in a different measure of damages
lines.name: English

lines.value: in cases where it is possible to frame a claim in either contract or tort it is necessary to be aware of what gives the best outcome
lines.name: English

lines.value: if the transaction was a good bargain contract generally gives a better result for the claimant
lines.name: English

lines.value: as an example neal agrees to sell mary an antique rolex for £100
lines.name: English

lines.value: in fact the watch is a fake and worth only £50
lines.name: English

lines.value: if it had been a genuine antique rolex it would have been worth £500
lines.name: English

lines.value: neal is in breach of contract and could be sued
lines.name: English

lines.value: in contract mary is entitled to an item worth £500 but she has only one worth £50
lines.name: English

lines.value: her damages are £450
lines.name: English

lines.value: neal also induced mary to enter into the contract through a misrepresentation a tort
lines.name: English

lines.value: if mary sues in tort she is entitled to damages that put herself back to the same financial position place she would have been in had the misrepresentation not been made
lines.name: English

lines.value: she would clearly not have entered into the contract knowing the watch was fake and is entitled to her £100 back
lines.name: English

lines.value: thus her damages in tort are £100
lines.name: English

lines.value: however she would have to return the watch or else her damages would be £50 if the transaction were a bad bargain tort gives a better result for the claimant
lines.name: English

lines.value: if in the above example mary had overpaid paying £750 for the watch her damages in contract would still be £450 giving him the item he contracted to buy however in tort damages are £700
lines.name: English

lines.value: this is because damages in tort put her in the position she would have been in had the tort not taken place and are calculated as her money back £750 less the value of what she actually got £50
lines.name: English

lines.value: special damages are sometimes divided into incidental damages and consequential damages
lines.name: English

lines.value: incidental losses include the costs needed to remedy problems and put things right
lines.name: English

lines.value: the largest element is likely to be the reinstatement of property damage
lines.name: English

lines.value: take for example a factory which was burnt down by the negligence of a contractor
lines.name: English

lines.value: the claimant would be entitled to the direct costs required to rebuild the factory and replace the damaged machinery
lines.name: English

lines.value: the claimant may also be entitled to any consequential losses
lines.name: English

lines.value: these may include the lost profits that the claimant could have been expected to make in the period whilst the factory was closed and rebuilt
lines.name: English

lines.value: on a breach of contract by a defendant a court generally awards the sum that would restore the injured party to the economic position they expected from performance of the promise or promises known as an expectation measure or benefit of the bargain measure of damages
lines.name: English

lines.value: this rule however has attracted increasing scrutiny from australian courts and legal commentators
lines.name: English

lines.value: when it is either not possible or not desirable to award the victim in that way a court may award money damages designed to restore the injured party to the economic position s he occupied at the time the contract was entered known as the reliance measure or designed to prevent the breaching party from being unjustly enriched restitution see below
lines.name: English

lines.value: parties may contract for liquidated damages to be paid upon a breach of the contract by one of the parties
lines.name: English

lines.value: under common law a liquidated damages clause will not be enforced if the purpose of the term is solely to punish a breach in this case it is termed penal damages
lines.name: English

lines.value: the clause will be enforceable if it involves a genuine attempt to quantify a loss in advance and is a good faith estimate of economic loss
lines.name: English

lines.value: courts have ruled as excessive and invalidated damages which the parties contracted as liquidated but which the court nonetheless found to be penal
lines.name: English

lines.value: to determine whether a clause is a liquidated damages clause or a penalty clause it is necessary to consider i whether the clause is extravagant out of all proportion exorbitant or unconscionable ii whether there is a single sum stipulated for a number of different breaches or individual sums for each breach iii whether a genuine pre estimate of damage is ascertainable
lines.name: English

lines.value: damages in tort are generally awarded to place the claimant in the position that would have been taken had the tort not taken place
lines.name: English

lines.value: damages in tort are quantified under two headings general damages and special damages
lines.name: English

lines.value: in personal injury claims damages for compensation are quantified by reference to the severity of the injuries sustained see below general damages for more details
lines.name: English

lines.value: in non personal injury claims for instance a claim for professional negligence against solicitors the measure of damages will be assessed by the loss suffered by the client due to the negligent act or omission by the solicitor giving rise to the loss
lines.name: English

lines.value: the loss must be reasonably foreseeable and not too remote
lines.name: English

lines.value: financial losses are usually simple to quantify but in complex cases which involve loss of pension entitlements and future loss projections the instructing solicitor will usually employ a specialist expert actuary or accountant to assist with the quantification of the loss
lines.name: English

lines.value: general damages compensate the claimant for the non monetary aspects of the specific harm suffered
lines.name: English

lines.value: this is usually termed pain suffering and loss of amenity
lines.name: English

lines.value: examples of this include physical or emotional pain and suffering loss of companionship loss of consortium disfigurement loss of reputation loss or impairment of mental or physical capacity hedonic damages or loss of enjoyment of life etc this is not easily quantifiable and depends on the individual circumstances of the claimant
lines.name: English

lines.value: judges in the united kingdom base the award on damages awarded in similar previous cases
lines.name: English

lines.value: general damages are generally awarded only in claims brought by individuals when they have suffered personal harm
lines.name: English

lines.value: examples would be personal injury following the tort of negligence by the defendant or the tort of defamation
lines.name: English

lines.value: speculative damages are damages that have not yet occurred but the plaintiff expects them to
lines.name: English

lines.value: typically these damages cannot be recovered unless the plaintiff can prove that they are reasonably likely to occur
lines.name: English

lines.value: statutory damages are an amount stipulated within the statute rather than calculated based on the degree of harm to the plaintiff
lines.name: English

lines.value: lawmakers will provide for statutory damages for acts in which it is difficult to determine the value of the harm to the victim
lines.name: English

lines.value: mere violation of the law can entitle the victim to a statutory award even if no actual injury occurred
lines.name: English

lines.value: these are similar to but different from nominal damages see below in which no written sum is specified
lines.name: English

lines.value: nominal damages are very small damages awarded to show that the loss or harm suffered was technical rather than actual
lines.name: English

lines.value: perhaps the most famous nominal damages award in modern times has been the $1 verdict against the national football league nfl in the 1986 antitrust suit prosecuted by the united states football league
lines.name: English

lines.value: although the verdict was automatically trebled pursuant to antitrust law in the united states the resulting $3 judgment was regarded as a victory for the nfl
lines.name: English

lines.value: historically one of the best known nominal damage awards was the farthing that the jury awarded to james whistler in his libel suit against john ruskin
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the english jurisdiction nominal damages are generally fixed at £2.many times a party that has been wronged but is not able to prove significant damages will sue for nominal damages
lines.name: English

lines.value: this is particularly common in cases involving alleged violations of constitutional rights such as freedom of speech
lines.name: English

lines.value: contemptuous damages are a form of damage award available in some jurisdictions
lines.name: English

lines.value: they are similar to nominal damages awards as they are given when the plaintiff's suit is trivial used only to settle a point of honour or law
lines.name: English

lines.value: awards are usually of the smallest amount usually 1 cent or similar
lines.name: English

lines.value: the key distinction is that in jurisdictions that follow the loser pays for attorney fees the claimaint in a contemptuous damages case may be required to pay his or her own attorney fees
lines.name: English

lines.value: traditionally the court awarded the smallest coin in the realm which in england was one farthing 1/960 of a pound before decimalisation in the 1970s
lines.name: English

lines.value: court costs are not awarded
lines.name: English

lines.value: generally punitive damages which are also termed exemplary damages in the united kingdom are not awarded in order to compensate the plaintiff but in order to reform or deter the defendant and similar persons from pursuing a course of action such as that which damaged the plaintiff
lines.name: English

lines.value: punitive damages are awarded only in special cases where conduct was egregiously insidious and are over and above the amount of compensatory damages such as in the event of malice or intent
lines.name: English

lines.value: great judicial restraint is expected to be exercised in their application
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the united states punitive damages awards are subject to the limitations imposed by the due process of law clauses of the fifth and fourteenth amendments to the united states constitution
lines.name: English

lines.value: in england and wales exemplary damages are limited to the circumstances set out by lord devlin in the leading case of rookes v barnard
lines.name: English

lines.value: they are punitive damages awarded in a us case would be difficult to get recognition for in a european court where punitive damages are most likely to be considered to violate ordre public
lines.name: English

lines.value: some jurisdictions recognize a form of damages called aggravated damages that are similar to punitive or exemplary damages
lines.name: English

lines.value: aggravated damages are not often awarded they apply where the injury has been aggravated by the wrongdoer's behaviour for example their cruelty
lines.name: English

lines.value: in certain areas of the law another head of damages has long been available whereby the defendant is made to give up the profits made through the civil wrong in restitution
lines.name: English

lines.value: doyle and wright define restitutionary damages as being a monetary remedy that is measured according to the defendant's gain rather than the plaintiff's loss
lines.name: English

lines.value: the plaintiff thereby gains damages which are not measured by reference to any loss sustained
lines.name: English

lines.value: in some areas of the law this heading of damages is uncontroversial most particularly intellectual property rights and breach of fiduciary relationship
lines.name: English

lines.value: in england and wales the house of lords case of attorney general v blake opened up the possibility of restitutionary damages for breach of contract
lines.name: English

lines.value: in this case the profits made by a defecting spy george blake for the publication of his book were awarded to the british government for breach of contract
lines.name: English

lines.value: the case has been followed in english courts but the situations in which restitutionary damages will be available remain unclear
lines.name: English

lines.value: the basis for restitutionary damages is much debated but is usually seen as based on denying a wrongdoer any profit from his wrongdoing
lines.name: English

lines.value: the really difficult question and one which is currently unanswered relates to what wrongs should allow this remedy
lines.name: English

lines.value: in addition to damages the successful party is entitled to be awarded their reasonable legal costs that they spent during the case
lines.name: English

lines.value: this is the rule in most countries other than the united states
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the united states a party generally is not entitled to its attorneys fees or for hardships undergone during trial unless the parties agreed in a contract that attorney's fees should be covered or a specific statute or law permits recovery of legal fees such as discrimination
lines.name: English

lines.value: the quantification of personal injury is not an exact science
lines.name: English

lines.value: in english law solicitors like to call personal injury claims as general damages for pain and suffering and loss of amenity psla
lines.name: English

lines.value: solicitors quantify personal injury claims by reference to previous awards made by the courts which are similar to the case in hand
lines.name: English

lines.value: the guidance solicitors will take into account to help quantify general damages are as hereunder
lines.name: English

lines.value: the age of the client is important especially when dealing with fatal accident claims or permanent injuries
lines.name: English

lines.value: the younger the injured victim with a permanent injury the longer that person has to live with the psla
lines.name: English

lines.value: as a consequence the greater the compensation payment
lines.name: English

lines.value: in fatal accident claims generally the younger deceased the greater the dependency claim by the partner and children
lines.name: English

lines.value: solicitors will consider like for like injuries with the case in hand and similar cases decided by the courts previously
lines.name: English

lines.value: these cases are known as precedents
lines.name: English

lines.value: generally speaking decisions from the higher courts will bind the lower courts
lines.name: English

lines.value: therefore judgments from the house of lords and the court of appeal have greater authority than the lower courts such as the high court and the county court
lines.name: English

lines.value: a compensation award can only be right or wrong with reference to that specific judgment
lines.name: English

lines.value: solicitors must be careful when looking at older cases when quantifying a claim to ensure that the award is brought up to date and to take into account the court of appeal case in heil v rankin generally speaking the greater the injury the greater the damages awarded
lines.name: English

lines.value: this heading is inextricably linked with the other points above
lines.name: English

lines.value: where two clients are of the same age experience and suffer the same injury it does not necessarily mean that they will be affected the same
lines.name: English

lines.value: we are all different
lines.name: English

lines.value: some people will recover more quickly than others
lines.name: English

lines.value: the courts will assess each claim on its own particular facts and therefore if one claimant recovers more quickly than another the damages will be reflected accordingly
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is important to note here that psychological injuries may also follow from an accident which may increase the quantum of damages
lines.name: English

lines.value: when a personal injury claim is settled either in court or out of court the most common way the compensation payment is made is by a lump sum award in full and final settlement of the claim
lines.name: English

lines.value: once accepted there can be no further award for compensation at a later time unless the claim is settled by provisional damages often found in industrial injury claims such as asbestos related injuries
lines.name: English
