lines.value: multics multiplexed information and computing service is an influential early time sharing operating system based around the concept of a single level memory
lines.name: English

lines.value: virtually all modern operating systems were heavily influenced by multics often through unix which had been created by the people who had worked on multics either directly linux macos or indirectly microsoft windows nt
lines.name: English

lines.value: initial planning and development for multics started in 1964 in cambridge massachusetts
lines.name: English

lines.value: originally it was a cooperative project led by mit project mac with fernando corbato along with general electric and bell labs
lines.name: English

lines.value: multics was conceived as a commercial product for general electric and became one for honeywell albeit not very successfully
lines.name: English

lines.value: due to its many novel and valuable ideas multics had a significant impact on computer science despite its faults
lines.name: English

lines.value: multics had numerous features intended to ensure high availability so that it would support a computing utility similar to the telephone and electricity utilities
lines.name: English

lines.value: modular hardware structure and software architecture were used to achieve this
lines.name: English

lines.value: the system could grow in size by simply adding more of the appropriate resource be it computing power main memory or disk storage
lines.name: English

lines.value: separate access control lists on every file provided flexible information sharing but complete privacy when needed
lines.name: English

lines.value: multics had a number of standard mechanisms to allow engineers to analyze the performance of the system as well as a number of adaptive performance optimization mechanisms
lines.name: English

lines.value: multics implemented a single level store for data access discarding the clear distinction between files called segments in multics and process memory
lines.name: English

lines.value: the memory of a process consisted solely of segments that were mapped into its address space
lines.name: English

lines.value: to read or write to them the process simply used normal central processing unit cpu instructions and the operating system took care of making sure that all the modifications were saved to disk
lines.name: English

lines.value: in posix terminology it was as if every file were ed however in multics there was no concept of process memory separate from the memory used to hold mapped in files as unix has
lines.name: English

lines.value: all memory in the system was part of some segment which appeared in the file system this included the temporary scratch memory of the process its kernel stack etc.one disadvantage of this was that the size of segments was limited to 256 kilowords just over 1 mib
lines.name: English

lines.value: this was due to the particular hardware architecture of the machines on which multics ran having a 36-bit word size and index registers used to address within segments of half that size 18 bits
lines.name: English

lines.value: extra code had to be used to work on files larger than this called multisegment files
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the days when one megabyte of memory was prohibitively expensive and before large databases and later huge bitmap graphics this limit was rarely encountered
lines.name: English

lines.value: another major new idea of multics was dynamic linking in which a running process could request that other segments be added to its address space segments which could contain code that it could then execute
lines.name: English

lines.value: this allowed applications to automatically use the latest version of any external routine they called since those routines were kept in other segments which were dynamically linked only when a process first tried to begin execution in them
lines.name: English

lines.value: since different processes could use different search rules different users could end up using different versions of external routines automatically
lines.name: English

lines.value: equally importantly with the appropriate settings on the multics security facilities the code in the other segment could then gain access to data structures maintained in a different process
lines.name: English

lines.value: thus to interact with an application running in part as a daemon in another process a user's process simply performed a normal procedure call instruction to a code segment to which it had dynamically linked a code segment that implemented some operation associated with the daemon
lines.name: English

lines.value: the code in that segment could then modify data maintained and used in the daemon
lines.name: English

lines.value: when the action necessary to commence the request was completed a simple procedure return instruction returned control of the user's process to the user's code
lines.name: English

lines.value: the single level store and dynamic linking are still not available to their full power in other widely used operating systems despite the rapid and enormous advance in the computer field since the 1960s
lines.name: English

lines.value: they are becoming more widely accepted and available in more limited forms for example dynamic linking
lines.name: English

lines.value: multics also supported extremely aggressive on line reconfiguration central processing units memory banks disk drives etc could be added and removed while the system continued operating
lines.name: English

lines.value: at the mit system where most early software development was done it was common practice to split the multiprocessor system into two separate systems during off hours by incrementally removing enough components to form a second working system leaving the rest still running the original logged in users
lines.name: English

lines.value: system software development testing could be done on the second machine then the components of the second system were added back onto the main user system without ever having shut it down
lines.name: English

lines.value: multics supported multiple cpus it was one of the earliest multiprocessor systems
lines.name: English

lines.value: multics was the first major operating system to be designed as a secure system from the outset
lines.name: English

lines.value: despite this early versions of multics were broken into repeatedly
lines.name: English

lines.value: this led to further work that made the system much more secure and prefigured modern security engineering techniques
lines.name: English

lines.value: break ins became very rare once the second generation hardware base was adopted it had hardware support for ring oriented security a multilevel refinement of the concept of master mode
lines.name: English

lines.value: multics was the first operating system to provide a hierarchical file system and file names could be of almost arbitrary length and syntax
lines.name: English

lines.value: a given file or directory could have multiple names typically a long and short form and symbolic links between directories were also supported
lines.name: English

lines.value: multics was the first to use the now standard concept of per process stacks in the kernel with a separate stack for each security ring
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was also the first to have a command processor implemented as ordinary user code - an idea later used in the unix shell
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was also one of the first written in a high level language multics pl/i after the burroughs mcp system written in algol
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1964 multics was developed initially for the ge 645 mainframe a 36-bit system
lines.name: English

lines.value: ge's computer business including multics was taken over by honeywell in 1970 around 1973 multics was supported on the honeywell 6180 machines which included security improvements including hardware support for protection rings
lines.name: English

lines.value: bell labs pulled out of the project in 1969 some of the people who had worked on it there went on to create the unix system
lines.name: English

lines.value: multics development continued at mit and general electric
lines.name: English

lines.value: honeywell continued system development until 1985
lines.name: English

lines.value: about 80 multimillion dollar sites were installed at universities industry and government sites
lines.name: English

lines.value: the french university system had several installations in the early 1980s
lines.name: English

lines.value: after honeywell stopped supporting multics users migrated to other systems like unix
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1985 multics was issued certification as a b2 level secure operating system using the trusted computer system evaluation criteria from the national computer security center ncsc a division of the nsa the first operating system evaluated to this level
lines.name: English

lines.value: multics was distributed from 1975 to 2000 by groupe bull in europe and by bull hn information systems inc in the united states
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2006 bull sas open sourced multics versions mr10.2 mr11.0 mr12.0 mr12.1 mr12.2 mr12.3 mr12.4 & mr12.5
lines.name: English

lines.value: the last known multics installation running natively on honeywell hardware was shut down on october 30 2000 at the canadian department of national defence in halifax nova scotia canada
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2006 bull hn released the source code for mr12.5 the final 1992 multics release to mit
lines.name: English

lines.value: most of the system is now available as open source software with the exception of some optional pieces such as tcp/ip
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2014 multics was successfully run on current hardware using a simulator
lines.name: English

lines.value: the 1.0 release of the simulator is now available
lines.name: English

lines.value: release 12.6f of multics accompanies the 1.0 release of the emulator and adds a few new features including command line recall and editing using the video system
lines.name: English

lines.value: dr peter h salus author of the definitive history of unix's early years stated one position with multics they tried to have a much more versatile and flexible operating system and it failed miserably this position however has been widely discredited in the computing community as many of the technical innovations of the multics project have found their way into modern commercial computing systems
lines.name: English

lines.value: the permanently resident kernel of this powerful multiprocessor mainframe computing utility much derided in its day as being too large and complex was only 135 kb of code
lines.name: English

lines.value: in comparison a linux system in 2007 might have occupied 18 mb
lines.name: English

lines.value: the first mit ge 645 had 512 kilowords of memory 2 mib a truly enormous amount at the time and the kernel used only a moderate portion of multics main memory
lines.name: English

lines.value: the entire system including the operating system and the complex pl/1 compiler user commands and subroutine libraries consisted of about 1500 source modules
lines.name: English

lines.value: these averaged roughly 200 lines of source code each and compiled to produce a total of roughly 4.5 mib of procedure code which was fairly large by the standards of the day
lines.name: English

lines.value: multics compilers generally optimised more for code density than cpu performance for example using small sub routines called operators for short standard code sequences making direct comparison of object code size with more modern systems less useful
lines.name: English

lines.value: high code density was a good optimisation choice for a multi user system with expensive main memory such as multics
lines.name: English

lines.value: the design and features of multics greatly influenced the unix operating system which was originally written by two multics programmers ken thompson and dennis ritchie
lines.name: English

lines.value: superficial influence of multics on unix is evident in many areas including the naming of some commands
lines.name: English

lines.value: but the internal design philosophy was quite different focusing on keeping the system small and simple and so correcting some deficiencies of multics because of its high resource demands on the limited computer hardware of the time
lines.name: English

lines.value: the name unix originally unics is itself a pun on multics
lines.name: English

lines.value: the u in unix is rumored to stand for ed as opposed to the ed of multics further underscoring the designers rejections of multics complexity in favor of a more straightforward and workable approach for smaller computers
lines.name: English

lines.value: garfinkel and abelson cite an alternative origin peter neumann at bell labs watching a demonstration of the prototype suggested the name pun unics pronounced eunuchs as a castrated multics although dennis ritchie is claimed to have denied this
lines.name: English

lines.value: )ken thompson in a transcribed 2007 interview with peter seibel refers to multics as ...overdesigned and overbuilt and over everything
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was close to unusable
lines.name: English

lines.value: they i.e massachusetts institute of technology still claim it's a monstrous success but it just clearly wasn't he admits however that the things that i liked enough about multics to actually take were the hierarchical file system and the shell a separate process that you can replace with some other process
lines.name: English

lines.value: the prime computer operating system primos was referred to as multics in a shoebox by william poduska a founder of the company
lines.name: English

lines.value: poduska later moved on to found apollo computer whose aegis and later domain/os operating systems sometimes called multics in a matchbox extended the multics design to a heavily networked graphics workstation environment
lines.name: English

lines.value: the stratus vos operating system of stratus computer now stratus technologies was very strongly influenced by multics and both its external user interface and internal structure bear many close resemblances to the older project
lines.name: English

lines.value: the high reliability availability and security features of multics were extended in stratus vos to support a new line of fault tolerant computer systems supporting secure reliable transaction processing
lines.name: English

lines.value: stratus vos is the most directly related descendant of multics still in active development and production usage today
lines.name: English

lines.value: the protection architecture of multics restricting the ability of code at one level of the system to access resources at another was adopted as the basis for the security features of icl's vme operating system
lines.name: English

lines.value: the literature contains a large number of papers about multics and various components of it a fairly complete list is available at the multics bibliography page
lines.name: English

lines.value: the most important and or informative ones are listed below
lines.name: English

lines.value: a quark () is a type of elementary particle and a fundamental constituent of matter
lines.name: English

lines.value: quarks combine to form composite particles called hadrons the most stable of which are protons and neutrons the components of atomic nuclei
lines.name: English

lines.value: due to a phenomenon known as color confinement quarks are never directly observed or found in isolation they can be found only within hadrons such as baryons of which protons and neutrons are examples and mesons
lines.name: English

lines.value: for this reason much of what is known about quarks has been drawn from observations of the hadrons themselves
lines.name: English

lines.value: quarks have various intrinsic properties including electric charge mass color charge and spin
lines.name: English

lines.value: quarks are the only elementary particles in the standard model of particle physics to experience all four fundamental interactions also known as fundamental forces electromagnetism gravitation strong interaction and weak interaction as well as the only known particles whose electric charges are not integer multiples of the elementary charge
lines.name: English

lines.value: there are six types of quarks known as flavors up down strange charm top and bottom
lines.name: English

lines.value: up and down quarks have the lowest masses of all quarks
lines.name: English

lines.value: the heavier quarks rapidly change into up and down quarks through a process of particle decay the transformation from a higher mass state to a lower mass state
lines.name: English

lines.value: because of this up and down quarks are generally stable and the most common in the universe whereas strange charm bottom and top quarks can only be produced in high energy collisions such as those involving cosmic rays and in particle accelerators
lines.name: English

lines.value: for every quark flavor there is a corresponding type of antiparticle known as an antiquark that differs from the quark only in that some of its properties have equal magnitude but opposite sign
lines.name: English

lines.value: the quark model was independently proposed by physicists murray gell mann and george zweig in 1964
lines.name: English

lines.value: quarks were introduced as parts of an ordering scheme for hadrons and there was little evidence for their physical existence until deep inelastic scattering experiments at the stanford linear accelerator center in 1968
lines.name: English

lines.value: accelerator experiments have provided evidence for all six flavors
lines.name: English

lines.value: the top quark was the last to be discovered at fermilab in 1995
lines.name: English

lines.value: the standard model is the theoretical framework describing all the currently known elementary particles
lines.name: English

lines.value: this model contains six flavors of quarks (), named up (), down (), charm (), strange (), top (), and bottom ().
lines.name: English

lines.value: antiparticles of quarks are called antiquarks and are denoted by a bar over the symbol for the corresponding quark such as for an up antiquark
lines.name: English

lines.value: as with antimatter in general antiquarks have the same mass mean lifetime and spin as their respective quarks but the electric charge and other charges have the opposite sign
lines.name: English

lines.value: quarks are spin particles implying that they are fermions according to the spin statistics theorem
lines.name: English

lines.value: they are subject to the pauli exclusion principle which states that no two identical fermions can simultaneously occupy the same quantum state
lines.name: English

lines.value: this is in contrast to bosons particles with integer spin any number of which can be in the same state
lines.name: English

lines.value: unlike leptons quarks possess color charge which causes them to engage in the strong interaction
lines.name: English

lines.value: the resulting attraction between different quarks causes the formation of composite particles known as hadrons see strong interaction and color charge below
lines.name: English

lines.value: the quarks that determine the quantum numbers of hadrons are called valence quarks apart from these any hadron may contain an indefinite number of virtual or sea quarks antiquarks and gluons which do not influence its quantum numbers
lines.name: English

lines.value: there are two families of hadrons baryons with three valence quarks and mesons with a valence quark and an antiquark
lines.name: English

lines.value: the most common baryons are the proton and the neutron the building blocks of the atomic nucleus
lines.name: English

lines.value: a great number of hadrons are known see list of baryons and list of mesons most of them differentiated by their quark content and the properties these constituent quarks confer
lines.name: English

lines.value: the existence of exotic hadrons with more valence quarks such as tetraquarks () and pentaquarks (), were conjectured from the beginnings of the quark model but not discovered until the early 21st century
lines.name: English

lines.value: elementary fermions are grouped into three generations each comprising two leptons and two quarks
lines.name: English

lines.value: the first generation includes up and down quarks the second strange and charm quarks and the third bottom and top quarks
lines.name: English

lines.value: all searches for a fourth generation of quarks and other elementary fermions have failed and there is strong indirect evidence that no more than three generations exist
lines.name: English

lines.value: particles in higher generations generally have greater mass and less stability causing them to decay into lower generation particles by means of weak interactions
lines.name: English

lines.value: only first generation up and down quarks occur commonly in nature
lines.name: English

lines.value: heavier quarks can only be created in high energy collisions such as in those involving cosmic rays and decay quickly however they are thought to have been present during the first fractions of a second after the big bang when the universe was in an extremely hot and dense phase the quark epoch
lines.name: English

lines.value: studies of heavier quarks are conducted in artificially created conditions such as in particle accelerators
lines.name: English

lines.value: having electric charge mass color charge and flavor quarks are the only known elementary particles that engage in all four fundamental interactions of contemporary physics electromagnetism gravitation strong interaction and weak interaction
lines.name: English

lines.value: gravitation is too weak to be relevant to individual particle interactions except at extremes of energy planck energy and distance scales planck distance
lines.name: English

lines.value: however since no successful quantum theory of gravity exists gravitation is not described by the standard model
lines.name: English

lines.value: see the table of properties below for a more complete overview of the six quark flavors properties
lines.name: English

lines.value: the quark model was independently proposed by physicists murray gell mann and george zweig in 1964
lines.name: English

lines.value: the proposal came shortly after gell mann's 1961 formulation of a particle classification system known as the eightfold way or in more technical terms su(3 flavor symmetry streamlining its structure
lines.name: English

lines.value: physicist yuval ne'eman had independently developed a scheme similar to the eightfold way in the same year
lines.name: English

lines.value: an early attempt at constituent organization was available in the sakata model
lines.name: English

lines.value: at the time of the quark theory's inception the particle zoo included amongst other particles a multitude of hadrons
lines.name: English

lines.value: gell mann and zweig posited that they were not elementary particles but were instead composed of combinations of quarks and antiquarks
lines.name: English

lines.value: their model involved three flavors of quarks up down and strange to which they ascribed properties such as spin and electric charge
lines.name: English

lines.value: the initial reaction of the physics community to the proposal was mixed
lines.name: English

lines.value: there was particular contention about whether the quark was a physical entity or a mere abstraction used to explain concepts that were not fully understood at the time
lines.name: English

lines.value: in less than a year extensions to the gell mann zweig model were proposed
lines.name: English

lines.value: sheldon lee glashow and james bjorken predicted the existence of a fourth flavor of quark which they called charm
lines.name: English

lines.value: the addition was proposed because it allowed for a better description of the weak interaction the mechanism that allows quarks to decay equalized the number of known quarks with the number of known leptons and implied a mass formula that correctly reproduced the masses of the known mesons
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1968 deep inelastic scattering experiments at the stanford linear accelerator center slac showed that the proton contained much smaller point like objects and was therefore not an elementary particle
lines.name: English

lines.value: physicists were reluctant to firmly identify these objects with quarks at the time instead calling them partons a term coined by richard feynman
lines.name: English

lines.value: the objects that were observed at slac would later be identified as up and down quarks as the other flavors were discovered
lines.name: English

lines.value: nevertheless parton remains in use as a collective term for the constituents of hadrons quarks antiquarks and gluons
lines.name: English

lines.value: the strange quark's existence was indirectly validated by slac's scattering experiments not only was it a necessary component of gell mann and zweig's three quark model but it provided an explanation for the kaon () and pion () hadrons discovered in cosmic rays in 1947
lines.name: English

lines.value: in a 1970 paper glashow john iliopoulos and luciano maiani presented the so called gim mechanism to explain the experimental non observation of flavor changing neutral currents
lines.name: English

lines.value: this theoretical model required the existence of the as yet undiscovered charm quark
lines.name: English

lines.value: the number of supposed quark flavors grew to the current six in 1973 when makoto kobayashi and toshihide maskawa noted that the experimental observation of cp violation could be explained if there were another pair of quarks
lines.name: English

lines.value: charm quarks were produced almost simultaneously by two teams in november 1974 see november revolution)one at slac under burton richter and one at brookhaven national laboratory under samuel ting
lines.name: English

lines.value: the charm quarks were observed bound with charm antiquarks in mesons
lines.name: English

lines.value: the two parties had assigned the discovered meson two different symbols and ; thus it became formally known as the meson
lines.name: English

lines.value: the discovery finally convinced the physics community of the quark model's validity
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the following years a number of suggestions appeared for extending the quark model to six quarks
lines.name: English

lines.value: of these the 1975 paper by haim harari was the first to coin the terms top and bottom for the additional quarks
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1977 the bottom quark was observed by a team at fermilab led by leon lederman
lines.name: English

lines.value: this was a strong indicator of the top quark's existence without the top quark the bottom quark would have been without a partner
lines.name: English

lines.value: however it was not until 1995 that the top quark was finally observed also by the cdf and do teams at fermilab
lines.name: English

lines.value: it had a mass much larger than had been previously expected almost as large as that of a gold atom
lines.name: English

lines.value: for some time gell mann was undecided on an actual spelling for the term he intended to coin until he found the word quark in james joyce's book finnegans wake the word quark itself is of german origin and denotes a dairy product but is also a colloquial term for rubbish
lines.name: English

lines.value: gell mann went into further detail regarding the name of the quark in his book the quark and the jaguar zweig preferred the name ace for the particle he had theorized but gell mann's terminology came to prominence once the quark model had been commonly accepted
lines.name: English

lines.value: the quark flavors were given their names for several reasons
lines.name: English

lines.value: the up and down quarks are named after the up and down components of isospin which they carry
lines.name: English

lines.value: strange quarks were given their name because they were discovered to be components of the strange particles discovered in cosmic rays years before the quark model was proposed these particles were deemed strange because they had unusually long lifetimes
lines.name: English

lines.value: glashow who co proposed charm quark with bjorken is quoted as saying we called our construct the charmed quark for we were fascinated and pleased by the symmetry it brought to the subnuclear world the names bottom and top coined by harari were chosen because they are logical partners for up and down quarks
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the past bottom and top quarks were sometimes referred to as beauty and truth respectively but these names have somewhat fallen out of use
lines.name: English

lines.value: while truth never did catch on accelerator complexes devoted to massive production of bottom quarks are sometimes called beauty factories
lines.name: English

lines.value: quarks have fractional electric charge values - either - or () times the elementary charge e depending on flavor
lines.name: English

lines.value: up charm and top quarks collectively referred to as up type quarks have a charge of + e while down strange and bottom quarks down-type quarks have − e antiquarks have the opposite charge to their corresponding quarks up type antiquarks have charges of − e and down type antiquarks have charges of + e since the electric charge of a hadron is the sum of the charges of the constituent quarks all hadrons have integer charges the combination of three quarks baryons three antiquarks antibaryons or a quark and an antiquark mesons always results in integer charges
lines.name: English

lines.value: for example the hadron constituents of atomic nuclei neutrons and protons have charges of 0 e and +1 e respectively the neutron is composed of two down quarks and one up quark and the proton of two up quarks and one down quark
lines.name: English

lines.value: spin is an intrinsic property of elementary particles and its direction is an important degree of freedom
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is sometimes visualized as the rotation of an object around its own axis hence the name ""), though this notion is somewhat misguided at subatomic scales because elementary particles are believed to be point like
lines.name: English

lines.value: spin can be represented by a vector whose length is measured in units of the reduced planck constant h pronounced h bar
lines.name: English

lines.value: for quarks a measurement of the spin vector component along any axis can only yield the values +h/2 or −h/2 for this reason quarks are classified as spin particles
lines.name: English

lines.value: the component of spin along a given axis - by convention the z axis - is often denoted by an up arrow ↑ for the value + and down arrow ↓ for the value − placed after the symbol for flavor
lines.name: English

lines.value: for example an up quark with a spin of + along the z axis is denoted by u↑
lines.name: English

lines.value: a quark of one flavor can transform into a quark of another flavor only through the weak interaction one of the four fundamental interactions in particle physics
lines.name: English

lines.value: by absorbing or emitting a w boson any up type quark up charm and top quarks can change into any down type quark down strange and bottom quarks and vice versa
lines.name: English

lines.value: this flavor transformation mechanism causes the radioactive process of beta decay in which a neutron () splits into a proton (), an electron () and an electron antineutrino () see picture
lines.name: English

lines.value: this occurs when one of the down quarks in the neutron () decays into an up quark by emitting a virtual boson transforming the neutron into a proton ().
lines.name: English

lines.value: the boson then decays into an electron and an electron antineutrino
lines.name: English

lines.value: both beta decay and the inverse process of inverse beta decay are routinely used in medical applications such as positron emission tomography pet and in experiments involving neutrino detection
lines.name: English

lines.value: while the process of flavor transformation is the same for all quarks each quark has a preference to transform into the quark of its own generation
lines.name: English

lines.value: the relative tendencies of all flavor transformations are described by a mathematical table called the cabibbo kobayashi maskawa matrix ckm matrix
lines.name: English

lines.value: enforcing unitarity the approximate magnitudes of the entries of the ckm matrix are where v ij represents the tendency of a quark of flavor i to change into a quark of flavor j or vice versa
lines.name: English

lines.value: there exists an equivalent weak interaction matrix for leptons right side of the w boson on the above beta decay diagram called the pontecorvo maki nakagawa sakata matrix pmns matrix
lines.name: English

lines.value: together the ckm and pmns matrices describe all flavor transformations but the links between the two are not yet clear
lines.name: English

lines.value: according to quantum chromodynamics qcd quarks possess a property called color charge
lines.name: English

lines.value: there are three types of color charge arbitrarily labeled blue green and red
lines.name: English

lines.value: each of them is complemented by an anticolor - antiblue antigreen and antired
lines.name: English

lines.value: every quark carries a color while every antiquark carries an anticolor
lines.name: English

lines.value: the system of attraction and repulsion between quarks charged with different combinations of the three colors is called strong interaction which is mediated by force carrying particles known as gluons this is discussed at length below
lines.name: English

lines.value: the theory that describes strong interactions is called quantum chromodynamics qcd
lines.name: English

lines.value: a quark which will have a single color value can form a bound system with an antiquark carrying the corresponding anticolor
lines.name: English

lines.value: the result of two attracting quarks will be color neutrality a quark with color charge e plus an antiquark with color charge −e will result in a color charge of 0 or white color and the formation of a meson
lines.name: English

lines.value: this is analogous to the additive color model in basic optics
lines.name: English

lines.value: similarly the combination of three quarks each with different color charges or three antiquarks each with anticolor charges will result in the same white color charge and the formation of a baryon or antibaryon
lines.name: English

lines.value: in modern particle physics gauge symmetries - a kind of symmetry group - relate interactions between particles see gauge theories
lines.name: English

lines.value: color su(3 commonly abbreviated to su(3 c ) is the gauge symmetry that relates the color charge in quarks and is the defining symmetry for quantum chromodynamics
lines.name: English

lines.value: just as the laws of physics are independent of which directions in space are designated x y and z and remain unchanged if the coordinate axes are rotated to a new orientation the physics of quantum chromodynamics is independent of which directions in three dimensional color space are identified as blue red and green
lines.name: English

lines.value: su(3 c color transformations correspond to rotations in color space which mathematically speaking is a complex space
lines.name: English

lines.value: every quark flavor f each with subtypes f b f g , f r corresponding to the quark colors forms a triplet a three component quantum field which transforms under the fundamental representation of su(3 c
lines.name: English

lines.value: the requirement that su(3 c should be local - that is that its transformations be allowed to vary with space and time - determines the properties of the strong interaction
lines.name: English

lines.value: in particular it implies the existence of eight gluon types to act as its force carriers
lines.name: English

lines.value: two terms are used in referring to a quark's mass current quark mass refers to the mass of a quark by itself while constituent quark mass refers to the current quark mass plus the mass of the gluon particle field surrounding the quark
lines.name: English

lines.value: these masses typically have very different values
lines.name: English

lines.value: most of a hadron's mass comes from the gluons that bind the constituent quarks together rather than from the quarks themselves
lines.name: English

lines.value: while gluons are inherently massless they possess energy - more specifically quantum chromodynamics binding energy qcbe - and it is this that contributes so greatly to the overall mass of the hadron see mass in special relativity
lines.name: English

lines.value: for example a proton has a mass of approximately 938 mev/c 2 of which the rest mass of its three valence quarks only contributes about 9 mev/c 2 ; much of the remainder can be attributed to the field energy of the gluons
lines.name: English

lines.value: see chiral symmetry breaking
lines.name: English

lines.value: the standard model posits that elementary particles derive their masses from the higgs mechanism which is associated to the higgs boson
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is hoped that further research into the reasons for the top quark's large mass of ~173 gev/c 2 almost the mass of a gold atom might reveal more about the origin of the mass of quarks and other elementary particles
lines.name: English

lines.value: the following table summarizes the key properties of the six quarks
lines.name: English

lines.value: flavor quantum numbers isospin i 3 ), charm c strangeness s not to be confused with spin topness t and bottomness b are assigned to certain quark flavors and denote qualities of quark based systems and hadrons
lines.name: English

lines.value: the baryon number b is + for all quarks as baryons are made of three quarks
lines.name: English

lines.value: for antiquarks the electric charge q and all flavor quantum numbers b i 3 c s t and b are of opposite sign
lines.name: English

lines.value: mass and total angular momentum j equal to spin for point particles do not change sign for the antiquarks
lines.name: English

lines.value: j = total angular momentum b = baryon number q = electric charge i 3 = isospin c = charm s = strangeness t = topness b = bottomness
lines.name: English

lines.value: * notation such as ± 710 denotes two types of measurement uncertainty
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the case of the top quark the first uncertainty is statistical in nature and the second is systematic
lines.name: English

lines.value: as described by quantum chromodynamics the strong interaction between quarks is mediated by gluons massless vector gauge bosons
lines.name: English

lines.value: each gluon carries one color charge and one anticolor charge
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the standard framework of particle interactions part of a more general formulation known as perturbation theory gluons are constantly exchanged between quarks through a virtual emission and absorption process
lines.name: English

lines.value: when a gluon is transferred between quarks a color change occurs in both for example if a red quark emits a redantigreen gluon it becomes green and if a green quark absorbs a redantigreen gluon it becomes red
lines.name: English

lines.value: therefore while each quark's color constantly changes their strong interaction is preserved
lines.name: English

lines.value: since gluons carry color charge they themselves are able to emit and absorb other gluons
lines.name: English

lines.value: this causes asymptotic freedom as quarks come closer to each other the chromodynamic binding force between them weakens
lines.name: English

lines.value: conversely as the distance between quarks increases the binding force strengthens
lines.name: English

lines.value: the color field becomes stressed much as an elastic band is stressed when stretched and more gluons of appropriate color are spontaneously created to strengthen the field
lines.name: English

lines.value: above a certain energy threshold pairs of quarks and antiquarks are created
lines.name: English

lines.value: these pairs bind with the quarks being separated causing new hadrons to form
lines.name: English

lines.value: this phenomenon is known as color confinement quarks never appear in isolation
lines.name: English

lines.value: this process of hadronization occurs before quarks formed in a high energy collision are able to interact in any other way
lines.name: English

lines.value: the only exception is the top quark which may decay before it hadronizes
lines.name: English

lines.value: hadrons contain along with the valence quarks () that contribute to their quantum numbers virtual quark antiquark () pairs known as sea quarks ().
lines.name: English

lines.value: sea quarks form when a gluon of the hadron's color field splits this process also works in reverse in that the annihilation of two sea quarks produces a gluon
lines.name: English

lines.value: the result is a constant flux of gluon splits and creations colloquially known as the sea
lines.name: English

lines.value: sea quarks are much less stable than their valence counterparts and they typically annihilate each other within the interior of the hadron
lines.name: English

lines.value: despite this sea quarks can hadronize into baryonic or mesonic particles under certain circumstances
lines.name: English

lines.value: under sufficiently extreme conditions quarks may become deconfined and exist as free particles
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the course of asymptotic freedom the strong interaction becomes weaker at higher temperatures
lines.name: English

lines.value: eventually color confinement would be lost and an extremely hot plasma of freely moving quarks and gluons would be formed
lines.name: English

lines.value: this theoretical phase of matter is called quark gluon plasma
lines.name: English

lines.value: the exact conditions needed to give rise to this state are unknown and have been the subject of a great deal of speculation and experimentation
lines.name: English

lines.value: a recent estimate puts the needed temperature at kelvin
lines.name: English

lines.value: while a state of entirely free quarks and gluons has never been achieved despite numerous attempts by cern in the 1980s and 1990s recent experiments at the relativistic heavy ion collider have yielded evidence for liquid like quark matter exhibiting nearly perfect fluid motion
lines.name: English

lines.value: the quark gluon plasma would be characterized by a great increase in the number of heavier quark pairs in relation to the number of up and down quark pairs
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is believed that in the period prior to 10 −6 seconds after the big bang the quark epoch the universe was filled with quark gluon plasma as the temperature was too high for hadrons to be stable
lines.name: English

lines.value: given sufficiently high baryon densities and relatively low temperatures - possibly comparable to those found in neutron stars - quark matter is expected to degenerate into a fermi liquid of weakly interacting quarks
lines.name: English

lines.value: this liquid would be characterized by a condensation of colored quark cooper pairs thereby breaking the local su(3 c symmetry
lines.name: English

lines.value: because quark cooper pairs harbor color charge such a phase of quark matter would be color superconductive that is color charge would be able to pass through it with no resistance
lines.name: English

lines.value: chess or the king's game () is a book on chess
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was published in leipzig in 1616 under the name of gustavus selenus gustavus being an anagram of augustus and selenus referring to the greek moon goddess selene linked to the latin origin of the name luneburg the pen name of duke augustus of brunswick luneburg 1579-1666
lines.name: English

lines.value: as a young prince augustus probably had learned of the game during his voyages to italy and purchased numerous chess books from the augsburg merchant and art collector philipp hainhofer
lines.name: English

lines.value: the first textbook on chess in the german language the work is mainly based on the libro de la invencion liberal y arte del juego del axedrez written in 1561 by the spanish priest ruy lopez de segura but also contains extensive philosophical and historical considerations e.g on the chess village of strobeck
lines.name: English

lines.value: in addition to chess instruction the book contained interesting illustrations of contemporary german chess pieces by jacob van der heyden et al the usage for chessmen at the time tended to favor slender designs with nested floral crowns
lines.name: English

lines.value: the book was so successful that pieces of this pattern became known as the selenus chess sets
lines.name: English

lines.value: over time pieces became taller thinner and more elaborate
lines.name: English

lines.value: their apparent floral nature lead some to name them garden chess sets or tulip chess sets
lines.name: English

lines.value: selenus pattern sets were commonly made in germany and central europe until about 1914 when they were completely eclipsed by the more playable and stable staunton chess set pattern which was introduced in 1849 by manufacturer jaques of london
lines.name: English

lines.value: beersel () is a municipality located in the belgian province of flemish brabant
lines.name: English

lines.value: the municipality comprises the towns of alsemberg beersel proper dworp huizingen and lot
lines.name: English

lines.value: on 1 january 2006 beersel had a total population of 23433
lines.name: English

lines.value: the total area is 30.01 km² which gives a population density of 781 inhabitants per km²
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is close to brussels beersel is approximately 12 km southwest of the center of the city
lines.name: English

lines.value: beersel is perhaps best known for the kasteel van beersel beersel castle built between 1300 and 1310 by jan ii the duke of brabant as a defense for brussels
lines.name: English

lines.value: guillaume dufay 1397–1474 the most famous european composer of the 15th century was most likely born in beersel
lines.name: English

lines.value: beersel is known for its boterham met plattekaas en radijzen sandwich with white cheese and radishes usually served with a geuze beer and for its mandjeskaas literally basket cheese which is a white cheese stored in little baskets
lines.name: English

lines.value: beersel also has two traditional authentic geuze breweries oud beersel and 3 fonteinen
lines.name: English

lines.value: extraterritoriality is the state of being exempted from the jurisdiction of local law usually as the result of diplomatic negotiations
lines.name: English

lines.value: historically this primarily applied to individuals as jurisdiction was usually claimed on peoples rather than on lands
lines.name: English

lines.value: extraterritoriality can also be applied to physical places such as foreign embassies military bases of foreign countries or offices of the united nations
lines.name: English

lines.value: the three most common cases recognized today internationally relate to the persons and belongings of foreign heads of state the persons and belongings of ambassadors and other diplomats and ships in international waters
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the past pre modern states generally claimed sovereignty over persons creating something known as personal jurisdiction
lines.name: English

lines.value: as people move between borders this led to in the framework of a territorial jurisdiction certain persons being under the laws of countries in which they did not reside
lines.name: English

lines.value: extraterritoriality in this sense emerges from the interaction of these two conceptions of jurisdiction personal and territorial when laws are applied based on who a person is rather than where they are
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the modern day extraterritoriality can take various forms
lines.name: English

lines.value: most famous are examples of diplomatic extraterritoriality where diplomats and their belongings do not operate under the laws of their host nations but rather under the laws of the diplomat's nation
lines.name: English

lines.value: similarly many nations claim the right to prosecute foreign combatants and violators of human rights under doctrines of universal jurisdiction irrespective of the nationality of those persons or the place in which the alleged crimes occurred
lines.name: English

lines.value: this extends to domestic criminal codes as well for example the people's republic of china claims the right to prosecute chinese citizens for crimes committed abroad
lines.name: English

lines.value: and in some military or commercial agreements some nations cede legal jurisdiction for foreign bases or ports to other countries
lines.name: English

lines.value: for example japan cedes jurisdiction over american military bases on its soil in okinawa to us military tribunals pursuant to a bilateral status of forces agreement
lines.name: English

lines.value: in maritime law ships in international waters are governed by the laws of the jurisdiction in which that ship is registered
lines.name: English

lines.value: this can be conceived of as a form of extraterritoriality where a nation's jurisdiction extends beyond its border per se
lines.name: English

lines.value: during the 13th and 14th centuries the italian sea republics of genoa and venice managed to wrestle extraterritoriality for their quarters pera and galata in the byzantine capital constantinople
lines.name: English

lines.value: they even battled among themselves for further control of the weakened empire
lines.name: English

lines.value: various capitulations were a series of treaties between the sublime porte and western nations from the sixteenth through the early nineteenth centuries
lines.name: English

lines.value: the legal impenetrability of the ottoman legal code created during the tanzimat era began to weaken continuously through the spread of european colonialism and the prevalence of legal positivism
lines.name: English

lines.value: the laws and regulations created for ottoman subjects to abide by often did not apply to european nationals conducting business and trade in the provinces of the empire and thus various capitulations were brought into effect with respect to many foreign powers
lines.name: English

lines.value: the various overlapping governmental laws led to legal pluralism in which jurisdiction often was left up to the great powers to institute and organize their own legal structures to represent their citizens abroad
lines.name: English

lines.value: the capitulations ceased to have effect in turkey in 1923 by virtue of the treaty of lausanne and in egypt they were abolished by the montreux convention in 1949
lines.name: English

lines.value: during the second world war the military personnel of the allied forces within the british raj were governed by their own military codes by the allied forces ordinance 1942 and the members of the united states armed forces were entirely governed by their own laws even in criminal cases
lines.name: English

lines.value: princess margriet of the netherlands was born on 19 january 1943 in ottawa civic hospital ottawa ontario as the family had been living in canada since june 1940 after the occupation of the netherlands by nazi germany
lines.name: English

lines.value: the maternity ward of ottawa civic hospital in which princess margriet was born was temporarily declared to be extraterritorial by the canadian government
lines.name: English

lines.value: making the maternity ward outside of the canadian domain caused it to be unaffiliated with any jurisdiction and technically international territory
lines.name: English

lines.value: this was done to ensure that the newborn would derive her citizenship from her mother only thus making her solely dutch which could be very important had the child been male and as such the heir of princess juliana
lines.name: English

lines.value: the most famous cases of extraterritoriality in east asia are those of 19th century china japan and siam emerging from what is termed the unequal treaties
lines.name: English

lines.value: the practice of extraterritoriality however was not confined to the 19th century or these nations as the monarchs and governments of pre modern east asia primarily claimed sovereignty over people rather than tracts of land
lines.name: English

lines.value: the creation of extraterritoriality for treaty nations was not introduced into east asia ex novo but built atop a long standing legal edifice
lines.name: English

lines.value: jurisdiction in qing dynasty china with differential treatment for han and manchu subjects was not determined by geography but rather by the identity of the subjects
lines.name: English

lines.value: for example the ruling manchu elite possessed legal privileges which placed them outside the jurisdiction of local ethnically chinese administrators
lines.name: English

lines.value: before the treaty of nanking which ended the first opium war foreign merchants were not satisfied with the state of the qing dynasty's legal system
lines.name: English

lines.value: british merchants were suspicious of what they regarded as a tendency in the qing legal order to impose collective responsibility they were also resentful of the qing practice of meting out capital punishment in cases of accidental manslaughter
lines.name: English

lines.value: after a controversial case 1784 case where a british gunner was executed for accidentally killing a chinese subject british east india company officials generally spirited away britons before qing officials could react
lines.name: English

lines.value: grants of extraterritoriality were regular in china
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the 1830s when the qing empire concluded a treaty with the uzbek khanate of khoqand it granted extraterritorial privileges to its traders
lines.name: English

lines.value: and in dealing with foreign merchants through the centuries the qing government rarely attempted to impose jurisdiction based on territorial sovereignty instead entrusting the punishment of foreigners to the respective authority in practically all cases except homicide
lines.name: English

lines.value: at the negotiations of the treaty of nanking qing negotiators readily extended a grant of extraterritoriality
lines.name: English

lines.value: cassel writes the imperial commissioner and manchu nobleman qiying readily conceded extraterritorial privileges to the british in an exchange of notes with pottinger [the british plenipotentiary] at the time of the conclusion of the treaty
lines.name: English

lines.value: this was in line with qing practices at the time where sovereignty was held by peoples rather than imposed on lands
lines.name: English

lines.value: a more formal declaration of extraterritoriality was concluded in the 1843 supplementary treaty of the bogue which established that britons were to be punished according to english law and chinese were to be tried and punished by their own laws
lines.name: English

lines.value: these provisions only applied to the treaty ports since foreigners were barred from entering the chinese interior
lines.name: English

lines.value: under imperial edict earlier in the year these privileges were extended to most western countries
lines.name: English

lines.value: other nations wanted reassurances and guarantees
lines.name: English

lines.value: for example the united states would negotiate the treaty of wangxia which stated in article 21 the wangxia treaty included an exception for american trading in opium and also subjected american ships trading outside treaty ports to confiscation by the chinese government in articles 33 and 3
lines.name: English

lines.value: similarly the french also pursued protections in the treaty of huangpu which further introduced a distinction between criminal and civil jurisdiction non-existent in qing dynasty law and gave frenchmen the full protections of chinese law outside concessionary areas
lines.name: English

lines.value: the sino british treaty of tianjin which ended the second opium war expanded the rights of western visitors their being permitted to enter the chinese interior after passporting
lines.name: English

lines.value: however extraterritorial rights were not extended outside the treaty ports
lines.name: English

lines.value: similar rights were granted to the interested western powers due to the most favoured nation clause all privileges the qing empire granted to one power would be automatically granted to the others
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1868 when the treaties which ended the second opium war were renegotiated british merchants clamoured to lift the travel restrictions on the chinese interior
lines.name: English

lines.value: the qing position was adamantly opposed unless extraterritoriality was also abolished
lines.name: English

lines.value: no compromise was reached and the qing government was successful in preventing foreigners from settling in the interior with extraterritorial privileges
lines.name: English

lines.value: extraterritorial rights were not limited to western nations
lines.name: English

lines.value: under the 1871 sino japanese treaty of tianjin japan and china granted each other reciprocal extraterritorial rights
lines.name: English

lines.value: china itself imposed reciprocal extraterritoriality rights for its own citizens in 19th century korea
lines.name: English

lines.value: however in 1895 under the treaty of shimonoseki china gave up its extraterritorial rights in japan without reciprocity
lines.name: English

lines.value: the most prominent of the treaty ports established after the opium wars was shanghai where the vague extraterritoriality provisions of the various treaties were most sophisticatedly implemented
lines.name: English

lines.value: the two main courts judging extraterritorial cases were the mixed court in the international settlement and the british supreme court for china
lines.name: English

lines.value: similar courts were established for treaty countries e.g the united states court for china
lines.name: English

lines.value: these had jurisdiction over the concession areas which formally remained under qing sovereignty
lines.name: English

lines.value: initially chinese who committed crimes in say the british zone were remanded to chinese authorities
lines.name: English

lines.value: the collapse of qing rule in shanghai during the taiping rebellion led to significant numbers of chinese settling in the international areas where they were ostensibly prohibited from renting property
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the absence of qing administration the people living in the international settlements while legally under qing law were de facto administered by the existing and functioning foreign courts
lines.name: English

lines.value: unsatisfied with this state of affairs in 1864 the mixed court was established with a qing official cooperating with a foreign consul to achieve some verdict
lines.name: English

lines.value: these courts ruled on chinese law applying to chinese subjects and unrepresented foreigners which belonged to non treaty state nations
lines.name: English

lines.value: around the same time the british moved their main court for extraterritorial cases in china from hong kong to shanghai's british concession partly under pressure from qing officials who were concerned with britain sending its subjects all the way to england for punishment
lines.name: English

lines.value: in british extraterritorial courts while qing officials were present in mixed cases they were sidelined
lines.name: English

lines.value: the mixed court itself when trying cases between chinese only similarly sidelined foreign influence
lines.name: English

lines.value: and served for the qing government a symbol of extraterritorial jurisdiction over the chinese community present in the international settlements where chinese were considered foreigners
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the last decade of the qing dynasty with growing nationalist sentiment the problems associated with various different jurisdictions became quite evident as revolutionaries used the protection of foreign jurisdiction to violate qing dynasty sedition and lese-majeste laws
lines.name: English

lines.value: by the early 20th century some western powers were willing to relinquish extraterritorial rights given chinese legal reform
lines.name: English

lines.value: for example the 1902 sino british mackay treaty"'s article 12 read qing law did not make a formal distinction between criminal and civil law
lines.name: English

lines.value: while efforts at legal reform were pursued in earnest in the last decade of the qing dynasty what was actually enacted failed to meaningfully address this lack of law regarding contracts trade or commerce
lines.name: English

lines.value: after the collapse of the chinese government in 1911 and the ensuing administrative vacuum the chinese members of the mixed court were subsequently appointed by the western powers placing all inhabitants of the international settlement under de facto foreign jurisdiction
lines.name: English

lines.value: the success of the northern expedition in increasing the authority of the chinese republic in the mid 1920s led to many governments giving up their more minor treaty ports without a fight
lines.name: English

lines.value: however the treaty powers were unwilling to give up shanghai or their privileges within it which remained the most prominent economic centre and treaty port even as the others were disestablished
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was only after a confrontation between shanghai police and nationalist demonstrators in 1925 that chinese authorities refused to enforce the verdicts of the mixed court this led to its disestablishment in 1927 and replacement with a chinese run local court
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1921 at the conference on the limitation of armament in washington an international resolution was signed expressing the willingness of the parties to end extraterritoriality in china once a satisfactory legal system was established by china
lines.name: English

lines.value: as a result of the resolution a commission was established in 1926 that published a detailed report containing its findings and recommendations for the chinese legal system
lines.name: English

lines.value: extraterritoriality in china for non diplomatic personnel ended at various times in the 20th century
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1937 the status with respect to the various foreign powers china had diplomatic relations with was thus germany and austria hungary lost their rights in china in 1917 after china joined the entente in the first world war
lines.name: English

lines.value: the russian revolution also removed russia from their consuls jurisdiction
lines.name: English

lines.value: while the japanese had unilaterally imposed extraterritoriality in the 1895 treaty of shimonoseki competition between it and the allies during the second world war led to the abolishing of extraterritoriality in nearly all areas of china in 1943 with many legal instruments between many different states ostensibly representing china
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was in this context of competition for chinese support that both the united states and the united kingdom ended relinquished extraterritorial rights via bilateral treaties in 1943 with the treaty for relinquishment of extraterritorial rights in china and the sino british treaty for the relinquishment of extra territorial rights in china
lines.name: English

lines.value: the legacy of this for jurisdictional control continues to the modern day
lines.name: English

lines.value: cassel writes extraterritoriality has left many policy makers in mainland china with a legacy of deeply felt suspicions toward international law international organisations and more recently human rights
lines.name: English

lines.value: with part of its legitimacy resting on claims to strengthening national sovereignty and territorial integrity the people's republic of china's constitution explicitly states that foreigners must abide by prc law
lines.name: English

lines.value: and the prc government claims the right under article 10 of its criminal code to prosecute chinese citizens for crimes against the criminal code which are committed abroad even if already punished for the crime
lines.name: English

lines.value: these emerge from significant claims of the importance of national sovereignty a reaction to its abridgement in the past where almost no nations emphasise the importance of their sovereignty more than china does today
lines.name: English

lines.value: japan recognized extraterritoriality in the treaties concluded with the united states the united kingdom france netherlands and russia in 1858 in connection with the concept of the most favoured nation
lines.name: English

lines.value: various commercial treaties extended extraterritorial protections in japan with various parties including with peru in 1873
lines.name: English

lines.value: most countries exercised extraterritorial jurisdiction through consular courts
lines.name: English

lines.value: britain established the british court for japan in 1879
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1887 only 2389 non chinese foreigners lived in japan with strict limitations on freedom of movement
lines.name: English

lines.value: these limitations meant that foreigners in japan were not able to commit crime with impunity in contrast with china where foreigners were granted the ability to travel to the interior after passporting
lines.name: English

lines.value: rather it was in the context of the japanese state's desire to eliminate all competing jurisdictions and calls for legal reform based on the models of those jurisdictions that japan's government desired to abolish foreign courts
lines.name: English

lines.value: having convinced the western powers that its legal system was sufficiently modern japan succeeded in reforming its unequal status with britain through the 1894 anglo japanese treaty of commerce and navigation in which london would relinquish its japanese extraterritorial rights within five years
lines.name: English

lines.value: similar treaties were signed with other extraterritorial powers around the same time
lines.name: English

lines.value: these treaties all came into effect in 1899 ending extraterritoriality in japan
lines.name: English

lines.value: after the allied victory in 1945 the mutual security assistance pact and its successor treaties between the united states to the modern day grant us military personnel on american bases in okinawa extraterritorial privileges
lines.name: English

lines.value: king mongkut rama iv of siam signed the bowring treaty granting extraterritorial rights to britain in 1855
lines.name: English

lines.value: sir robert hermann schomburgk british consul general from 1859 to 1864 gives an account of his judicial training and responsibilities in a letter to his cousin dated 6 september 1860
lines.name: English

lines.value: unequal treaties were later signed with 13 other european powers and with japan
lines.name: English

lines.value: extraterritoriality came to end in 1917 with respect to the german empire and austria hungary
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 19251926 the treaties were revised to provide for consular jurisdiction to be terminated and nationals of the parties to the treaty were to come under the jurisdiction of thai courts after the introduction of all thai legal codes and a period of 5 years thereafter
lines.name: English

lines.value: by 1930 extraterritoriality was in effect no longer in force
lines.name: English

lines.value: after absolute monarchy was replaced by constitutional monarchy in the bloodless siamese revolution of 1932 the constitutional government promulgated a set of legal codes setting the stage for new treaties signed in 19371938 which canceled extraterritorial rights completely
lines.name: English

lines.value: turin is a village in lewis county new york united states
lines.name: English

lines.value: the village is within the town of turin and is north of the city of rome
lines.name: English

lines.value: as of the 2010 census the village population was 232
lines.name: English

lines.value: the village was previously called turin four corners the early village was the location of three grist mills
lines.name: English

lines.value: turin is located at 43.628921 -75.409355
lines.name: English

lines.value: according to the united states census bureau the village has a total area of 1.0 square miles 2.6 km² all land
lines.name: English

lines.value: turin is west of the black river located on mill creek
lines.name: English

lines.value: the village is located on new york state route 26 state street near the south town line
lines.name: English

lines.value: as of the census of 2000 there were 263 people 101 households and 73 families residing in the village
lines.name: English

lines.value: the population density was 257.2 people per square mile 99.6/km²
lines.name: English

lines.value: there were 134 housing units at an average density of 131.1 per square mile 50.7/km²
lines.name: English

lines.value: the racial makeup of the village was 99.24% white 0.38% native american and 0.38% asian
lines.name: English

lines.value: there were 101 households out of which 30.7% had children under the age of 18 living with them 52.5% were married couples living together 15.8% had a female householder with no husband present and 27.7% were non families
lines.name: English

lines.value: 23.8% of all households were made up of individuals and 10.9% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older
lines.name: English

lines.value: the average household size was 2.60 and the average family size was 3.07
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the village the population was spread out with 28.9% under the age of 18 7.2% from 18 to 24 20.5% from 25 to 44 25.9% from 45 to 64 and 17.5% who were 65 years of age or older
lines.name: English

lines.value: the median age was 41 years
lines.name: English

lines.value: for every 100 females there were 90.6 males
lines.name: English

lines.value: for every 100 females age 18 and over there were 98.9 males
lines.name: English

lines.value: the median income for a household in the village was $36250 and the median income for a family was $42500
lines.name: English

lines.value: males had a median income of $25000 versus $22500 for females
lines.name: English

lines.value: the per capita income for the village was $14157
lines.name: English

lines.value: about 11.4% of families and 10.0% of the population were below the poverty line including 15.7% of those under the age of eighteen and 5.9% of those sixty five or over
lines.name: English

lines.value: joseph antoine ferdinand plateau 14 october 1801 - 15 september 1883 was a belgian physicist
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was one of the first people to demonstrate the illusion of a moving image
lines.name: English

lines.value: to do this he used counter rotating disks with repeating drawn images in small increments of motion on one and regularly spaced slits in the other
lines.name: English

lines.value: he called this device of 1832 the phenakistiscope
lines.name: English

lines.value: his father born in tournai was a talented flower painter
lines.name: English

lines.value: according to at the age of six the young joseph plateau was already able to read and this made him a child prodigy in those times
lines.name: English

lines.value: while attending the primary schools he was particularly impressed by a lesson of physics enchanted by the seen experiments he promised himself to penetrate their secrets sooner or later
lines.name: English

lines.value: he used to spend his school holidays in marche les dames with his uncle and his family his cousin and playfellow was auguste payen who later became an architect and the principal designer of the belgian railways
lines.name: English

lines.value: at the age of fourteen he lost his father and mother the trauma caused by this loss made him fall ill
lines.name: English

lines.value: on 27 august 1840 he married augustine therese aimee fanny clavareau they had a son a year later in 1841
lines.name: English

lines.value: his daughter alice plateau married gustaaf van der mensbrugghe in 1871 who became his collaborator and later his first biographer
lines.name: English

lines.value: fascinated by the persistence of luminous impressions on the retina he performed an experiment in which he gazed directly into the sun for 25 seconds
lines.name: English

lines.value: he lost his eyesight later in his life and attributed the loss to this experiment
lines.name: English

lines.value: however this may not be the case and he may have instead suffered from chronic uveitis
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1872 he became foreign member of the royal netherlands academy of arts and sciences
lines.name: English

lines.value: he died in ghent
lines.name: English

lines.value: born in brussels he studied at the university of liege liege where he graduated as a doctor of physical and mathematical sciences in 1829
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1827 he became a teacher of mathematics at the atheneum school in brussels
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1835 he was appointed professor of experimental physics in ghent university
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1829 joseph plateau submitted his doctoral thesis to his mentor adolphe quetelet for advice
lines.name: English

lines.value: it contained only 27 pages but formulated a great number of fundamental conclusions
lines.name: English

lines.value: it contained the first results of his research into the effect of colours on the retina duration intensity and colour his mathematical research into the intersections of revolving curves locus the observation of the distortion of moving images and the reconstruction of distorted images through counter revolving discs he dubbed these anorthoscopic discs
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1832 plateau invented an early stroboscopic device the phenakistoscope the first device to give the illusion of a moving image
lines.name: English

lines.value: it consisted of two disks one with small equidistant radial windows through which the viewer could look and another containing a sequence of images
lines.name: English

lines.value: when the two disks rotated at the correct speed the synchronization of the windows and the images created an animated effect
lines.name: English

lines.value: the projection of stroboscopic photographs creating the illusion of motion eventually led to the development of cinema
lines.name: English

lines.value: plateau also studied the phenomena of capillary action and surface tension
lines.name: English

lines.value: the mathematical problem of existence of a minimal surface with a given boundary is named after him
lines.name: English

lines.value: he conducted extensive studies of soap films and formulated plateau's laws which describe the structures formed by such films in foams
lines.name: English
